Terrific variety. Location of the hotel was not central. There is a Daiba Station but you can't use your JR Pass on this line and it is pretty pricey (approximately 200-300 yen for each ride). One thing I need to comment on though is my disappointment that Gyn facilities are not available to hotel guests. It is available though, if you pay for it (approximately A$1,000 yen per visit and hours are limited). This is the first five star hotel that I have stayed in that does not provide access to the use of its facilities by being a guest and I really wasn't interested in paying for it.

We got a great last minute deal so decided to spend our last night in Japan in this delightful hotel. Rooms were large, clean, warm, beautiful snd with an awesome view of the Tokyo skyline. We also had dinner in Grill on floor 30 - it was expensive but worth every penny! Easy transfer back to Haneda in the morning, assisted by friendly and helpful staff. We would definitely recommend the hotel and restaurant.

Indeed the hotel is not in the city center but it is just near the public transportation station and with a great promenade. Room 1121 had a beautiful view of the beach during day and night. It is quite far from elevator location but the view is compensating. Nearby is a shopping mall. Very few charging points but it is sufficient. WiFi worked well in the room.

Stayed 2 nights here. Room big & very clean with a good selection of bathroom toiletries. Breakfast buffet was plentiful but get here early had to wait 25 minutes at 7.00.Staff very friendly. Easy walk to the waterfront.

We loved this hotel. Great executive room (bathroom is dated but very spacious and clean), great view (although there is a big Hilton in front that spoils uninterrupted view!), delicious breakfast up on top level restaurant, staff were very kins to our 2 young children which was much appreciated, convenient location for Odaiba shopping. Wish we had stayed our whole trip here now! Have no hesitation recommending the executive rooms.

Well, the hotel of this name used to be on the next door - which was better hotel but with financial streamlining they had to downsize. The old Nikko hotel is now Hilton. They charge arm and leg and no longer holds the charmness from Japanese-run hotels. Go figure.Same service but smaller hotel rooms. Not much outlets for your phones and PCs. They give perks like free parking if you booked online. Their breakfast is flooded with tourists but pretty decent. I wish the room was a bit bigger. Coming from other country the size kind of affects the ability to relax.Pretty reasonable if shopped ahead of time and good service. I might stay again.

Our tour company booked rooms here for our 2 night stay in Tokyo. Although the room was relatively small the view of the city made up for it, Service was outstanding. When we requested a 3 prong outlet for our computer it was delivered within minutes.

I arrived several hours early, due to flight time. I was visibly shattered.Staff were unable to allocate a room earlier, and offered me nothing. I asked if they had a gym so I could at least shower, and was told yes. And that I could pay for that little luxury!!I ended up having my 1400-1700Meeting before I was able to check in, and only at that point was I told that as my room was on the Exec Level, I could have used the exec lounge to rest while I was waiting, rather than , as I had done , been a nodding dog in the general foyer. I would not recommend the staff, although the room was as it should be.

This gorgeous hotel located conveniently near a train station had such an easy check in process. The rooms are luxurious though still quite small and the view iy d beautiful. Breakfast is not included but the room service we ordered for dinner was delicious beautifully presented and fairly priced. Highly recommend this hotel.

Dirty carpetSuffocating room - it's smoking room, but other hotel with smoking rooms at cheaper price did far better job at removing the cigarette odorAnd the worst was terrible staff. I could get much better attitude at hotels 1/3 the price (also in Japan) and in case you think I didn't know what it's like in luxurious hotels, I'd been to those that were 3-4x GNTD's price. GNTD should learn from Chinzanso or Ritz Carlton Osaka
user_name:
Van N
Ho Chi Minh city

review_body: I spent 7 nights while at a conference at Big Sight. The hotel could hardly be faulted. Service very good, food good, location excellent for attending a conference at the conference centre. Caught the rail back and forth. Hilton is on the other side of the station so convenient if other delegates located there. 30 Floor could do with a larger bar area.

Great hotel. We had a room with 4 beds and there was plenty of room for our luggage and kids to spread out. Great amenities plus free phone to use for our visit. Staff very friendly and helpful. It was a good location and loved the free shuttle bus to Disney! You can also get train there too easily enough. It's also close to 2 different malls so lots of food and shopping options. Would definitely recommend this hotel!

very happy with the service and professionalism shown ,stayed for 2 nights , as had to attend the exibition in big site tokyo , hotel is very close by the monorail..rooms are big , decent , pillows could be better ... staff very polite and professional .. total opposite of what’s across them the hilton odaiba .. worst experience ever .. keep up the good job guys .

I compare my experience in this hotel to my experience in Moscow 2013, Izmailovo Best Western hotel. This hotel is huge... I think, in more ways than one, too big for its size. One of the biggest drawbacks is the lack of "any" facilities in the hotel you can use for meetings. You're either at a restaurant, or paying for a meeting room. You can't receive anyone in the lounge. There's places to sit (stone benches) but nothing that isn't used by the constant flow of checking in or checking out people. So, if you want to do anything casual, there's a clean but really expensive coffee shop just outside the door, with a very limited selection on the menu, and there's an even more limited one about 50m away which... isn't clean (a rarity for Tokyo). Daiba is not well served by airport shuttles. The first one starts at 0700 at the Hilton, so if your flight is too early your only real choice is to take a taxi or leave the night before. It's really close to Haneda but landing or departing Haneda is more of a hit and miss when you book your ticket. The reception area is huge but service is impossibly Japanese. I use the word "impossibly" because the staff's english is quite poor and while they do try to be helpful, a simple statement like "I would like to separate my room expenses from the miscellaneous" isn't something a typical japanese client would request, so they're not well equipped to answer. They will, by default, invoice you the rack rate for their services so it's definitely beneficial to read the invoices carefully and revise them with the staff before you hand over your credit card. Apart from that, the rooms are quite clean, and housekeeping is, again, not what you'd expect from chain hotels like Marriott or Starwood. A typical housekeeper does not clean the tables, what they will do is wipe them assuming you take out the plates yourself. It is important to differentiate this. On the other hand, breakfast is never an option and meal vouchers to have to be bought separately (a costly mistake we were only told about on checkout), and the sheer influx of the number of people at the food areas does overwhelm the staff. The food selection is quite good, but there was a noticeable lack of some dairy products or other western staples (again, we attribute that to the origins of the hotel) Their menu selection for room service is quite good, and the food is more than reasonable quality. Interestingly enough, we felt that the huge portions (not typical for a Japan hotel) were much better fitted in the room service than they were in the hotel restaurants. The top floor one was too expensive (at 18,000 yen a person) so we avoided that one altogether. What else is there to say ? The Nikko is a very Japanese restaurant, run with the typical efficiency of any Japanese establishment. The staff is nice but not very responsive. We enjoyed the rooms but the overall experience, in my opinion was subpar.

We stayed here for 11 nights. Such courteous and helpful staff. Check in and out we're quick and efficient. We used their Disney and airport shuttles. Several malls nearby so always easy to find food and shopping. Train station right outside for easy access everywhere! Everything was clean, bathroom a bit dated bit was fine. We would stay again.

We stayed in the rainbow bridge view twin room on the executive floor. We had good time in the executive lounge. This hotel is connected to Daiba station and have air port bus to Haneda and Narita. The view was beatiful day and night. Their services were excellent. I love breakfast on the grill on 30th. I'll highly recomend this hotel.

What a beautiful place to stay. We had a room on the 26th floor with views that were on postcards. Lots of restaurants, shopping and attractions nearby. Excellent breakfast buffet. Comfortable bed and large bathroom with everything you need. Staff also helpful when you have questions about getting around.

This is my second time to stay this hotel. It’s closed to several malls and tourist spots. However, there is weird smell. I can tell what it is. Excepted this, it is almost great. ゆりかもめ 近く、ショッピングセンターもすぐそばですこく便利だった。立地も良く素晴らしいホテルだと思います。

....splendidly located ( on Odaiba island in the middle of Tokyo Bay) luxury hotel serving both business and leisure travelers. Distinguished lobby and public areas. Well above average amenities provided such complimentary cell phones with toll free (i,e, VOIP internet protocol) calling to the USA. And don't forget about the electrically heated toilet seats. A real plus during those chilly winter months ! Recommended.

The check in is super long q and slow on a Monday... Room carpet is full of stains and furnitures are old... View from room is the only good thing I feel. Have not visited the area and have not try the hotel food yet.

The room condition is good, but room service is just a little bit lower than expected (I bring my own blanket, in other hotels I've stayed room service will folde it & place on the bed, but not here). The hotel is close to beautiful site-seeings & shopping malls (I preferred Diversity than Aquacity). The metro station is also nearby, so we can easily go to Shibuya or other shopping areas.
user_name:
HungAn-NGUYEN
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: Very nice hotel with a lot of luxury details such as chandeliers, paintings, carpets. A very nice surprise when you get to the room, a mobile smartphone that you can use during your stay. You can even make phonecalls to same specific destinations. 4 different breakfast rooms. I 've tried 2 and I don't think that they were that special. Excellent location.

Our stay here was kind of mixed. The location is ok right on a train station but it's not in central Tokyo. The two most disappointing aspects were the room and food. Our room was very tired, everything was old and worn. The first night we had room service which was very sub pat, almost inedible. However, the concierge was really good and the price was ok for the room.

The Grand Nikko Daiba hotel is located right next to the Daiba monorail station so you can access the Koto area easily especially to Tokyo Big Sight for a trade show. It is also right next to the Odaiba shopping center and the nice bay side park. It is very popular with Disney visitors as the hotel has free shuttle there which only takes 30 minutes. The rooms are all a bit dated but fine.

Tokyo's new interesting zone Odaiba with a lot to experience (onsen, beach, shopping malls..). We stayed for 2 nights in Grand Nikko! Actually we stayed in 2 hotels in Tokyo during our 6-night-stay for the convenience of being close to where we needed to go and to get to know the large city a bit better. Grand Nikko is a relatively new hotel with large rooms, very good service and great view from guestrooms to sea and city. We recommend you to take the automated Yurikamome-train over Rainbow bridge when coming to hotel! It stops right next to and offers magnificient sightseeing.There's a free shuttle from hotel to both Tokyo Disney sites. We recommend to book seat in advance on hotel's website. Also, there is a direct bus that takes (is payable) you to Shinkansen train station if you want to continue your trip from Tokyo to Kyoto as we did.

Excellent customer service and baggage service. Truly a professional hotel, however one thing that really brought the rating down is the discrimination against tattoos which was really disappoing because it's so hot and we wanted to go into the pool. Just because someone has tattoos doesnt mean they should be automatically classed as someone looking to cause trouble. The rooms are lovely, executive lounge access and restuarant on the 30th floor. Once again after paying $800 a night for an executive suite it made me really upset that I couldn't go swimming just because I have art on my skin. Again, a good hotel but the discrimination was really disappointing.

This was the hotel our tour company Go Ahead Tours booked. Beautiful hotel, wonderful, friendly and knowledgeable staff and concierge service. Be sure to walk the neighborhood if you stay here. Multiple shopping malls going both directions, entertainment options, restaurants and a subway stop just steps from the front door. Breakfast came with our stay and it was excellent offering both Japanese and Western options. My husband used the laundry service and it was same day. We enjoyed nightcaps on the top floor for city views.

The rooms are much more spacious than many hotel rooms in Tokyo. The view is great! Love the handy provided!! Just next to Daiba station of the Yurikamome Line. Shopping malls are within walking distance.

If you want to visit Tokyo, but not to be in the midst of the craziness, Daiba area is the area to go. Nice stores and services near by. The hotel Grand Nikko is very comfortable and the service is excellent. The view of the city is wonderful.

Close to a large mall, next to a small park with a miniature Statue of Liberty, this hotel is luxurious with a fantastic breakfast. Very comfortable rooms, many overlooking the city and inlet. Excellent staff.

I love this hotel. I stayed in this hotel 2 years ago and I chose this hotel again.It was in a good location right next to the station and had some good shopping malls nearby.The room was comfortable and amenities were really good.

A good and accessible hotel, except for the long queue for check-in as they conduct check-in at 4:00pm for everybody. Breakfast seems popular as you will need to queue at around 9am. Would I go back? Sure.

My family and I were so impressed with this AMAZING 5 star hotel!! Rooms were immaculate with gorgeous views and all of the hotel staff members were extremely helpful, polite and friendly!! The Grand Nikko Tokyo Daiba is definitely one of the best hotels we’ve ever stayed at and we will absolutely stay here again!! :-)

Grand Nikko Hotel was a good place to stay in to spend a four day holiday in Tokyo. The Daiba train station was right beside the hotel and made it convenient for us to go to all the places we wanted to visit and the eateries with the food we had planned to try.My sister and I had single beds in a spacious room, with a bathroom equipped with a tub for soaking our tired bodies at the end of long walks during the day. Toilet amenities were avqilable, includng bath salt and hair brushes. Towels were changed daily and rooms were always cleaned. Newspapers were provided every day. We were given breakfast coupons for three days,with 3 choices that included a garden dining buffet, a set Japanese breakfast and a sushi breakfast. Not being fans of the last two, we opted for the buffet, were happy on day one but dissapointed that exactly the same dishes were served on all three days we stayed.On our last morning, when we decided to do last minute shopping, we found out the mall across opened at 11. But next to the hotel was a small boutique where we bought affordable chocolates, ramen packets, and face masks. A plus factor for the hotel is its affordable airport limousine service, which you reserve,pay for on the day of departure, and picks you up right outside the hotel.I'd defintely recommend this hotel to friends who plan to visit Tokyo.

Pros:Large roomBeautiful view of the bridge and Tokyo tower if you choose the optionNice front desk staff, easy to check inBus from Narita stop right in front of the hotelClose to shopping centers if you like to shop. Mostly low end shop and fast food.See pictures for train that goes to this hotel. Cons:Very far to the city or things to do in Tokyo. Many transfer from different metro line — mean wasting time to have transportationVery expensive food in the hotel, and food does not taste all that goodMy room was smelly, like old stale smellI don’t think staff speak English all that well.Probably not good for kids since there are no swimming pool and long walk to go from one place to another. I travel with my 7 and 9 years old this time.Too expensive for what it has to offer. I have chosen to come back to another hotel at my second trip to Tokyo.

The hotel lobby is elegant and the room is great for a family of four. We got 4 single beds and the luggage fits under the bed so we have ample room to move around. They provide you with water, toothbrush, comb, shaver with shaving cream, hair ties and most importantly, a cellphone you can use for free with data. There’s a currency exchange machine downstairs and a 24 hour store nearby. It is also close to the Daiba station and aqua city where you can take a river cruise to 3 locations. They do have a shuttle that will take you to Disney but we opted out since the next bus doesn’t leave until 11:30 am or something so make sure you make your reservations fast. We took a cab from Disney to the hotel and we paid like $52 dollars. We also took the train to Disney and the hotel provided us a map. Unfortunately, the map is not accurate- their map shows to go straight down the teleport station but in reality you have to do a lot of turns and walking before you reach the station. There is also a rainbow bus that stops at the hotel and will take you to shinagawa. Overall, the service is great and I would definitely stay here again

Spent 3 nights here, recommended by my travel agent, stunning lobby and very friendly staff!! Very close to station, restaurants etc. The room was a triple deluxe and plenty of room, well stocked with anything you could think of. I will be returning and recommend to my friends!!

Just few step to the station, near shopping centre and big gundam. So many cafe in front of the hotel, you can enjoy coffee or brunch.the room is not too bad. Service ok, not too good but happy maybe come back

Family of four had a connected room with beautiful view and probably one of the biggest hotel rooms in Tokyo.The rooms are very classy and very clean. They also provided free smart phone for use while you are in Tokyo.We love the location that is connected to Daiba station on yurikamome line. The hotel has mix groups of local people and foreigners but not tour bus. The night view is beautiful, but all the sights are very touristy which I do not enjoy. but it is close to to shimdome, shimbashi and few stops to Ginza.

I stayed here from June 20-23, 2018 and parked my car at their car park. However, nobody informed me about the parking procedure. I asked the reception and someone told me that I need to pay JPD2000 for the 1st night and then I will get a receipt to redeem the free parking ticket for the rest nights. So I paid the JPD2000 when I left the car park on June 21, 2018, but no receipt printed out for the transaction automatically from the machine. I asked the staff again on the morning of the next day (June 22, 2018), she said that I need to present the receipt to get the free parking, although I told her that there is no receipt printed from machine (They said that I SHOULD have the said receipt). Finally they gave me the free parking ticket. But I don't feel good, because it is not my fault.I left this hotel on June 23, 2018 morning. Finally, I found a button (in Japanese-> 領収証/ 領収書) for printing the receipt on the machine. (But their staff never told me to press the button during my stay)I would like to suggest - If you would like to park your car here, you should "press the receipt printing button" after you paid the bill. If you do not press the button, you cannot get your receipt.It would be better if they give their guest an instruction (in English, black and white) about the parking procedure and offer.

This hotel is located in daiba area, just a few minutes walk from the metro station. The liberty statue, shopping Center and beach is in walking distance from the hotel. At night you can Enjoy the beutfull view of the rainbow bridge outside the hotel. The room is big compare to other hotel. WE enjoy our stay in this hotel.

Stayed here for a business trip in March. Fabulous location as it is close to everything given that train stations are just a short walk. But there are lots of restaurants and shopping within walking distance so no need to leave the area unless you are looking for a specific tourist spot. Room was spacious and clean. Internet was good. The mobile phone they provided for local use was invaluable! Staff were always courteous and willing to help, but the hotel could always use a few more staff who could speak better English - but that's just nit-picking. The breakfast buffet was included in my stay and it was wonderful! Just what a business traveler needs to start his day off right. This hotel is perfect for both the business traveler working within the area (as I was) or for families visiting Tokyo area. I have no problem recommending this hotel to others as this would be my first choice of accommodations for the next time I have to visit Tokyo area.

Grand Nikko is located at the great location and is a classic Japanese hotel. Although it is maintained well, you may feel the 'classic-ness' in the room... View of Tokyo Bay is wonderful and a Metro station is inside of the hotel so it is easy to get to. The service was great - I asked the staff to bring extra bath salt and wine glasses and they were so responsive to the requests.

Very nice (but small) executive rooms at the 25th floor incl. Nespresso coffeemachine, Shiseido-ameneties, bathroom a bit outdated, but very clean. TV is offering one, max two (english-speaking) US-channels, but no European channel. Aircondition and ambience light pretty good and state of the art. Minibar offers some complimentary drinks which is nice.Bar and breakfast at the 30th floor - really wonderful as you oversee the water and the enormous skyline of Tokyo. You should spend some time there! Only issue is the staff - waiting for 10+ minutes to order or to get the receipt. Maybe a bit too long.Executive lounge, however, is at the 2nd floor - so you always have a "long ride" of about 23+ floors. View is here close to nothing. Seperate reception desk for guests and lounge is really stylish and cool. Some issues here: copies for some pages takes you 15 minutes and staff try to charge you. Same for one guest for 30 minutes without a drink/tea - they asked for about 40 USD! Kind of strange in a 5-star hotel. Location is good, entertainment is around and not that far to vibrent areas of Tokyo.Would recommend again, but not highest score.

This is a good quality hotel next to a train station giving good access to the city centre. The breakfast was good the only problem being that we had to queue for up to 20 minutes to get in. The staff were very helpful and pleasant

Stayed here one night before flight back to UK, everything you would expect of a 5 star hotel, great area close to rainbow bridge and they have a top floor bar with fantastic views of the bridge and lights at night, also Aqua city not far away and the statue of Liberty, as all Japan very safe to walk about at night so take advantage of the area.room was spacious with large comfy bed and silky sheets, good size bathroom with large shower, drinks and eats very pricey here but local restaurants close by, would recommend this hotel.

This is an aging luxirious hotel with an extremely nice location in Odaiba. The room service pizza was really good. Most of the staff were helpful and nice (I’ll get back to why I said “most” in the things I didn’t like section). The hotel also has cheap limousine buses to both Haneda and Narita airports as well as Shinagawa Station. There were lots of shopping and dining options nearby (also Halal food for muslims). The rooms are equipped with free Handy Smartphones that work as MiFis and as guides through Tokyo and you can also make local and intentional calls from them free of charge!!!!!! There is also a 24 hour convenience store just outside which also sells Pokemon and Dinsey character plushies (in case you missed out on them in Pokemon Centers and Disneyland/Disneysea).I can’t believe I’m writing a negative feeback about customer service in JAPAN!!!!! It’s a custom that once or twice during any of my stays, I order from either Pizza Hut or Domino’s Pizza. One evening I reached the bell desk clerk (Wasima I believe) and asked him if he could help us order from Pizza Hut since I don’t speak Japanese, I’m going to give him the benefit of the doubt and say he was confused even though he was acting and expressing that I was an inconvenience (at least he tried to help). He even took my phone and started using it to contact the restaurant thinking it was the hotel’s free Handy Smartphone. Now the worst part is that after further confusion he spoke to another Bell Desk Clerk whose name was Nishio (I made sure I got her name right from the Duty Manager who didn’t seem that bothered when I complained to him) and she rudely raised her voice saying “SORRY, WE CANNOT HELP YOU CALL PIZZA HUT”, really, couldn’t you be nicer about it? I’m not asking you to get out of your way and do me a favor I just asked if you could assist me as a customer. I stayed in many hotels around Japan from three star business hotels in Shinjuku to the luxurious Hilton Tokyo Daiba which is adjacent to the Grand Nikko Daiba (it was managed by the same company during my stay prior to being a Hilton establishment) to the Crowne Plaza in rural far east Hokkaido (Kushiro) and all the employees in those hotels tried their best to help with this trivial request. Why not this one? Incompetence much?

We have decided to book this hotel based on the pics and the fact that it was in Daiba for the last leg of our trip.We knew we're going to be tired and needed few days of luxury to rest and enjoy our holiday.The entrance was very impressive and staff greeted us well but that's where it stopped... They put us in a room in level 19 which had nice views and all that till I went to the bathroom and omg, pink mould was growing everywhere the bathroom was dirtier than public toilet. Don't get me started on the filthy carpets which was pure disgusting...I have called and complained and they have sent someone to look at it. Immediately they realised it's really bad and they've moved us. We went to a bigger room but not that nice view as we had Hilton blocking the view.The bathroom was still dirty and mould in the shower but better than the other one.Next morning we went for breakfast and had to wait 20 min to get in. Food was S&#%. Everything was stone cold and by that time we just had enough of this crap. We went and had a talk with the manager who immediately sent us to another restaurant.We thought well that's great... BUT NOHaven't even settled a bit they've called us that we need to change your room AGAIN as they had renovations and it's going to be loud... Are you Kidding me?????I just had enough of this s%#& and wanted to go for a swim and realise oh I have to pay for swimming pool Next day the cleaners found someone else's dirty old sucks from underneath the bed and left it with our luggage They have realised they've mucked us around so much and gave us a bit of refund but that didn't take the stress away and already put a dampener on my holiday. My goodness with the money we've spent we expected a great service but I'm telling you this was the worst of our trip. This is not a luxury hotel, it's dated and old and VERY dirty... Avoid Avoid Avoid

The hotel is located in Odaiba, a bit far away from the center (but with metro connections not too far). The rooms are modern, with a lot of amenities and a nice bathroom. The decoration is so-so. Nothing particularly unpleasant, nothing particularly nice. The hotel is quite big, with a rather unpersonal touch. The main bad point is the very low quality of the service, a rather unusual feature in Japan where the quality is normally pretty high. Some members of the staff cannot care less. Even the front desk comes sometimes with absurd requirements. To give an exemple, on the first night, friends were asked to book a slot for... breakfast and were told that the only slot available was 7am (!). The night after, when booking via room service, I asked to replace two items of the breakfast (sausages and potatoes) by just an extra toast - not exactly an extravagant or costly request - and got a ‘not possible’ answer.Not serious hotel for an hotel in this category. There are plenty of better alternatives.

The Grand Nikko hotel in Daiba gives you the "isolation" you may need from the bustling city but at the same time offers all the shopping and dining opportunities within walking distance. The hotel offers a buffet, sit down dining and specialty restaurants. The rooms are very well appointed and service is excellent. Taking the train or cab takes a little more time during rush hour but you get some spectacular views of the city at night. A great option.

We loved this hotel. It exceeded our expectations. It is right by a train station, had amazing views of the rainbow bridge and the Tokyo skyline, close to museums, shops and restaurants. The only downside is that it was a bit out of town but there was a train station right outside and it was actually nice to come back to after a day of sightseeing in the centre.

駅からすぐ近く、アクアシティ、ダイバーシティの両方にも近く、大変便利です。残念な点は、チェックインの際に中国人の団体客がロビーでうるさかったことと、夜には30階のバーを利用しましたが、窓枠が高く、向きによってはレインボーブリッジも見えず残念な感じでした。酔っ払った客がうるさくて、せっかくの雰囲気も台無し。部屋は接客には文句はありません。次はヒルトンにしようかな。The hotel is near station. 5 minutes walk takes you to shopping centers, Aquacity and DiverCity. The room and the service were good but not surprising.

Super modern large hotel , that's just been refurbished, its out of town in the new developments in Tokyo Bay , but there are attractions near by.major problems on catering at breakfast for the non Japanese restaurant, waits (queuing)of 20/30 minutes typical for the days I was there, despite early starts !!!Rooms were delightful and pleasantly large for Japan.

Checking in as part of a tour we were confronted by a long queue - quite orderly but took around 40 minutes. Room was large, immaculate and most comfortable with a good view. Asked concierge where to eat - delightful man and so helpful - took us outside and pointed the way to Aqua City - 10 minute walk - huge shopping complex with every type of restaurant - all very reasonably priced. Late night Coffee shop on the way back a bonus. Included Breakfast excellent. Surprisingly excellent start as part of a tour of Japan.

Been here for 3 nights, Grand Nikko Tokyo Daiba is in a very good location with 24 hours big convenience store on its own. Rooms come in different size, so we have to be careful when booking. It's very convenience to go anywhere from the hotel as there is a skywalk connected from the hotel to train station and several shopping mall. Room price is quite reasonable if you book it in advance. In overall, I think this hotel is not bad.

Our room was on the regular floor and provided a stylish and relaxing space. We could a see the bay from our hotel as well as the sun in the morning and the lights at night.2 dining areas: main floor (opens at 7am) and the lower level (opens at 6:30am) lower level you set in chairs if you arrive before opening.A bakery and pastry shop, Chinese restaurant, fitness club, several dining areas and more.The plus for you are the timely buses to the airport.A hotel I would gladly return to.

The hotel was big and beautiful, the room was clean and very comfortable bed and bathroom, nice and polite staff, close to malls such as Aquacity, Divercity, Venus port, you can find lots of restaurants there

I am not sure with the other comments by saying the hotel has no character because the hotel is not dab smack in the middle of the town with the busyness of Tokyo or just because it looked luxury. That's just a matter of taste. You want character? stay in Ryokan. You want craziness in Tokyo, lots of hotel in Tokyo are like that, heck you can get the tiny room while you are at it. This hotel are not for that, which I love.Personally I found the hotel is very good. close to malls such as Aquacity, Divercity, venus port etc. Food courts are abundant in these malls. They are all walking distance. Decent meal ranging from 600yen. If it's still too expensive you can always get food from the Family mart 24hrs just beside the hotel. If that's still too expensive.... why are you here holidaying in Japan?Stations were close with daiba station and tokyo teleport and all within pleasant walking distance with the park and flowers around (we came at the end of March). Bus stop was just beside the hotel as well if you want to ride one. The place is very connected. If you need to do some laundry and want to save some coin, a laundromat is only 10 minutes away by bus (白クマコインランドリ).The hotel also has free scheduled shuttle bus if you don't want to walk around Daiba.Service was very good, the room was big compared to the average hotel I've been in Tokyo. Free loan Mobile phone was provided in the room inclusive of calls and data, which really helps to navigate around Tokyo. Strolling in the afternoon passing the miniature liberty statue looking at the rainbow bridge among the blooming sakura... it was just perfect. All this without the craziness and bustling of Central Tokyo? Anytime! Only took you half an hour from odaiba to get to those anyway.And... if you want to go to Disney, this hotel is a partner hotel, so there is a free scheduled bus from the hotel and back. Very useful after a long day, all tired from too much fun that you can just go to the dedicated stop and straight back at the hotel.Definitely will go back here again for my next Tokyo trip.

I chose this hotel as I needed somewhere to stay for my final night in Japan and it was close to Haneda Airport and a reasonable price compared to the city hotels.The hotel was nice enough and the room was very comfortable, nice bed and bathroom and great views over the harbour. However, both the hotel and the area were all a bit ‘nouveau riche’ and characterless for me. The hotel had a large opulent lobby, everything was a bit over the top and soulless and it seemed to cater for your groups on shopping / packaged type holidays. The area was too far from Tokyo for my liking (but great for Haneda) and mostly surrounded by malls and new man made activities, which probably suits families with kids more. I much prefer the mix of old / new and local craziness of central Tokyo.

This is my first visit in Japan. I chose this hotel just because they provide bus service to Disney Land Tokyo (that i missed the schedule).The Location was great. In front of Daiba station in Yurikamome Line. If you have JR Pass you cant use it in Yurikamome Line so you need to have Pasmo or Suica Card. Hotel is far away from Tokyo Center and hard to find cheap restaurant near. So this hotel is not for backpacker.You can get anything near such as : Locker, Convenience store, mall, attraction, park, and also limousine bus from or to airport.I Love how they treat the guest. Very kind and polite staff, they even provide device that we can use free during our stay and you can make international call for free. But..i don't like the breakfast. almost same every day and nothing special on it.

This hotel is extremely popular with tour groups and I can understand why. Compared with most hotels in Tokyo rooms are very comfortable and spacious and good value for money. Tour groups tend to come and go in buses. But as independent travellers staying here 4 nights we had to use the yurikamome line to even begin to get anywhere. This line is comparatively expensive and added half an hour to every journey. The area around the hotel is all malls and places to interest young families, rather than travellers. We found it lacking character and it could have been anywhere in the world.The best part of the hotel was the Japanese breakfast, which was quiet, calm and delicious but the same every day, the spacious and well equipped bathroom and cleanliness. Staff were helpful but impersonal which one would expect in such a big hotel. The worst part was the inefficient queueing at the buffet breakfast venues especially early in the morning when there could be as many as 50 queued before the room opened at 6.30. The hotel insists in seating everyone which is incredibly slow. The buffet itself could not keep up with demand and dishes needed replacing or refilling. The pastries were nice but fruit limited.We were in Tokyo for a wedding and the hotel gave us a comfortable space to get ready but I would recommend tourists find something elsewhere ideally on the yamamote line.

We spent three nights at this hotel on our first visit to Tokyo. Pleasantly surprised with its location right near Daiba station and shopping malls with many dining choices. We were at the start of a group tour at cherry blossom time. Our room faced the bay at the front of the hotel on Level 16 with a great view of the Statue of Liberty! We didn’t expect to see her!Hotel staff were very pleasant and professional. Elevators are the quietest we have ever experienced. Housekeeping was exceptional with toiletries continuously replaced and fluffy towels with a great shower.In our room was a smart phone for use during our stay, a first for us in our many hotel stays. Room was not large, but adequate for us as we spent most days outside the hotel sightseeing.

LikesThe location, the view of the rainbow bridge and surrounding area, all the fine details about the room and service. The complimentary free talk & data phone is a life saver! I preordered phone SIM cards from Japan Wireless and they don't work or not work at all! Love how your housekeeping staff will refill the water kettle, toiletry items (high quality ones too), and provide the complimentary water bottles every day. The privacy and do not disturb lights make sense instead of those always falling door hangers. The mouth rinsing cups in the bathroom having the lid at the bottom to catch dripping water make a lot of sense. My wife would appreciate the "keep warm" the toilet seat function. The design of the blinds to have the transparent one having magnet to connect, and the light shading ones cross over each other to prevent light coming in are well noted. Size of the room is also great. I'm glad I chose to stay at this hotel as I double-booked one in Akihabara close in town that is tiny and won't even fit our luggage. Also love the Haneda Airport limousine bus service as otherwise we won't be able to haul our luggages around trains. The 24-hr Quality Convenience Store next to the hotel is also wonderful and convenient. The elevators are extremely quiet which is amazing. I have lived in Hong Kong for many years and have not been in such a quiet elevator! Also love the courier service to provide boxes for us to purchase and help with mailing! The electric charger having 3 outlet ports and 2 USB ports is also a must have! The safe's size is also good that we can put in a laptop computer.DislikesBefore the trip, I tried to clarify what phone/pocket WiFi is provided for each room. I wish the staff would have told me more details as I did not realize to my pleasant surprise that it's a free handy smartphone that provides complimentary data and talk even free calls to HK and the USA! It even can have personal hotspot for my son to connect his phone for data as the Japan Wireless SIM card doesn't work on my personal pocket WiFi.I also had problem during check-in, took almost an hour. I had a booking for 6 nights and I added one more night before the trip. It must have been the default on booking.com that when I went back and forth looking at different options, the 1-night booking happened to only include 1 guest instead of 2 as in my first booking. So the staff "argued" with me (very politely) and spent the time calling booking.com to check it for me. As it turns out, I had to cancel the booking using my phone on booking.com and added another night there to finally make it work. So that did waste almost an hour of my precious travel time in Tokyo.
user_name:
Clement W
Maple Grove, Minnesota, United States

review_body: A fantastically beautiful view from the 18th floor. The room is big and has all modern conveniences. Very clean( like in most Japanese hotels.) The location is very close to numerous malls,shopping centers and various restaurants and cafes.The staff is very friendly and helpful.(fortunately, most of them speak and understand English!)

This hotel is located in Odaiba, thus away from the hustle and bustle of the city. Pros:1) Very simple to get to from the airport by Limosine Bus. Inform the bus ticket counter the name of hotel, and the bus will drop you directly at the front door.2) Very big rooms for the price I paid. The beds are lovely and the most powerful shower I have ever encountered. 3) The room cleaning crew are absolutedly wonderful in the way they work and, are very polite4) The hotel is connected to the Daiba train station, and 15mins walk away to Tokyo Teleport train station. This is very convenient5) Room service. I ordered my meal for two, and the food arrived in less than 15 mins. Amazing.6) Located next to Aqua City Mall. Many wonderful restaurants to eat there, as well a simple food court. Very convenient.7) On the way to Daiba train station, there is a 24hr convenience store. Also very convenient.Cons:1) Same food over 7 days for breakfast. Garden Dining and Le Bouquet serve exactly the same food/ buffet as each other. The Japanese restaurant offers a set meal but it also the same food everyday2) Peak periods of 7.15am to 7.45am, expect to wait up to 30 mins for a table during breakfast3) Shampoo, body soap and conditioner. Quality could be improved4) If you happened to stay on the same floor with groups and they have young children, prepare to be woken up very early with kids/ adults talking/ running down the corridor as the hotel offers free bus shuttle to Disneyland at 7am, 8.30am and 10am. I don't fault the hotel for the noise made.

The hotel has a great view and and is massive dimensions...the room is quite old need an upgrade.... Queue at reception just three peoples at the front desk and other hundred running up and down nobody at the entrance to greetings the customers Most of the amenities maybe all .... Required an extra payment..... The only think complementary was a couple a small water bottles and few cheap tea bags ..... Personally I think could be more clean and detailed for the price it's not a luxury accommodation .

I have attended a global conference with more than 1000 delegates, everything was clean. But the front desk did not make the impression that they wanted to help me. I arrived early and was not offered a place to change after an overnight flight. An invoice could not be modified, and changing an address took 30 mins. Would not recommend to stay without the conference. Colleagues of mine switched after the event.

We booked 5 nights at this hotel and very much enjoyed this premises’ services. You can find almost everything nearby this hotel: 2 big shopping malls: the waterfront area, 01 minute to Daiba station, 24/7 convenient store right on the side door, free shuttle bus to Tokyo Disneyland (03 time slots in the morning), travel time is approximately 20 minutesMinus point: - breakfast is expensive, not worth the money value- subway tickets is not cheap and confused train/subway system

After checking out of the Grand Nikko Tokyo Daiba on 3/24/18, my sick 8 year-old daughter and I were sitting in the lobby. She was drinking apple juice and eating a musubi and left the small carton on the table. About an hour in, while she was drinking another apple juice, a very rude, young bellman, kinda tall with face acne, proceeded to scold us for eating and drinking in the lobby, saying that eating and drinking there was not allowed and the couch tables were for "luggage only"and not for drinks. Huh? This despite the fact that many staff had passed us in the hour before and not one said anything at all. He never bothered to ask about my daughter, how was our stay, etc. I asked if there was a place we could eat and drink while waiting for our limousine bus. He said to leave the hotel. I also noticed after I apologized that other guests were drinking or eating. No one said anything to them and that really upset me...to the point that this is the first time I am writing a review. My best guess...racism. I look Chinese even though I am Japanese American. I will never stay at this hotel again and will tell my family, friends and colleagues to stay away, too. It's obvious the Grand Nikko has poorly trained staff and doesn't genuinely care for the safety or health of its younger guests. One bad experience is all it takes...goodbye and good riddance to the Grand Nikko.

Nice hotel but remote, nice dinning experience but not easy, nice service but less humanity. Everything here are well presented and everyone seems polite and well trained, but its a bit lack of humanity inside. This place is serious, not for people who is looking for resort type accommodation~

The hotel was great! Big rooms, great view, great location, good service . We stayed on the executive rooms on the 25th floor, so we could go to any of the restaurants for brekafast. Additional benefit like gym access & afternoon drinks were also a plus. Breafast on the 30th floor was awesome. Eggs with salmon & caviar was always welcome. But there's only small thing. The garden dining restaurant seemed lack of staff & charm. First time we ate there, we could see tables filled of dirty plates with no one around to clean them up, meals were unattended as well, so everything was overcooked. They did fix it on the second day we went there, yet a lot room for improvement for the garden dining experience.

This hotel was amazing! It looks like a 5 star all around! It is conveniently located right off the subway! But the best thing about this hotel is they GIVE YOU A CELL PHONE during your stay! Coming from overseas my cell phone doesn't work but they give you a local cell phone equipped with everything! GPS, Google (it's an android phone) and everything any cell phone does! Once you're done with the cell phone you simply wipe the date clean and leave in room! I have just never been to a hotel that offers this type of service (and I've been to over 10 countries)! Also the view from the hotel is absolutely gorgeous and the morning buffet was excellent. The room was clean, the bathroom was great the only thing is the pillows were way too soft for me...I had to stack 3 but that's only because I like firm pillows! When I'm back in Tokyo I'm definitely staying here words cannot say enough!

My husband and I stayed a few nights at the Grand Nikko Hotel, and had the pleasure of dining at the hotel's restaurant on the 30th floor, with fantastic views over the city of Tokyo. The tasting menu with champagne was wonderful from start to end, with attentive service, a sophisticated ambience and tasteful decor. Each course was presented akin with a work of art, and composed of delicious flavours and textures. A real treat, and somewhere we'd love to visit next time we are in Tokyo.

This hotel is excellent in three stages: location, amenties and space. location: it is strategically located on Daiba station, giving you the pleasure of evading the rush hours in Tokyo both in morning and evenings. Specially, if you are travelling with children in strollers, space is a scarecity in trains during rush hours. The hotel is strategically located in a way that amenties in both east and west are easily reachable within 30mins either way.The hotel itself provides toiliteries including bath salt from natural spring waters from tokyo, good sized rooms, king size bed that suits every hight and sizes and a variety of breakfast choices to suit both Asian and western guests. We opted for a quiet room, and this hotel certainly delivered. Complementary wifi access is throughout the hotel with excellent reception, and a free handphone ready for you should your mobile not have the necessary 4g technology to work in Japan.The staff are quite accomodating, and even if there are staff that speak basic English, they do the extra mile to try to understand you, which is by far much better than a lot of places I have stayed in Tokyo so far.They are able to store your luggage both at check in and check out, and many large sized elevators ready to take you, your strollers and luggage up to any floor. There are weelchair access available from the station all the way to the lobby, and the station is 3 min away from the lobby and clearly marked. There is a 24 hour convenient store if you require anything and is 2 min away from the lobby.Simply perfect, will be staying again on my next visit.

Big room for Japan standard, comfy bed, malls just across the street, train station just a few minutes walk, shuttle to Disney Land and Disney Sea is a big plus. Helpful and effective check in and check out. We send our luggage from our Hotel in Osaka to Grand Nikko, and they kept it neatly. Generous bath room amenities, I have nothing to complain, If your looking for a Hotel that far from the usual Ginza hustle, this is the one.

i used to stay in downtown Tokyo, but for the convenience to Tokyo Disney, I chose this hotel during Chinese New Year holiday with my family. It turned out to be a great choice. The hotel has such advantages as location (shopping, sightseeing, transportation), English speaking, nice food, clean beds and shuttle bus to Disney and Haneda/Narita Airports.

We stayed here at the end of our visit to Tokyo as it is near the Haneda airport. It is very big and very busy. We did not use any of the leisure type facilities.By Tokyo standards the room was big, though a little bit dated things worked well.Well done to the hotel who allowed us early check in.

The staff at the hotel were extremely helpful. No request was too much for them. They arranged two adjacent rooms for the same price (even though there were none available after we booked the first room) via email correspondence and helped to source a birthday cake at short notice for one of our group. We chose rooms with a view of the Rainbow Bridge and this was well worth the extra cost. The views of the city at night across the bay were excellent. The Rainbow Bridge never lit up in rainbow colours but it was quite colourful. The hotel is well located right next to a metro station (monorail) with good connections to other services. There are three shopping centres only a few minutes walk away. Each has good shopping and dining options. There's a 24 hour convenience store just outside the hotel where you can buy food, drinks, alcohol and has an ATM. Some of my group had room service which they said was very good. Each room has a two outlet USB power point so you don't need a power adaptor if all your electronics charge by USB. The mattress was very comfortable but the pillows were soft. You can order different pillows from house keeping. The bathroom is well appointed with good water pressure in the shower (step up into bath tub). There's a free mobile phone in each room which was very handy. The free wifi was quick and reliable. I only have a couple of minor suggestions for the hotel. 1. There should be more free TV channels available particularly for English speaking guests (no excuse these days with technology). 2. Charging ¥100 for 10 minutes and ¥20-50 per page to print from the hotel guest computer. This should be provided free to guests wanting to check in flights online and print boarding passes. A highly recommended hotel.

Shopping. Restaurants. Amusement Parks. Ferris Wheel. Beaches. Long strolls, and I mean l o n g . Waterway taxis to Sumida and back! Party at Ageha Nightclub 10 minutes away by Taxi, Tokyo's largest EDM Club. Take the shuttle to Disneyland, 20 minutes.Take the Narita airport express from Shinagawa Station. Walk along the beach and eat waffle ice cream sandwiches at Family mart for a buck. Eat and eat and eat and hit up Oedo Monogatari and soak and soak.

We stayed in the hotel for 2 nights (from 31 Jan - 2 Feb 2018). Although very cold in Tokyo for these 2 days, we were so appreciate for the warm services provided. The lobby of the hotel is large and decent, room is clean and tidy. The location is also very convenient as it is located next to Daiba Station.

I stayed here with my family including two young children on a two week holiday to Japan and it was the best hotel that we stayed in during our two week stay. Our triple room wasn't massive, but really very good by Japanese standards and there was enough room for the four of us and our bags without tripping over each other or our bags. There was a nice big bathroom with a bath, and and abundance of high quality toiletries. We were upgraded to an executive room, possibly because I had requested a room with a view of the Rainbow Bridge which was not provided. Instead we were given a room on the Executive Floor, and while we weren't granted the Executive Lounge privileges, the room itself was very nice and it had a complimentary mini bar! We love our booze, and didn't even get through the complimentary mini bar provisions in the three nights we were there (we were of course eating and drinking out however). This was a great hotel - quick, efficient check in, and a very comfortable room. On the first night we realised that I had left my phone on the limousine bus from Narita Airport to Tokyo Terminal Station, and the concierge kindly made calls and helped us make arrangements to retrieve my phone. We used the complimentary shuttle to Disneyland (booked in advance) which was great. The convenience store just downstairs was, well, very convenient. As such, we didn't use any of the restaurants or bars on site. Nor did we seek out the gym, pool etc. In summary, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this hotel. It was excellent value as it felt like a luxury hotel but without the price. I'd stay here again.

This is one of the more reasonably priced hotel in the area. It's a little distance to all the action but still within walking distance. I'm spoilt because I was driving.Everything you would expect from a Japanese hotel: clean, comfortable, etcI apologize for the brief reviews I have been writing these days. Gone are the times where I write super-detailed reviews on a hotel, unless it is exceptionally good or bad. After much travelling, I realized what you do in the day, sights that fascinate you, food that captivate you, locals who are hospitable to you, are so much more important than the bed you sleep on at night. So take in the sights and don't let other unimportant stuff distract you from having a good time.

We recently stayed 2 nights at the Grand Nikko Tokyo Daiba after a skiing trip in Northern Hokkaido. We love Tokyo, and would normally choose to stay closer to the center of the city, but we actually found the location of this hotel to be very convenient as well. And given it costs about half the price of a central Tokyo hotel of a similar standard, it’s well worth considering. It is incredibly easy to get to and from Haneda airport - only 20 mins and 500Y on the Limousine Bus. And if you’re interested in going to Tokyo Disneyland, the hotel has free “Good Neighbor” Shuttle buses there and back. (You need to book both with concierge ahead of time though) The Odaiba area has lots of restaurants and shops to explore, and it is just a short monorail ride across the rainbow bridge to connect with the Yamamote line - which will get you to most other parts of Tokyo. The hotel rooms were very comfortable and had almost a touch of Disney to them. Our only one complaint was that at times we could hear noise from the room adjoining ours. It wasn’t a huge problem, but surprising in a hotel of this quality. That said - our kid were in a room down the hall from us, and didn’t have the same problem, so maybe we were just unlucky.

This hotel is close to Tokyo Disney Land and not in the center of Tokyo. However, it has great shopping malls and tons of restaurants within a five minute walk. We reserved a room on the executive floor where we got VIP treatment! We checked in on the 27th floor where there was also a club room. In the club room, they offered drinks and all kinds of snacks. Alcoholic drinks were available after 5pm. You serve yourself. The view was wonderful from the lounge. Also, we opted to have breakfast included with the room. It is really worth it because it will cost about $35/person if you get it separately. We reserved a table at the restaurant on the 30th floor. First of all, the view was incredible and the food was great. It was all Western food up there. When we had to leave on the limousine bus to the airport, they kept our bags at the front desk then loaded them into the bus for us. The service was wonderful. We will definitely stay there again!

My only problem is that there is NO GYM IN THE HOTEL!! This is crazy for a 5-star luxury hotel. There is a gym in the adjacent shopping plaza, but you have to pay $16 per visit, even if you are a guest at the hotel. Even so the gym doesn’t open until 9am??!! Likewise, there is no pool in the hotel; that is, the pool is located in the adjacent gym, so you have to pay to enter, etc. Even if you did pay, children under 16 are not allowed entry. I am sure the neighbouring Hilton does not suffer from these shortcomings...

We had an executive suite because there were 5 of us (pricey though) with fantastic views on the 26th floor. The room and facilities were 5 star all the way. The location was a lot quieter than downtown Tokyo but close to Disney, shopping and Legoland.

A number of years ago I stayed at what was the former Nikko in Daiba which is now a Hilton hotel located across the street (nearer to Tokyo Bay). So I was curious to experience its new incarnation. Fortunately, January is the time to visit Odaiba if you are at all budget constrained..Odaiba is basically a warm weather seaside resort favored by families and young people. There are numerous malls, restaurants and even a giant Ferris wheel. But even on a winter's day, if the sun is shining the surroundings are pleasant and sufficiently enjoyable in that it is somewhat removed from urban Tokyo while being only a short distance away. The hotel is about a 2 minute walk from a train line that after 15 minutes takes you to Shimbashi station. From there it is simple to catch other trainlines to points throughout Tokyo.It is very conveniently located near Haneda Airport. If you take a limousine bus direct to the hotel it takes all of 20-25 minutes and costs only 520 Yen each way. Though there are only a limited number of such buses a day. Otherwise, if traveling light it is possible to use the monorail and train system with two changes of lines required. However the limousine bus is best if possible, especially if you are burdened with luggage. (Narita is quite a distance away and either a limousine bus - 2800 yen - or the Narita express to Tokyo station and then a train to Shimbashi station and a change to the line going to Odaiba.)This is a very large hotel with some 30 floors and lots of rooms. I was fortunate enough to get a room on the 17th floor with a view of the bay. Like all four and five star Tokyo Hotels service is very good. In the case of the Nikko it is exceptional. It has a very large staff who are more than willing to assist you. English throughout the staff seems uniformly good. (Not sure of course about the maids but everyone else I dealt with had more than satisfactory English.)Rooms are of a good size for a Tokyo hotel with free wifi and about anything else I would want or expect in a very good hotel. I dined with a friend in the hotel's sushi restaurant. The room was very comfortable (with a table side view of the snow falling outside) and the food uniformly excellent. You can manage to eat here without paying exorbitant prices. Given the low price I actually paid for the room, I came out a very clear winner. It has to be one of my more recommended hotels in Tokyo especially if you can land a good deal.

Beautiful hotel on Tokyo bay, close enough to get to all of the main attractions in Tokyo, but also far enough away from the busy side of Tokyo. Beautiful views of the Rainbow Bridge and city from here.The only negatives were the on site restuarants were quite expensive and you have to pay to use the pool and children under 16 are not allowed in the pool at all.

Great location to Haneda Airport, which is only 20-30mins away via bus or taxi. Also Daiba train station is right outside with trains to Narita Airport or into central Tokyo . We had two rooms ( 1 x double & 1 x twin share) has we were a family of four with 2 teenage daughters. The rooms are very spacious especially for Japan and the views of the rainbow bridge and Tokyo are simply stunning. There are two shopping plaza’s within a 5 min walk ( DiverCity Plaza and Aqua City). The restaurants on level 6 at Aqua City all have amazing views of Tokyo harbor and the skyline of Tokyo with lots of variety of food on offer - Thai, Italian, seafood, Japanese etc.The staff at the Grand Nikko are very polite, professional, friendly and extremely helpful.

Nice hotel. Near 3 different malls which cater to highend shopping. Lots of restaurants to choose from. Good for families who want to stay in a quiet area. Lots of interesting museums like the wax museum, toyota showroom, lego place etc. But most establishments close early in this area. You'll really have to commute to see a lot more of what japan has to offer.

Not Central Tokyo but easy enough to get around from. On the train line, so can get anywhere. Staff very friendly and helpful. Has complimentary bus to Disneyland but you have to book well in advance.

Cozy good size room with excellent view of the Rainbow Bridge and Bay. Near to many shopping malls and restaurants but strangely none of the more popular ramen and sushi chains has a branch nearby. Location is 20 minutes by bus from Haneda Airport.You have to board the monorail (linked to the hotel) to get to Shimbashi, which costs Yen320 per trip and adds 15-20 mins to any journey, to transit to other parts of Tokyo via the train network. As we are a family of 4, we ended up taking taxi for some of the shorter trips. It is added cost but saved us a bit of time. Room and service are faultless. So if you are prepared to pay more and spend a little more time on transport in return for a more spacious room (relative to the central Tokyo hotel room), this hotel is worth considering.

Very nice stay in Odaiba, away from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, but easily accessible via the monorail. Absolutely gorgeous view of Tokyo Bay from the room and all major shops and restaurants of Odaiba are located within a five to ten minute walk. Definitely recommended to anyone who appreciates some space and greenery and views of the waterfront while in Tokyo. Perfect for runners as well! Plus the view of the Rainbow Bridge in the evening is absolutely stunning.

We stayed here for one night as our first night in Japan to look around Odaiba area before we moved to Minato area. We took monorail from the airport.The location is very nice if your purpose if to walk around Odaiba area. We checked in at the hotel and was upgraded to a rainbow bridge view room. The room was very nice and clean. All of the hotel ameneties products were Shiseido. My mom was allergic to dust and she said that the room was very clean as she did not have allergic reaction while staying here. The hotel connected to various places via bridges such as Aqua city Odaiba, Fuji TV Building, Divercity Tokyo Plaza, and near subway station. From the bridges, you can walk to see the Liberty Statue and to see a Rainbow Bridge. The view was amazing. Also, you can walk to see the Gundam statue via the bridges which is located at Divercity Tokyo Plaza. Outside the hotel towards the bridges, there are several shops: 24 hours convenience stores, a bakery, and couple restaurants. I would recommend to stay here as the room is very clean and the services was amazing. I read lots of other reviews: overall everything in Tokyo is expensive, if you want free breakfast, then you should pay the breakfast packages or expect to pay expensive breakfast. We actually have breakfast at the bakery outside the hotel. The hotel is old but the room size is okay and most important, the room is very clean. My parents and I (3 people) stayed here and the room size was okay and we rent the cheapest one. I also use the TA-Q bin service from the hotel and it was amazing as she helped me fill all the documents needed.

Spacious room and excellent view even though not facing the Rainbow Bridge. Convenient location to explore Daiba. If you like running, there are 2 well organized 5km running path that bring you to coastal line and shopping malls. Get tired, a public onsen is 2 stations away from the hotel. Many good restaurants nearby and needless to say, shopping shopping and shopping! The only drawback is that the gym and swimming pool is not complementary. You need to pay for those facilities.

What a wonderful hotel with very attentive staff. Very beautiful view of the rainbow bridge from the room as well as the lounge. Only a few steps away from the train station which was a huge advantage. Loved it and will come back here again in our next trip to Tokyo

This was the third and final hotel of our trip to Tokyo, the Grand Nikki was very expensive and did not include breakfast. The restaurant in the hotel was also incredibly expensive and for a family of four I could not justify paying the extortionate price for breakfast after already paying so much for the room. The location was great with direct access to public transport and therefore had other breakfast options close by. I was very surprised when I checked in and after handing my credit card over they actually produced the old style machine that you put the card on with the slip on top and the run the lever over it... it should have been a sign as the rooms were equally as dated as the credit card machine was!

I reached the hotel at 7AM in morning after a 14 hours flight from US. The reception said check in is only at 3PM and asked me to come back later. Then I asked if I can use the shower at the gym or the pool to freshen up and they said I need to PAY for it!! I was stunt, couldnt believe what I heard. Then I asked him to ask his manager about this, he came back to me saying his manager said I can check in to the room now but I need to pay JPY 22,000!!I am a frequent traveler, I have SPG Platinum, Marriott Platinum, Golden Circle Diamond and never ever I am treated like this even if I stay at hotel without any membership. I chose this hotel because it's not too far from airport and I'll only be spending 1 night in Tokyo for transit.My first experience with Nikko hotel and I will never ever again stay in any Nikko hotel chain!!! Btw, the limo bus from Haneda airport is only available from 10:50AM onwards, so you need to sit taxi if you arrive early in the morning.

The room may be small, but we had incredible views, found the location to all the city attractions very, very easy, and it made our visit feel like home.There are loads, and loads, and loads of Japanese cafes, shops, shopping centres, tourist attractions (Gundam displays and shops, ferris wheel, Venice themed shopping centre, Love sign, mini statue of liberty, bay habour, above ground light rail station etc) all around the hotel and all within easy walking distance (and all just beautiful at night when you want to walk off dinner and sake!).Lovely, hard working and helpful staff, and the exterior and interior entrances, wedding foyer and lobby is amazing (we kept stopping just to enjoy it all at different times).Get a room with a view (worth it to feel and watch this mega city at different times of the day and night) and make sure you have at least 1 cocktail up at the top floor bar, sit on a couch, and just enjoy the skyline (was about $20 per drink, but well, well worth it for our last night and the experience).This area is perfectly designed and inspiring as it part of the 2020 games expansions, and locals love it all as much as tourists.

First time staying in Odaiba, and we were glad we chose Nikko Grand.The exterior of the hotel may look typical, however, the interior is as grand and luxurious as an ancient palace. Those whom liken a break from the urban world, Nikko Grand is worth a try.We were allocated a room where we could enjoy interesting view of the morning sea traffic from the nearby habour, and planes landing and taking-off from Haneda Airport.  (Hotel had direct shuttle bus thru-and-fro Haneda airport.) Nikko Grand’s superior twin room is at least 1 time more spacious than typical hotel rooms in Tokyo area. We had walking and sitting space within the room even after opening up 2 non-cabin-size luggage bag and a haversack. There was an in-room mini table for us to enjoy coffee and bread during breakfast by the window too.We were lucky to meet the house keeping team every morning. They really did a very good job in keeping the rooms spick and span. On top of that, they also brighten up our morning with their greetings! The lobby executives demonstrated great hospitality. We were looking for Nikko Grand’s Bakery, the lobby executive did not simply show us the direction, he actually walked us to the Bakery!Bread lovers, if you happened to be around Nikko Grand, do try the bread from the Nikko Grand Bakery. Their aromatic bread had crispy crush and fluffy crump. It was our most preferred during our whole tour in Japan.We did not use the Yurikamome Transit, however we saw that a train station is conveniently at the door step of Nikko Grand. We took the Odaiba Rainbow bus from the bus stop in front of the hotel’s lobby, ride through the rainbow bridge, and reached Shinagawa JR Station in ~ 30min. Nikko Grand is also within walking distance from the bay area & shopping/dining places. While enjoying the peacefulness at Nikko Grand, it was relatively convenient to commute around Odaiba and town area.

We have enjoyed our stay at the Grand Nikko. Accessibility to public transport was fantastic and the surrounding area is perfect for families. We enjoyed all of our meals in the different restaurants on site. We found all the staff to be very helpful.

I was very much looking forward to spend some time in Grand Nikko Hotel and exspecially in the SPA/ Pool facilities after a long day of seightseeing in Tokio. Well, however, I must have had very unrealistic expectations to a 5 star hotel, since the pool area was not included in the 5 star hotel price. Ridiculous! Very, very disappointing and poor performance. Apart from this, the pool area is located at a very public part of the hotel complex, so in order to get to the forbidden pool you had to walk a solid trail in your bathrobe through e.g. an art exhibition and a wedding chapel. Interessting but highly unrecommendable. Another unpleasent point during my stay was the very unhelpful staff at the reception who didn't ever offer to help with my luggage. Thanks, but NO thanks!

Great room, western of Japanese style breakfast, convenient to Daiba rail station taking you into Tokyo city proper and all that it has to offer, including, Tsukiji fish market, Tokyo Skytree, Asakusa, etc...Nearby amenities.

Grand Nikko is a very good hotel, spacious room, spacious bathroom. Staff was excellent and able to speak english very well. Breakfast is very good big variety of food to choose. Located near Train Station and Shopping Malls.Grand Nikko also has a very good view of Tokyo skyline across the bay.

This is the last hotel in our 3 week honeymoon trip. We've stayed in various hotel properties ranging from 3 to 5 stars in both vietnam and several locations in Japan. I didn't think too much about service when staying at a hotel, but Grand Nikko Daiba has shown me why it matters. They are terrible in customer service. Here is what happened, I booked a non-smoking room. When we were checking in, I felt the guy was cold and rushed to give us our room key. I didn't think too much of it, because it is not that big of a deal. But compare this with a 3 star hotel in Sapporo who not only welcomed us, but helped walk our luggage up to our room. Major difference compared to what should be a 4 star hotel??The real problem was when coming back to our room on the 2nd night we smelled smoke. I felt it was strange since usually entire floors our kept non-smoking. So I called the front desk. They didn't give any explanation but only simply says we will bring new room key to you. They proceeded to move us to a new room but provided no explanation of what happened, so I decided to ask the manager (the staff connected me over the phone). He basically told me to prove i booked a non-smoking room by telling me to come down to the front desk.When I did, showing him the e-mail confirmation of a non-smoking room. He proceeded to say no, you booked a smoking room. I wouldn't care if they simply offered apologies or explanation of what really happened, but they wanted to pin all fault on me. And I told him at the end, that you should ask your customers in checking in if they are in a smoking or non-smoking room. (Something all hotels, vietnam and japan did before i checked in. They are the only one who did not confirm!!)AWFUL experience, will never stay in a nikko branded hotel. They do not care about their guests and they treated me with such disrespect.(Also should note that the rooms are outdated and the lights flicker, only saving grace of this hotel is walking distance to a couple malls. But it is NOT worth it, trust me. Since trains are fast to this area.)

Booked a non-smoking room for our honeymoon and they gave us a smoking room WITHOUT LETTING US KNOW. The staff that checked us in did not confirm anything with us and just sent us away with a room card. Nobody even came to help with our luggage. We only started catching on during our second night when the smoke smell from the rest of the floor started to come into our room. When we called the front desk and spoke to the manager, he demanded us to come to the lobby to show us the confirmation email of our booking as proof that the hotel made an error. We acquiesced and all he said was, "Smoking-free room means smoking." He denied that we booked a non-smoking room and dismissed us without any kind of compensation or sincere apology.And if that's not enough to convince you not to book this place (there are many other better hotels in the nearby area), the rooms are sad and dated, the chandeliers in the room flicker because they don't replace the lightbulbs regularly, and there is A QUEUE FOR THE ELEVATORS AT ALL TIMES OF THE DAY due to their terrible ratio of elevators to guests in the hotel. Your money can get you much better elsewhere.

This is my first tine in my life and my first time ever to use Nikkko brand with rejection of utilize concierge service!!!After i checked out, surprisingly i can’t put my luggage to concierge and they said that concierge only for guest who still stay with this hotel. If we want to use this services, it a must that we MUST pay for a room.A very ridiculous fove stars international hotel ever in my life! And i have told my office to delete All Nikko hotels chain to avoid company extra cost for such thing!Its totally different with other office colleague in Hilton Shinjuku and Shibuya Mark city hotel which allow us to keep luggage in concierge and giving us paper tag in order to claim back our luggage later.Beware of this Hotel and maybe this hotel policy applied to All Nikko chain. Just ignore or leave this hotel chain if you dont want to get disappointed with such a five stars. TOTALLY DISAPPOINTED HOTEL AND MAKE TROUBLESOME WHILE I HAVE ANOTHER URGENT MEETING TO ATTEND AFTER CHECK OUT!!!!!!!!

Grand Nikko Daiba is an excellence Hotel @ a very good location.Connecting to a monorail station, surrounded by several shopping malls, and have a stunning view of Tokyo Bay from our 29th fl.meeting room...Beautiful..!!Delicious breakfast options!!Neat room & bathroom...!!!Will comeback to visit grand nikko for sure...

This is the third time I stayed in this hotel in the last three years. Its location and sizes of rooms were the reasons for my choice. However, it's sad to see standards going down. Rooms are tired. The staff at the Front Desk who checked me in was less than warm. I would appreciate more food outlets (the restaurants at the nearby Hilton are significantly better in terms of food quality and ambience).

We stayed here for 4 days.Hotel was very clean, lobby & elevators are well-maintained. Room amenities are very good.Great customer service from hotel staff, they’re very friendly & helpful.Hotel location is very convenient.3-min walk from Daiba Station (Yurikamome Line) line, so going around Tokyo is quite easy. It’s also around 25-30mins from Tokyo Disneyland.When traveling with an infant or little kids, I would recommend taking the Airport Limousine bus from/to the airport. It’s very convenient especially with luggages.Attractions around hotel:Rainbow bridge, Venus Fort, Aqua City, Diver City, Giant Ferris Wheel, Mega@Web Car Showroom & many others.We would definitely stay at this hotel when we go back to Tokyo.

The Grand Nikko Tokyo Daiba is a great hotel with large spacious rooms. The bathrooms are also large with a separate shower and tub. The service and food are excellent. The location is a few minutes walk to Aqua City and Diver City shopping malls with lots of stores and restaurant options. The Yurikome train station is just steps from the hotel which goes to the Ginza and connects to other train stations. There is also a bus which provides access around Daiba.

We came to Tokyo primarily to see the Tokyo Motor Show so this Hotel was in a great location with proximity to the Tokyo Big Sight. But when we got there it was a whole lot more than we had imagined. Odaiba is a great location, many things to see and do in this location. The Yurikamome line train station is right at the door for ease of connecting to greater Tokyo.
