We had a Deluxe room and the room was huge and the bed was huge. The room had many amenities and luxury touches like Shiseido toiletries, Comfy slippers, Nespresso Machine and Noritake coffee cups. We also have a great view of the Rainbow Bridge and Greater Tokyo. We also had a choice of three restaurants to dine in for breakfast all included in our package. This Hotel is of Grand proportions and tastefully decorated. The stand out feature is the attentive and welcoming staff who went above and beyond to make sure our stay was enjoyable. We can't wait to come back. A big thank you to all the staff at Grand Nikko Tokyo Daiba

I attend a conference in the Miraikan Museum. The hotel was within walking distance. It’s also next to the Yorikamome metro line that takes you into Tokyo in about twenty minutes. A cool feature is that each room has a smart phone that you can take with you to navigate Tokyo (at no charge). You can also make free calls with it to certain countries.

It is easy access to all the shopping malls and attractions nearby and with free shuttle bus service, very convenient. Airport limo to Haneda Airport is just at JPY 520 and less than 30 mins journey. Room is big and bed is comfy. However, check- in time is 5pm and check-out time is 10am which is quite weird.

We stayed 2 nights here as part of a 2-week organised tour. The hotel is an older one, and as part of a tour package, we would have had a basic room. This was a bit small, and showing a little 'wear and tear', but completely adequate and very comfortable. Very good doesn't have to be ultramodern! Everything about the hotel generally is what you'd expect of a big hotel in a very large modern city. Everything runs smoothly, the lifts are excellent, the staff is helpful, and the breakfast quite astounding in variety and quality. At times there were queues for a breakfast table. Meals and bar drinks are expectedly expensive, though there are plenty of cheaper options nearby.

Grand Nikko Hotel is located in Daiba area. The hotel is beautiful and clean, and the staff friendly and helpful. There are little shops inside the hotel, and a convenience store located just steps away from door. Also within walking distance are two large multi-floor department stores, Aqua City and Diver City. Who says you can't eat cheap in Tokyo? Both Aqua City and Diver City have food courts on their lower level. I especially loved the food court at Diver City. I was able to get delicious beef udon noodle soup for only 4.50 Yen. Went back next night for Yaki Soba for only 7.80 Yen. I would definitely stay again at the Grand Nikko. Just a few steps away from subway. So convenient. Couldn't be happier with my stay in Tokyo.

Good high room with view of the Rainbow Bridge.Double bedGood sized bathroomQuick liftsClose to 3 shopping Malls and heaps of resturantsCovered access to driverless train into Shimbasi to connect to everywhere else.Free bus around Odaiba to other attractions

This one is really worth. Location : full marks. Just on the Daiba mono rail station and very well connected to the city. You can enter the hotel directly from the station. Easy walk, even with luggage. You can walk to the shopping mall AquaCity directly without going down or crossing the street. Most important is that the sightseeing tour buses pick you up from this hotel lobby, which is a great relief. Also you get local bus from hotel lobby for Shinagawa station, which is bullet train shinkansen station. So, if you are going to other city after Tokyo, you don't need to take taxi. Bus are very comfortable even with luggage. If you get a higher floor with view of Rainbow bridge, take it. Ambiance : Awesome. You can feel the grandeur in the lobby. Very specious and well decorated entrance and foyer. If you are early for checkin, you can easily and comfortably wait. there is enough sitting space. They take care of your luggage. Staff : Reception speaks workable english. All are very courteous and polite.Rooms : Spacious. We were warned about small rooms in Japan but this was a pleasant surprise. bathroom are good. Amenities are very nice. You get everything. Don't worry if you forget dental or shaver etc. View from higher floors are superb. Breakfast : good spread. Of course, for vegetarians it would be very limited choice but one can survive on variety of breads, waffles, cornflakes, fruits etc. Yes, go early-6.30 am to get a table. by 7am, you will have to wait outside ! People really have very early breakfast :) And they do not allow room slippers in restaurant. Wear proper footwear. The top floor restaurant is very expensive.Summary : this may be a bit costly, but worth it.

The exterior and lobby makes you think this is a great hotel but don’t be fooled. Thus is a big hotel with old tired rooms. They desperately need replacement. The room decor is terrible. There is only one English tv station and cnn is dubbed in Japanese. Service is non existent. There are better at the price.

Stay here twice in October 2017 in two different rooms. First time for 2 days on 21st floor twin deluxe room on Tokyo bay side view. Second time on "Ocean" view side twin deluxe 16th floor room. Both rooms were clean and comfortable. The 21st bay view room was bigger and had great views. The ocean view was smaller and view was nothing to see but cranes and trains, but $30/night cheaper. The facilities and staff were 4 star quality, but room décor and bath rooms need updating and showed a little wear. Both rooms had portable air cleaners and dehumidifiers, which leaked water on to carpet. These units were to freshen the stale and humid air, since they do not keep the a/c on when rooms are not occupied, (i.e. need room key card to have lights and a/c on). The on site restaurants are good, but this hotel books large tour groups and conventions, so if you want breakfast- GET UP EARLY! Be in line 15 minutes before the restaurant opens. There are plenty of shopping and food/restaurant options (i.e. Aqua City)in the large malls just a short walk away from hotel. The hotel location is not in the city center, so it does take some extra work to get to all the major activities in Tokyo. However, the hotel location is handy to the a train station on the Yurikamome line, which is operated by a third party ( not JR rail or Tokyo metro). So you can not use your tourist metro or JR rail passes to use this line and have to buy a 360 yen ticket for a 20 minute ride to the Shimbashi station to connect to other public transit in Tokyo. The hotel is about 30 minutes from Haneda airport, but 90 minutes from Narita airport by shuttle bus. The hotel does not offer compliment bus services to either airport.

Second time we've stayed here. It's first class! Convenient for Haneda airport (30 mins by bus) Shimbashi metro station (20 mins by train). The hotel is truly 5 star and would cost 3 times as much in London.Thoroughly recommended

We stayed in this Hotel during a visit to Tokyo motor show. The hotel is very good in terms of quality and services. Also very close to metro station which is quite convenient and nearby two malls, Aqua City Odaiba (5 minutes) and Diver City (10 minutes). Also you can go for a jog or walk along the seaside in the park next to the hotel. The only problem was that if you want to have an early breakfast there is only one non Japanese restaurant opening early and it gets so crowded that you may have to wait half an hour.

I have been to Japan for so many times but this is the 1st time that the staff ask me to waited for an hour for the receipt on the check in process, which normally they will just carefully make it and give you on check out process. The executive lounge open 8:00 - 22:00 but the staff are rude enough turn the light off and closed the drink bar since 21:20. Breakfast at 30 floor is poor in variety, quantity and quality as you can see in the attached photos that all the food they provided for the buffet. Although they have the À la carte menu to order 1 per guest but the quantity and quality of that dish are still unacceptable for 3,300JPY per person.

Of the five hotels we stayed in in Japan this had the least helpful and friendly staff of them all. The rooms are a good size and the cleanliness excellent as it was in all the other Jananese hotels. However this hotel itself is just another 5 star hotel and it may boast Rainbow bridge views but if it is the view you are after, stay at the Hilton as that really has the views of the waterfront! This one really is not worth the money.

Grand Kikko Tokyo Hotel located at famous business and recreation zone of Tokyo, the famous Daiba area, with convenient traffic arrangement for foreigners and travellers. Hotel setting is extremely beautiful and cozy, extremely clean and room service highly efficient. Dinner order will be delivered in an unexpected pace and in particular food quality is excellent. Do not forget to try their breakfast buffet with all kinds of varieties, western, Italian, Japanese style, with space capacity of more than 200-250. General impression: Two Thumbs UP!!!

2 years ago i staid at Nikko (now Hilton) i enjoyed great view on Tokyo bay snd great stay. Grand Nikko moved, and you now have a view on the Hilton or the motorway. After a sleepless night because of noise of the latter (only single glazing) and harsh negotiations they gave me another room. Rooms and bathroom are OK. Good access to nearby mall with plenty of shops an restaurants.If you want to have breakfast, better wake-up early or late to avoid 20 minutes queue.In short, i would advise to look for other options.

Diaba is not in a central location for downtown Tokyo, but with the monorail right out the front door access to all of Tokyo’s transit system is excellent (takes about 40 minutes to get anywhere central). Only stayed one night but was suitably impressed with the room, layout and services. So if wishing to avoid high Tokyo central hotel pricing this could be a nice option.

I like this hotel, very comfortable bed and washroom, the view is amazing, everything is correct about this hotel. Only breakfast on the top floor was a bit messy, you need to queue up and there were like 50 people waiting as the same time. Around the hotel you can enjoy the view and shopping mall, however I don't find these malls exceptional, it is quite boring if you used to travel in Asia you know what I mean, it is a big connected department store selling standard stuff.

We stayed here for two nights on the 11th floor. The hotel is of high quality and has everything you could wish for. The personnel is friendly and speaks good English. However, there is a certain Las Vegas feel of the hotel, I don't know if it's the Statue of Liberty replica nearby or the drunken Japanese having their own party on our floor (we almost had to report them the first night, but they quieted down around midnight). The bar located on the 30th floor has a stunning view of downtown Tokyo and is definitely worth visiting, they feature Japanese versions of known western drinks that are worth trying.

The hotel has an excellent location overlooking the Bay Area. Facilities are clean, rooms are spacious. Two train stations are nearby which makes access easy to Central Tokyo and other areas. Few areas need to be improved though: staff do not always speak very good English which makes communication difficult. The other is the management of the buffet breakfast. Almost every day there was a huge queue to get in to the breakfast area. No matter what time you arrived, you had to wait at least 15 minutes. Overall a pleasant experience.

Beautiful hotel, extremely clean. Rooms are larger than most Asian hotels. Super comfortable beds. Walking distance to the train. Family Mart just outside the hotel. The staff tried their best with English but could have some improvement. Great Wifi

We had 4 nights in this hotel staying on the 17th floor. The staff were excellent, could be improved slightly in the English department on the Captains desk but no big deal.The restaurants are all top class and the food exceptional. Try the Japanese breakfast, a real treat.The hotel is close to the monorail so a short walk with easy access to the city, get a day pass 820 Y.We found our room quiet and comfortable, recommended.

There are two areas to check in. The main check in counter is at the second floor. Second floor lobby is big and elegant. There are many art piece through out the lobby which are beautiful.Room is at a good size for two people with good view. There is fridge in room but empty. The hotel provides two bottle of water per room which is nice.The location of the hotel is close to the Tokyo Disney, which can be your choice if you are planning a Disney trip.The thing I notice the most as soon as I entered the lobby is the aroma scent is unique and very nice.The hotel team members are well trained and friendly. Especially thanks to Ms. Saori Nakamura for her warm hospitality.

The hotel is quite dated but appears clean with a larger room than I expected. However, the bedroom carpet appeared dirty in places. it was noisy not from inside noise but from noise from the outside which could be heard in the room. The hotel is situated close to very busy roads and a car racing business. In the morning there was pandemonium at breakfast. The hotel was busy and at one stage people were waiting outside the restaurant holding numbers to get a table. Despite empty tables in the restaurant. I felt that it seemed down to poor management and the hotel did little to resolve the situation. This happened both mornings that I had breakfast. I would not stay here again.

The hotel is great and is accessible to Daiba Station. Breakfast has limited selection. Service is exemplary. It has coffee shop, store in front of the hotel. It also housed several specialty restaurants.

We were here for a conference which was held in the hotel. It is a HUGE hotel and on the day we arrived, 7 weddings were being held there. That's how big it is. However also because of its size, we didn't really notice it being extra busy.The staff were the most willing and polite staff I have ever encountered in a hotel, anywhere. The rooms are modern, spacious and well thought out. An extra wall socket would have been nice but we managed. The bathroom is large, with every possible amenity that you could imagine and let's not forget about the Japanese toilets. They are amazing! You have to go to Japan if only for the toilets. They were a big hit with all of the conference delegates as well.There are only 2 comments that I could possibly have about the hotel that make it not the perfect place to stay, one is the breakfast. Although I didn't of course go hungry and the breakfast was sufficient, personally I would have preferred a non-fat or low fat alternative for milk and yoghurt - everything is full fat. But again personal preference here.The other thing that bothered me was cleanliness. Everything in the hotel is spotless except for one thing and that is the top ledges of the baseboards. Not only in our room did they miss these ledges, but also throughout most of the hotel which of course became a thing of mine when wandering around. Other than that, a perfect hotel with a, for us, perfect location next to the metro and with an amazing staff.

Close location to the airport and direct access to all transportation to the city.Friendly staff.Unfortunately, the rooms show their age and were not clean. For a short business trip ok or if you plan to go to Disney with your family

Perfect hotel if you plan to visit the The Tokyo big sight convention center, the location is as well very closed to some shoping center, the room are not too big but very comfortable, the service is excellent... the buffet breakfast is well organized with a lot of choice..

I am not used to post reviews online but the experience in this hotel was so bad that I thought I would share with you as this hotel definitely should be avoided...First of all the hotel is completely out of the center of Tokyo and far from the near metro or monorail station. It will take about 40 minutes by metro or 4000 yen to go to Shinjuku, Shibuya, Roppongi or Ginza.Second be aware that the room are very very noisy. The room, and I changed a few because of the noise, are all overlooking a high speed way which goes out of Tokyo and the double glazing is very poor and not efficient. You can literally feel the glass vibrate when cars or motor bikes go by. I could not sleep all night because of the noise Third staff is very rude and completely unhelpful, from receptionist to duty manager. I have never been treated so badly in a hotel.Fourh the rooms are very bad value for money and need a refurb. Only 2 power plugs available in the whole room, carpet wear and tear, beds are uncomfortable. Fifth the hotel works with large tourists group which, overcrowded, noise, a lot of waiting at facilities, elevator...I spent only one night here and I am very happy to leave.Overall a very unpleasant stay.AVOID AT ALL COST

We liked the hotel and location.Hotel is large, a touch impersonal but with "biggish" comfortable rooms. We were traveling with our 6 year old daughter and liked the proximity to the walking area connecting the green area and shopping Mals just around the hotel.Nice and relaxing after a whole day downtown.Nice touches were the kids toothbrush and slippers in the room and the decent sized Bath tub.Nothing negative to note.Bed was comfortable- not too hard.The views from our room higher up was a nice distraction on a jet lag in the middle of the night.

The hotel is huge and suitable for groups of any size. Central location as it is in area for great many tourist activities. Daiba Japan Rail train station stops on hotel property. Accommodation comes with sumptuous buffet breakfast.

very friendly staff, efficient check-in, great breakfast buffer, the rooms are western style, and have ample storage room, which is not necessarily the case in other Hotels in Japan. Access to the City via Jurikamome takes 15 Minutes, and 2 large Shopping malls offer evening meals.

The hotel was excellent, staff were helpful and the rooms functional and very clean, in fact the Daiba area where the hotel is located was unbelievably clean, no litter or graffiti anywhere.The hotel is ideally located with a train station 3mins walk, numerous large shopping centres within 5-10mins walk, shops within the hotel complex including a small supermarket and cafe and restaurant and a local bus stop right outside the hotel entrance.We would certainly use this hotel again

This is a good business hotel. It's not in the centre but there is a train station close by. Staff are very professional and attentive. I would recommend it for a business stay. It is in the mode of a big hotel so not very atmospheric.

Stayed 4 nights at the Grand Nikko Hotel Daiba in September. Lovely hotel with wonderful staff. It's located away from central Tokyo accessed by above ground train across the Rainbow Bridge with station located directly outside the hotel entrance. The local area needs to be explored on foot and it's all great (look out for the illuminated wheel) and explore everything within. It's easy to reach central Tokyo via Shinbashi and the travelling is fun. The hotel bar has a brilliant atmosphere and it's great to relax late at night after the hectic visits to Times Square, Electric City etc. Wonderful place wished we could stay longer but off to Kyoto.

I recently stayed at Grand Nikko Hotel for 5 nights in the middle of September during the Ultra Music Festival. The music festival ran for three days & the hotel is in prime location to the festival & Tokyo Odaiba Ultra Park. The festival was a 2 - 3 minute way each way. The hotel also has Daiba train station & a 24/7 convenience store at its doorstep. If you want bigger shops then Aqua City Shopping Mall is less than a minute’s walk away. The hotel has a very grand entrance with a lot of marble on display & stunning views out over the Rainbow Bridge. I would definitely recommend this hotel to people looking to stay in Daiba.

Really convenient for Haneda Airport and great connection to central TokyoBut dullThe views from top floor are spectacular but the immediate area is dull and in interestingSecond rate malls and cheesy attractionsMuch better to pay a bit more and stay in central TokyoOverall it was clean food good and reasonable prices

The surrounds are a bit void of anything much including restaurants but the hotel itself is very nice. The rooms are clean and nice. The staff are polite and all on the concierge desk extremely helpful.I was there for a conference and the facilities were amazing. The only criticism I would have is that the lobby bar was slow and overwhelmed. If you are going to have conferences of 500+ people having one person serving behind the bar is never going to work. Waiting 40 minutes for a drink is unacceptable.

Visited the Grand Nikko Hotel Daiba in September on a business trip. I took train from Haneda Airport got off from Tokyo Teleport and walked for around 10 minutes. Hotel is located on a podium overlooking the Odaiba Bridge and the Tokyo Bay. Check in was a little bit hiccup they firstly gave me a smoking room without asking. It was corrected swiftly by replacing a bayview room.The hotel's deco is not super modern but classy and well maintained. I attended conference in the hotel banquet room, organization and facilities were high standard at a large scale banquet standard. There is a shopping mall houses number of restaurants by 3 minutes walk. A convenient store locted just outside hotel entrance. The Daiba train station is 1 minutes walk on the connecting podium, this train goes to Shimbashi in 20 minutes. Overall it is good value hotel of reliable service at the room rate. Highly recommend to those plan to stay in this part of Tokyo.

After an amazing whirlwind two week trip in Japan, am so sorry to have booked the Grand Nikko for the last night. What an utter disappointment. Front desk was appalling. Was made to feel like a beggar. Was not made to feel welcome at all and was asked to pay for my room up front? This hadn't happened once at any of the properties I'd booked, from the Park Hyatt, to Benesse House, to private ryokan, never once was I asked to pay upon check in. The room was listed as a luxury room, and we paid a luxury tariff, but received a tatty outdated room with really tacky decor, a sad looking chandelier and rundown carpets?! And on a low floor with a view of an industrial area?? What luxury are they referring to?? The amenities in the bathroom are of such a low quality compared to other properties of the same caliber. On top of that, the room smells, and the road noise was very loud and disturbing. Would never stay here again and will make sure to pass this information on to any friends or colleagues that are planning a visit to Japan. What a shame to end our trip on such a low note. There is nothing Grand about the Grand Nikko!

We stayed 9 days in this beautiful hotel , very enjoyable stay. Staff very polite and helpful.You have everything nearby and you can access anywhere from a sort of tram connecting to the subway with fantastic views along the line .The breakfast was excellent , a massive choice.The only letdown is the fact that they charge you for the the privilege of using the swimming pool 2600 yen each. We would highly recommend this hotel .

A very nice hotel, big room, and the view is always stunning. We stayed her during May/Jun 2017. We noticed this hotel when we were staying at another hotel across to this hotel, and decided to give this a go this year. Although some of the staffs were not that warm compared with other hotels, but I can say they are quite helpful. This hotel also provides a free shuttle to and go for Disneyland and Disneysea. Just don't forget to put your name in the list for each trip (to go there and to return back). Hotel room is big, bathroom is big and completed with nice toiletries. A very convenient hotel, as outside the hotel is the Yakamome line which you can hop on/off to connect at other line at Shimbashi station. The Family Mart-convenience store is also in front of the hotel. Last time our hotel view was facing Rainbow bridge. Will come back.

Stayed at this hotel for 3 nights as a stop over to Europe. A beautiful hotel, conveniently close to the rail link into the city. Beautifully furnished and excellent staff. A quiet part of Tokyo. Highly recommended

Gorgeous grand hotel with very large and spacious rooms (especially by Tokyo standards!). Hotel is very luxurious and has tons of restaurants and facilities. Within a short 3 minutes walk to the subway stop, it's convenient, albeit time consuming, to reach the main areas. You're looking at 35 minutes+ to get to Ginza, Shinjuku, etc. It's within walking distance to two large malls. Great hotel if you don't mind spending some time on public transportation.

When i entred the hotel i got a feeling of luxury and Class. I thought i got a small room, but oh no... It was big and the bathroom was big aswell, bathtub and a shower. The Only disapointment i had was i got harbour view and not rainbow bridge view with the Tokyo skyline ( worth upgradeing ) The transfer to hotel on a daily basis is kind of expensive. You have to get a special card to ride the yurikamome line from shimbashi, its 319 yen One way. Campares to Tokyo Metro when you get 3 days unlimited rides for 1500 yen.Housekeeping was good all in order nothing ordenary there.Staff nice and polite just like japaneese people are. Helpful and careing. I recomend this hotel IF you have a good budget, since it not the cheepest hotel. But very worth the money. Around the hotel you have status of Liberty, diver city (mall and restaurants ) Aqua city (same) Venus fort (outlet) and a big fairiswheel. There are alot of things to do on odaiba Island so you are not gona be disapointed.

Grand Nikko is a fantastic hotel. There is something for everyone to see and do. Plenty of shopping, dining, family entertainment. Everything is within walking distance from the hotel. The train station is outside to hotel.

There is no doubt that the hotel is grand. There are lots of impressive spaces that are designed for occasions like a ball or weddings. When nothing much is happening, the space can feel a little empty.The guest rooms are reasonably spacious. Very well appointed and not lacking in any amenities. In fact, we were quite impressed with their selection. As usual, the number of English TV channels are very limited but being situated in the middle of the Daiba district, there are a lot of entertainment options which will be sufficient for most people on a short stay.There are two issues why I only gave it 4 stars. One is that it is not in Tokyo metro proper so any visits to other main touristy areas will require a train trip (possibly changing trains and stations) and extra traveling time. Keep this in mind and look at the map before you book. The second issue is the extra cost of using the gym and pool (about USD 10 per visit). I understand that it is a very nice facility which is marketed more as a spa but consider how much they are charging for rooms, it seems a little petty to charge paying guests extra for use of gym equipments.There are lots of dining options on-site but they are all quite expensive. But here are lots of other options within walking distance so it is not an issue. When you are desperate for a midnight night snack, there is a 24hrs convenience store just around the corner.Staff are uniformly polite and helpful. Can't fault them at all.

This is an excellent hotel located right next to Daiba station and various shopping centres. The staff are most helpful and very friendly. The food is very good and the breakfast choice is very high quality. There is also a direct bus service to and from both Narita and Haneda airports. But check the timings for exact departure times of the buses as they can be infrequent

This was a very convenient place to stay and and overall I liked it and the staff were very nice, but there are things to consider. You can easily catch the monorail out the front of the hotel and go over to Shimbashi to go to one of the main areas, they leave every few minutes up until midnight. From there you have many options as it is busy during the week and not so as isolated and is completely different. I have mixed reviews about this hotel. It was a good location, it was easy to get to Shimbashi but it was a long way from other things. From Narita airport we caught trains, as our flight was too late to use the limousine bus, it took us nearly 4 hours!! But we did get given some wrong directions at the airport train station which caused a bit of a delay. Not sure the bus would be much quicker, maybe depends on the time of day.The first room we had was great on 11th floor over looking the beach area and Statue of Liberty, awesome view. We had that room for 6 nights, then we had to change as our room was not available for our whole stay. So we moved to room 940. Awful, the room and the whole floor stink, even in the corridors there was this damp, sewerage kind of smell. I am still washing the smell out of the clothes. I don’t know if other levels have this problem but level 11 did not. So this ruined the second half of our stay.The hotel has a very good no cleaning room initiative, you can choose on certain days not to have your room done by house keeping and you receive 1,000 Yen tokens which you can spend at certain shops and restaurants, or donate directly to UNICEF. Very nice toiletries in the rooms. The beds were really hard, so not comfortable at all.We stayed here because the hotel had a pool and it is warm weather. We phoned to make sure I could use it as we had read a review that said no women or children were allowed. The hotel confirmed I could use it a couple 2 days before we arrived, BUT they neglected to tell us it was closed until Summer and did not reopen until the end of July!! We were there at the end of June until 4th of July, I would have thought that was summer, this is not on the website!The gym and pool cost extra so look out for that, if you were a family it would be very expensive. Gym was OK, not great. Pool no idea, closed.There are a lot of nice places to eat amongst the many shopping centres and food courts in Daiba. There is a 24 hour convenience store at the front of the hotel, very reasonable and saved us a few times, especially the night we arrived as it was late and places in the area closed quite early so everything was closed. There is a pretty good coffee shop out the front and a nice bakery & pastry shop, both will take your coupons if you have any, but not at the 24 hour store.I would consider staying again but not on level 9 that is for sure.

When arrived at Daiba station (Yurikamome line), the Hotel would be seen due to it's in front of Daiba station.Could walk to the nearest mall, Aqua city and photo with liberty statue - rainbow bridge.2 choices of breakfast style: western buffet style at Garden Dining or at Le bouquet, or Japanese breakfast meal at Oshima restaurant. We booked triple room and thought that our preschool children would be free for breakfast, but no... we had to pay JPY 1029 for the breakfast (pricing pics attached).Comfortable beds, big and clean rooms with complete amenities (shiseido), good hot/cold shower and has a bath up. It also has ice making room (in front of our room) and the ice bucket also prepared.The plus plus, the hotel has bay shuttle bus to go around odaiba area (asked for schedule time-in the counter in front of receptionist) and limousine airport bus to Haneda or Narita (bus ticket could be bought in the counter in front of receptionist).The hotel could be access from tokyo tower skytree or from kinshicho station by tobu bus (adult JPY 600, child JPY 300 - see the hotel website or tobu bus web for detail).Unfortunately, the swimming pool was closed during our stay. It open only mid july till august and need to pay for using the pool.I would recommend this hotel due to its location, great staff and comfort room.

As far as I know this hotel changed its name twice. It's a grand hotel which is obviously aging and needs some serious improvements. It was my second stay for two nights with my grade school aged kids. Flying from LA, riding a bus from Narita, jet lagged, exhausting kids finally fell asleep and then right by my ears from the headboard, first I thought, there came the continuous creaking sound went on and on. It wasn't my next door guests. The very distinct, annoying noise was just like the old wooden door creaking in horror movies.I did search for the past TripAdvisor guest reviews with the similar experiences then found three reviews in Japanese so that proves hotel is aware of the problem. As a former hotel concierge myself I am certain that they keep records of which rooms had clams before. Their intervention for us in the middle of sleepless night when I called was to move my bed from the wall. They said there were no other rooms available on the same floor or they had a room only with two beds! I was paying for three beds for three of us for the stay. Hello??? I even let one employee hear the sound from the wall and he told me the strong wind was the cause. Their excuse was since they can't predict the direction of the wind they can't do much about it. After having two employees over, talking with them right next to my kids trying to fall back to sleep after being awake more than 24 hrs, I had enough for the night. The loud spooky sound kept going throughout the night even after moving bed.Next day the front desk told me on windy days quite a few guests complain about the noise. The least I expect from a hotel is a clean, quiet room so my kids and I can be well rested to enjoy the following day in Japan but that was totally ruined. I took my 15 min filling out the after stay surveys but they haven't said a thing about after almost two weeks. My impression was the management focuses more on Chinese speaking group guests.The interns and room maintenance people working under the questionable management were extremely polite and went above and beyond their assigned work. I very much appreciated their service so two stars are for them.

Our family of 4 was a bit large for the accommodations - but us and the hotel made the best of things and pushed all 4 beds together and it all worked out fine. The bathrooms were good sized and since there was a bath tub and shower, our family was able to maneuver pretty easily. Our kids especially enjoyed the morning breakfast buffet and all the near by shopping!

Airport limousine bus available from both Narita and Haneda airport, closer to Haneda airport. Hotel is connected to Yurikamome line and shopping malls. Most of shops around this area close at 9 or 10pm. 24 hours convenient store next to the hotel. Very busy hotel with lots of groups. Lobby area was full all the time. It is a big hotel but some areas are under utilized especially B1, 2nd & 3rd floor area. Room is quite spacious but outdated products. No amenities or special benefits for One Harmony members. Additional charges will incur for those who wishes to use fitness club and sauna. One Harmony sent some discount coupons for room upgrades but front office declined to accept it without any reasons. Some male staff in front desk and concierge are very rude. They do not greet or talk with eye contacts, and more importantly I never have seen them smiling during my 5 night stays. Matured male staffs in bell desk not friendly at all. Room service meals are highly overpriced. Quality of food is very average and actually worse than some Nikko hotels or Okura hotels. Not sure why this is branded as Grand Nikko...maybe only because of size. Great area to walk around and relax. Spent early morning and late evening walking around after busy schedules.

Particularly fond of elegant and expansive lobbies, complete with sparkling chandeliers and high ceilings, the Grand Nikko's lobby was exactly that and I was utterly enthralled! Ideal location (what with the entertainment and restaurants, elegant boutiques, shopping centers, train station practically right at its doorstop); exceptional service; friendly and helpful staff at the Front Desk, Concierge, Housekeeping, Restaurant; sizable room AND bathroom; GREAT view; ample amenities; the best breakfast AND dinner buffets! The Grand Nikko is, for this lady, a tick-all-the-boxes hotel! Superb! Kudos!I must expressly mention that when I needed a box to pack some of my things, Concierge got me a box, gave me all the wrapping materials I needed, offered to help me with the sealing and labeling, all delivered with a smile! And with sumptuous breakfasts and dinner @the Garden Dining buffet, we tossed out the window any and all resolve to diet as we partook of the very delectable fare! Again, kudos! I must also mention that because a queue can make hungry diners irate at the door while waiting to be seated during breakfast hours, the hotel thoughtfully set up a lovely coffee service at comfortable sitting area outside the restaurant. I was soooo tickled pink that we stayed 3 nights @the Grand Nikko! ALL, and I mean, ALL things considered ~ Superb!

Stayed in this hotel already a few times, however the first time since it became part of the Nikko Hotels.Nice room, good shower, good facilities and very convenient to Tokyo Big Sight exhibition center with the train station right in front of the hotel. Also 2 shopping centers nearby.The only thing which could be improved is the fact, that the last bus to Narita leaves before 5 pm, but this will be beyond their control I guess.

Exceptional and marvellous hotel! We really enjoyed every night of our staying there. Very comfortable, spacious rooms, all the amenities included, highest level of quality and staff is very helpful. Only 10 minutes to get to the center of Tokyo by monorail (the station is 1 minute from the hotel). Best views on Tokyo bay and Rainbow bridge. Largerst shopping centers are also very near. Definitely recommend and I will return there with pleasure!

I booked this room for the view that it offers looking towards the Tokyo skyline. The hotel is located on reclaimed land and sits beside a number of amusement park type facilities. Some locals refer to the location as "the island" and consider it a bit out of the way which perhaps it is but for the view looking back is worth the expense and few extra minutes you may need to spend on the subway/metro train to get there. I paid more for similar size room at another hotel with no stunning view and no regular facilities for this level of hotel, such as fitness center, business center, concierge desk, room service, etc. The amusement and entertainment facilities nearby make it a great hotel for families with children. So in summary, good value.

Despite other opinions, I found this perfect place to access central Tokyo. The Daiba station is just outside the hotel and you are in the Center just minutes away. The rooms are spacious and you have everything you need. The buffet breakfast included in our stay was excellent. Going out and walking to Aqua city or other malls was very entertaining. When we return to Tokyo definitely this will be our choice!

This hotel is impressive. The foyer is huge with chandeliers and marble pillars. There are loads of staff on the front desk who bow to you as you enter, your bags are taken up to your room on a trolley. There are boutiques in the foyer, including one selling souvenirs. In other words, it's what you imagine from an old-fashioned posh hotel.The staff on the desk and in the restaurant speak English. The wifi is free and available all over the hotel. The rooms are medium sized (large by European standards, probably not by American standards) and you get a desk, two easy chairs, a small fridge (not stocked), plenty of drawers and a wardrobe with enough hangers for a week-long business trip. You get two bottles of mineral water daily, though the tap water is also drinkable. The bathroom has a full-sized bath, along with a strong shower and a toilet with all the buttons and features (bidet, heated seat...). They provide shampoo and conditioner, and all the toiletries you might have forgotten (toothbrush and paste for example). I forgot a nightshirt and there was one provided, which got replaced with a new one every day! An English-language newspaper was provided daily in front of my door. It is expensive. And I recommend getting a package with breakfast - I had tokens for the buffet, which included freshly cooked omelettes made to order, as well as the core components of a British, American, European, Chinese and Japanese breakfast. My colleagues who did not have the with-breakfast deal found breakfast far too expensive and ended up eating out. It is in a quiet part of town, right next to Daiba station on the monorail (Yurikamome line). It took about an hour to get there by train and monorail (one change) from Narita airport. On my return I took a taxi to Haneda airport-about 25 minutes at 6am. There's a taxi rank outside the hotel, so no booking and waiting. It was easy to walk to my conference venue and the whole area is pedestrianised and open for walking around. There are loads of shopping centres, all with plenty of restaurants for all tastes nearby. I didn't try out the hotel gym, because there were pleasant places to run outside - and that was fine as a woman alone at 6am, I never felt any concern. You can run 5km without crossing a road - and the route for that is sign posted (look for Odaiba running course).

The room is big and beds are very comfortable. It is also a place where kids will enjoy specially in the bathroom with a big bath tub. Staffs are very helpful but they need a person who can speak and understand english to attend to their tourist guest needs and make their service excellent in providing directions(specially the closing time of trains going to the airport and a tourist information desk will be much appreciated). Location is very near to the train station and shopping mall and convenience store. Breakfast is tasty but is a little of what we expected for a buffet in an expensive hotel. It will be more better if there will be a lot of options since it is the best meal of the day for us who will tour all throughout the day and explore nearby tourist spots. I also hope that they have a place for little children in the lobby since you cant stop these children to play and make a noise.(Children are still children and not adults who follow all instructions). We did not see the pool and hoping even though its cold, they will let their guests see it open. Free shuttle to and from Disneyland is of great help to us. We will still book in this hotel in the near future.

As everyone else has said good clean hotel .Friendly staff and very polite .Now the breakfast in my opinion was very limited for the western style no baked beans ,convenience store at hotel open 24hrs Aqua city shopping mall two minute walk away.The water pressure in the shower is very good and always plenty of hot water.After 4 nights in this hotel when we left the staff waved us off.

This was a great location due to its proximity to the Haneda (HND) airport and the convention center at Tokyo Big Sight. The proximity to the subway was great. The hotel itself was nice. The elevators are so smooth, you do not feel like you are moving. The view was nice from my room.It was a 15 minute ride on the subway to get into the city. For those leaving out of NRT airport, there is a bus that picks up at the hotel so that was also nice. Would stay there again if in Tokyo.

We stayed for 4 nights. It was a chore getting from Narita and we opted for a cab in the end which was pricey bit got us there. The hotel is absolutely beautiful with spacious rooms- plenty of space for our fam of 4. The local area kept us entertained and there is a station next door- although not JR. The free Disneyland shuttle is great, saves time and hassle. Getting out to central Tokyo eg ueno, shinjuku took time. The staff were lovely and welcoming. We would stay again in a heartbeat.

Five nights at the Grand Nikko and it truly was a good hotel in an excellent location for "tourism". Surrounded with amazing views of the Tokyo Bay, the hotel is a short walk to major commercial centers packed with shops and restaurants. Our room was surprisingly large on the 25th floor and the view was beautiful, especially at night. Hotel staff is exceptional with polite warmth and go to attention. The only detail I would address is the fact that they make the guest wait and wait until the designated check in time. It is an enormous hotel and many travelers have been in the air and or airports for 18 plus hours. They sincerely should be mindful and work with the guest.

The Grand Nikko Daiba is very high, 30 stories. The location is excellent, even apart from its amazing view over Tokyo Bay. The Daiba rail station is just steps outside the hotel’s front door as is a convenience store. Several large multistory “malls” are nearby, also a replica of the Statue of Liberty. Airport express buses, for just 520 yen per person, run several times an hour, leaving the hotel with the next stop at Haneda Airport.Our room was rather small but well appointed, with queen bed, desk and chair, two comfortable chairs next to a table and floor lamp, an unstocked mini fridge, safe, small dresser, night stands, closet, good air-conditioner, TV, two phones, free wifi, slippers and Japanese nightshirts, humidifier, and one luggage stand. Electricity is operated by putting the plastic key-card in a slot by the door. There are buttons that turn on outside lights requesting privacy or housekeeping. There are nightlights that illuminate the carpet from under the bedside tables. We got an English-language newspaper each morning in a holder outside our door as well as two free bottles of drinking water daily. There were plenty of outlets, which accommodate American-style plugs and have similar voltages. Our 18th floor room looked out onto an expressway exiting from a tunnel under the bay, parking lots, an industrial waterway, etc. We heard road noise, though faintly.Our bathroom was well designed, with a shower/tub combo, the usual fancy Japanese toilet that ran and squirted whether you wanted it to or not. The bathroom mirror was heated so that it didn't fog up from the moisture of a shower. Service response was very quick (e.g. laundry delivery). The eight main elevators were excellent, extremely quiet, with faint classical music. On each floor, a light immediately came on indicating which elevator would arrive first and whether it was going up or down; it then blinked when it arrived. The hotel has a huge atrium, which includes a wedding venue. The fitness club costs about $10 per day, even for hotel guests, but has an indoor pool with a nice temperature. People with tattoos are not admitted, a peculiar form of Japanese discrimination. When we asked about a room with a view toward the Rainbow Bridge, we were told that we would have to pay 126,000 yen for our six-night stay rather than 89,000...and though the room would be larger, it would have two twin beds rather than the queen bed we desired. So we declined. Our rate did not include the 3,300 per-person charge for breakfast. Most guests had breakfast coupons, presumably via deals that included breakfast with the room charge. Given the amazing view from the 30th floor restaurant and abundant variety of western and Japanese breakfast items, the charge was not unreasonable, and the room charge (booked via TripAdvisor) was also reasonable, though somewhat more expensive than other nearby hotels.We recommend the expensive breakfasts on the 30th floor that opens at 6:30 a.m., though there are other options that open later. On some mornings, the restaurant was largely empty; but on others, a long queue had formed before opening and still later arrivees had to give their names and return later. The most desirable tables, facing the Rainbow Bridge, are mostly for two people only; these provide what must be the best, premium view in the entire city of Tokyo. We tried the Japanese and Chinese restaurants in the hotel; they provided good, attractive meals with good service, but were expensive.Our international conference, in a nearby science museum, held its “banquet” in a splendid underground ballroom of this hotel. The food served buffet style was soon gone; many interpreted it to be an appetizer course, but it was actually the entire meal. Some people had nothing to eat other than dessert (and beer), despite paying about $130. Whether this was a failure of the hotel or of our conference organizers, or perhaps a cultural mismatch in what to expect and how much to eat from a dinner buffet, we do not know.On our final morning, we requested a noon check-out instead of the posted hour of 10 a.m. The front-desk clerk said that it would cost 4000 yen! We explained that we had never heard of charging for a late check-out unless it extended well into the afternoon. He was obstinate. We asked to speak to a manager and he told us to stand in the lobby by the suitcases, which we refused to do. No manager ever came. After about 15 minutes, the clerk finally said, “OK, you can depart at noon with no charge, but just this one time.” We recommend this hotel, but beware of unexpected high prices, like the 4000 yen extra charge to extend your stay just until noon, or the appetizer plate of caviar that costs about $300.

Well, it's our first time in Japan, and we stayed at this hotel a couple of weeks ago, first hotel on our trip, great staff, superior service, we were over the moon happy with it, but then came yesterday.It was a Sunday, and I'm not sure that was a factor, but the service took a great dive. First they didn't find both rooms and thought that we had booked a twin room for three people, finally they thought of checking under the third persons name and found the other room, they had all of our passports so it was just a matter of looking. Then they didn't give us all of our meal passes for breakfast, so I had to use one of my friends, when I went to get more today after using it the attitude was one of "why do you need more if we gave that to you yesterday?", like I was not telling them the truth or something. They gave me one for today and one for tomorrow even though I explained that I needed them both for tomorrow, so I needed the concierge (thank God for him) to explain what I needed. Ah, another thing, after check in, no one helped us with our luggage, nor to our room, we remembered the hotel so we went on, but I find that unacceptable too.

Saga's tour "Land of the Rising Sun".A tour full of interest and fascination.Saga tours for older folks have frequent stopsFor old men like me who need a "rest" - lots.The rest rooms in Japan are everywhere clean.I've been impressed wherever I've been.The rate of progress is usually slow.There's time to photograph wherever you go.Local guides may be hard to engage,With inadequate skills in English language.We had an excellent tour managerWho had a great sense of humourPlus empathy with clients quite appropriate.This was our first holiday to JapanAnd I am sure I'll remain a fan.The Grand Nikko hotel, Daiba's magnificentAnd I'm really pleased that's where we were sent.Using the toilet is quite an event !I read the instructions before I went.There's a problem with the loo roll,It's very thin and water soluble.Needing bright sunshine to reset my body clockWe were greeted by mist, low cloud and fog.The breakfast room is up on floor thirty" On clear day from here one can seeAs far away as the mountain "Fuji".Perhaps, maybe, allegedly.Breakfast's a good international buffetBacon, hash browns, croissants, cafe au lait.The choice most people this will suitBut some may prefer more choice of fruit.It's all cold of course but don't be lateIt gets quite busy around quarter to eight.The tour of Japan starts with Tokyo.It's crowded and noisy but of course one must go.Temples and shrines of which there are lotsGot off at Shinbashi, walked to Ginza shops.Caught the monorail back to Daiba, (hotel)And our afternoon went very well.If Tokyo was lost in crowdsMount Fuji next day, was lost in clouds.

My husband had a last-minute business trip to Japan and our options were limited with a budget of <$450 a night, this was all we could find. It takes about 40 minutes by train to get into Tokyo - to Ginza, Shibuya, etc. If you can get this hotel for <$250, then I think it's a good deal. Expensive by American standards, but not expensive in Japan. I'm giving this hotel a poor review for three main reasons. The location. The horrible brunch that cost US $28 and the outdated Japanese toilets. Keep in mind that I have higher expectations for hotel Nikko based on the one in San Francisco. And paying $400/nt for a remote location, expectations are a bit high. Location:Location - if you are American, I'm not sure why you would want to stay in this area because everything is American, ranging from Red Lobster to ToysRUs. There's even a Statue of Liberty in the bay out front. Just not my scene. I guess it's fine and desirable for people with kids.Dining options were very limited in my opinion, unless you want to spend several hundred dollars. The only decent Japanese option that we enjoyed was Gonpachi in the huge mall next door. (This is a copy of the main restaurant in Roppongi, where Quinton Tarantino's Kill Bill had a famous scene.) On the positive side, it is very conveniently located adjacent to a new private train. Expensive compared to other local trains and no combo or day use options. Costs $7 round trip to Shimbashi station (then you need to buy new tickets to wherever). Taxi from Narita is $200. No joke. That's what we paid. (Try the limousine bus, if that's available.)If you're coming for business, not doing much sightseeing in the main Tokyo areas, then this hotel is fine, and a lot closer to Haneda. Brunch:Brunch had a wait. Yes, it's a buffet and you had to wait to get seated. And the food was poor quality. Though, I was not impressed with much of the breakfast in any hotel in Japan so perhaps it's just me. But the runny scrambled eggs and the overcooked rubbery hard sunny side up were horrible - and that was the best of all the options. It was so bad, I had to take a picture. See below. Thankfully they had fresh fruit and yogurt. Even the minimal pastriespastries were boring and dry. Omelette station looked nice, but I'm not into omelettes. Toilet:Disappointing toilet. Outdated by Japanese standards. This is a fancy hotel, and I expect the toilets to measure up. Here, even on the executive level our toilet was just the added bidet seat thing. It wasn't even a mid-range. It was low end. If you don't know what I'm talking about, it sounds like I'm a complete snob, but after you spend some time in Japan, you will notice the difference. We stayed in a very small ryokan in the middle of nowhere and the toilet had automatic sensors that lifted/shut the lids, heated seats, and even air dried your butt! This toilet had 1/5 the features. Positives: lovely room on the executive floor with nice views. Very clean and comfortable. Excellent shower and water pressure and large bathtub.

A very impressive hotel. Have very beautiful view.The location is good, the service is good, the staffs are good, the view out of window is good, the take away coffee is good, the room is good……Everything is good!I like this hotel!

Our room was small but very nice,comfortable beds , excellent products in bathroom, breakfast was included in our stay and it was excellent with lots of choices, easy walk to train and Aqua city mall where you have many restaurants with reasonable prices, able to walk to and fro without having to be at street level even a lookout over the river.

Truly 5 star highly recommended for their facilities,friendly staff and great location.Check in cards ready in advance upon arrival no waiting or time wastage. In the room u will find each and every thing they are mentioning,even tea maker filled with water.

presidential floor quiet reception, no annoying people around there. Lounge had good appetizers, salmon salad, vege sticks, cheese, high quality sweets, free alcohol beverages including fancy Japanese sake, sparkling wine, as looking great view of Tokyo skyline. Room coffee machine was very good and buffet lunch next day was amazing.

Very good value for moneyWonderful staff who are so gracious,helpful and generally happy with their station.The breakfast as incredible and it was just as well we were only staying a couple of days.Close to convenient walking areas

Hotel is located on Daiba island, connected to the mainland by the light rail its a 25mins transfer to Ginza/Shimbashi. Don't get me wrong, its a wonderful location surrounded by many shopping malls eg: Venus Fort. ...but if you rather go around Tokyo then be prepared to travel into the island across the rainbow bridge.The room is big and spacious, the bathroom is large comparing to many international hotels I have been to.. plus it has a bath tub. Breakfast is served either on the 30th floor which give you a 360 view of Tokyo or 2nd floor. Be prepared to wait 20 mins if you want to try the 30th floor. The buffet spread is five star...large spread of both the usual pancakes, eggs, breads, hams plus the japanese breakfast.Or better still go to the top, have a drink at the bar and you can see the captivating night view of the Tokyo Tower and rainbow bridge.

The location adjacent to two shopping malls with lots of clothing stores and restaurants to choose from is a major factor for choosing the hotel. There are several halal restaurants within walking distance as well. The staff are extremely helpful and polite. The room was comfortable and the A/C was easy to control and was very proper. The wifi could've been faster and I found the furniture to be a little bit outdated compared to the adjacent Hilton Daiba Hotel which I stayed at in 2014 but those weren't big issues and can easily be overlooked.

We stay there on our final two days and nights in Japan. The best hotel we stayed in, first class service all the way. The staffs are friendly and helpful. The room are huge and comfy with a view of Daiba city and the Rainbow bridge. Very convenient location, close to outlets, train station, shopping center, Game Center for kids, easy access to a huge range food courts and restaurants in the area.

Nice and spacious room with great view on the high floor. Service is fantastic and expect high price at this hotel. Moving about is convenience as the metro station is just a short walk away.Only one negative feedback, should you need the power point to charge your devices, they are not conveniently located.

Daiba Station right in front of the hotel. The moment we stepped in, we were warmly greeted by the staff and direct us to the reception for check-in.The room is comfortable for 3 of us. The toilet is big, clean with a tub where I soak myself with sea-salt provided and a stand shower.The location is good, the promenade is just a few steps away. There are a man-made beach, the popular Rainbow Bridge, a replica Statue of Liberty. Getting over to other parts of Tokyo is not a hassle, via train to Shimbashi.The hotel provides courier services, and the limousine airport bus. We took the airport bus, arrive in about half an hour. It is very convenient.The only con, we stayed at mid floor, the hotel is blocked by Hilton Hotel & we could not really have a full view of the Bay.Highly recommend.

The over the top expensive restaurants is the only reason we didn't rate this a 5. Our room was very clean and every bit what we expected. Everyone working at the hotel was helpful. The mass transit stations within a short walk made the fact the hotel is not in the middle of the tourist areas no big deal. The Tokyo system is so efficient location didn't matter. Excellent views of Tokyo made it nice too. Ate at a closed in mall within walking distance after stick shock at the restaurants.

this is a first rate hotel.. we stayed for 2 nights in this place.. as part of the Tour Package. the room is well setup .. bigger than the average size hotel rooms in Japan. The lifts are super quiet.. There is a smoking room on the ground floor so you don't have to go outside (might be cold Season).. to smoke. Staff is very friendly.. one good thing is the Daiba Station (mono rail) is only 200 metres from the hotel .. very convenient. Breakfast can be done on the 1st or 30th Floor .. We prefer the 30th floor cos you have a nice view of the city while having your breakfast.. I plan to come back to this hotel for my next trip

This hotel in Odaiba offers great view on the bay and Tokyo skyline.The location is far away from the Tokyo cultural and life centers. On the other side it's close to the sand beach and well connected with metro.

My wife and I stayed here for 3 nights as part of a tour, lovely location overlooking rainbow bridge, large comfortable room with complimentary tea, coffee and water. Ideal for exploring Tokyo using the driverless shuttle train, station just outside. Plenty of shops and restaurants within 5 min walk also lovely views of Tokyo across the water. An enjoyable stay.

Generally if you are on your first business trip it is probably ok. If on vacation and need to be in this area then it is probably convenient. However if you travel often then you may be disappointed - from front desk service to the stripped clean mini bar you are not made to feel like this is something special. The rooms are old and tired reminding you of a 5 star china hotel in mid 1990's. Breakfast is a Buffett style and there are several options, but after three days you realize it is the same everywhere. No points, average service. Meh. While they Make effort compared to other hotels in Japan and Asia this misses the mark.

We stayed for four nights after a cruise and loved this hotel. It is located right next to the monorail for easy access to downtown Tokyo. It is also next to a large mall with many restaurants.The staff here could not be more gracious and helpful. The beds are very comfortable and the rooms are clean and a good size. Our view was spectacular. We overlooked the river with Tokyo in the background. Overall we would highly recommend this as a plave to stay when visiting Tokyo.

Stayed there for 3 nights. First impressions are good as the hotel is very big clean and located on Faida island with nice views of the sea, Location wise it is a bit out of central Tokyo as you need to use an extra train (Yurikamome line) to get there which adds 20 mins to your journey but on the positives, its quiet with really nice sea views, A positive is also that the hotel is connected to the train station which means you don't have extra walking to do and is also close to a big shopping mall.Our check in was fine though with limited English from the reception staff but efficient. On the positives the room is spacious (for Tokyo) and so is the bathroom with nice views. I recommend the breakfast on the 30th floor as it has a good variety of food even for westerners which is something hard to get in Japanese hotels. Wifi was also strongAll in all a good spacious hotel with good value for money which I would recommend,

Me and my family went to Tokyo for the Easter Holiday. Because we took an afternoon flight and arrived late at Haneda Airport, we decided to stay at Daiba for two nights before going to Tokyo Disneyland. We compared the two well-known hotels in Daiba and found Grand Nikko offered a better rate for late check-in guests which fitted our schedule. When we arrived at the Haneda Airport, it was already passed 11pm. So we took a taxi from the airport straight to the Hotel. It was a short journey and only took about 15 minutes but costed about Yen 5000. Anyway, it was pretty convenient and fast by taxi. The hotel is pretty grand and the front desk staff was polite but not warm. There was no one at the front door to help us with the luggage. Still there was no line at all at the check-in. So we could get our room key pretty soon. The room is spacious, clean and nice. We could overlooked the Daiba area but not much of the view, because we did not pay for a room with view. So it was understandable. The house cleaning did a good job to clean room pretty well every day. One good thing about the hotel is that it is connected to the Mono Rail station (Yurikamome). It is just about 2 minutes walk from the hotel lobby to the Mono Rail station and the Mono Rail can take you around the Daiba area or connect you to other Tokyo subway. So the location is very convenient. It takes only about 30 minutes from Daiba to Shinjuku or 10 minutes from Daiba to Tsukiji (the fish market). I gave the hotel four stars instead of 5 because I couldn't feel any warm greeting from the front desk or bell captain. Otherwise, it would have been a star review.

What a spectacular building. It was truly posh...but the moment we stepped out after a long journey from Odawara we were miffed with the staff. None of the hotel staffers offered to help us cart the baggage to the room. We were a bunch of senior citizens, we asked if we could use their luggage carts and return them to the hotel lobby but we were denied access...all because we were a group. I have never been more agitated in my life..we had to make several trips to help each other move baggage... and all the hotel staffers did was to avert looking at our helplessness. Shame!That said...the breakfast on the 30th floor with the panorama view of Tokyo was simply stunning. The choice from the buffet spread was amazing. Loved the shopping and eating plazas walking distance from the hotel.. very convenient. Would I stay in the hotel again.. most certainly yes.. but not as part of a group.

We stayed for 5 nights with two separate rooms. The rooms consider big size in Japanese hotel standard. The location was fantastic, it was literally only 2 minutes away from the train station and they even have 24 hours minimart if you want to grab snacks. It is part of one huge complex in Odaiba and walking distance to famous malls and tv station in Odaiba. For the breakfast, there were 2 options, breakfast buffet or fix traditional Japanese breakfast. I think they need to work on the menu for the buffet for more options. As for the hotel service, it was quite efficient and something that you expect from Japanese efficiency. One thing that is quite disappointing it was the lack of English speaking staff. Considering this is a 5 stars hotel, I was disappointed. When I asked about the hotel membership card, there was this male Japanese staff at the concierge desk who cannot provide the explanation in English. In the end, I was confused and decided not to bother him. So overall conclusion as follows: 1. Location: great2. Rooms: spacious 3. Breakfast: Japanese was great - buffet need to be improve4. Staff service: good but suggested to have extensive English course, especially for those who works on front office and concierge.

he hotels is perfect for every things , location as it is far from the heart of Tokyo but the neighborhood is very nice and many tourist attractions within walking distance , the room size after one night in very tiny room in other hotels was very good i can tell is big rooms enough fro family with 4 persons, the bathroom are big with shower box and bath tub the supplements of the bathroom are exceed mu expectations with shiseido brand products and all what need are there.The view was not on the rainbow bridge in the other side but really it is very nice view also. the airport bus stop right front of the hotel and also buses take you to shiagawa train station, there are free shuttle to Disney resorts we use it in the return but as we are not early person so 10:00 am was the last morning bus. Ever thing in this hotel are excellent.it is not near every attraction ion Tokyo little far from the heart of Tokyo but the best for family.

Booked for two nights in this hotel and we loved it. Very good place to stay and so relaxing very posh. Would like to come back again in this hotel❤️There is also a coach bus going to Narita airport which coat ¥2,800 per pax. Easy access to central Tokyo walking distance to train station and lots of route to choose from.Room:very spacious nice and clean with free toiletries all Shisiedo products i love the smell of their body wash so refreshing. Linens are nice and clean aa well big flat tv screen and we are very lucky to have a nice view in higher floor.

all hotel restaurants close at 9 pm , if you feel hungry only room service until 1 am or you eat yourself.even no snacks or chocolate in the mini bar. it's completely empty.AVOID THIS HOTEL PLEASE, IF YOU ARE PLANNING TO TOKYO

My wife and I spent three nights at this hotel on the third leg of a coach tour. Check in was very slick and our first impression of our room was very favourable. It was well equipped and sparklingly clean. The room was very spacious with two queen sized beds. There were two arm chairs with a table so we could sit and relax in comfort. Mattresses were comfortably firm and the choice of pillows was helpful for those who prefer different levels of head support. There was little noise from the traffic during the night. There was no transmission of sound from above or from neighbouring rooms, neither was any sound heard from the corridor. Helpfully, the room had a fridge and a kettle (although we have never encountered one which took so long to boil). There were complimentary bottles of drinking water and a range of hot drink options was available. Bathroom facilities comprised a half sized bath with a reasonably powerful shower. The hotel provided hair and tooth brushes and shaving razors.Breakfast was served from 6.30 am on the 30th floor. Queues formed before this time and once vouchers had been surrendered, we were escorted to a free table. This was a rather ponderous process which caused some of our party considerable delay. There was a varied selection of cooked offerings although they were rather bland. Fresh fruit and pastries were plentiful. There was a huge variety of Japanese style food although we didn’t try these. Everything was replenished promptly when things ran low. Wait staff cleared tables promptly - everything was done in a formal and polite manner.The hotel is easily reached by the highly efficient railway system. It is surrounded by 4 shopping malls which offered an enormous range of eating options.

Grand Nikko has two great advantages : Access straight to the lobby from the airport & Shinagawa station via the rainbow express right outside the station & crazy good views of the Odaiba bridge. The hotel is also ringside to a couple of malls, the walk on the beach and for us notably the Miraiken Musuem of technology and innovation. The rooms are spacious and clean. Service is great though the check-in/check-out maybe slow. It's also important to ask about views from your floor because you may miss the bridge view in some rooms and certainly from the lower floors (17 and below).
user_name:
Ayesha H
Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, India

review_body: This hotel is excellent. The rooms are spacious and very well appointed. The beds are large and comfortable with fantastic pillows. The hotel is ideally located within a few minutes walk from the "Aqua City" and "Diver City" Plaza's. There is a local elevated light rail station just outside the hotel that gets you to the Shinagawa station and from there the Tokyo Metro to any station in Tokyo.A hint when using the Tokyo rail system, ensure you know which line you have tickets for. Most auto ticket machines will give you and English version text.Staff at the hotel where friendly and always up for a chat. Great local area advise from the concierge.Just be aware that breakfast at the main restaurant is always crowded and you may find yourself waiting for a table.

We stayed here because of the bigger, more spacious room and it did not disappoint. We had three beds and it had plenty of room to walk around. The bathroom was big and it had separate shower and very roomy bathtub. The front desk was kind and helpful as I could not locate my bullet train ticket but they were able to locate them for me. Since the hotel is little bit further out, it take an extra 15 mins or so using going from Daiba station into heart of Tokyo. Daiba station is right in front of the hotel so we used that a lot more than other station which is 5-10 mins away on foot.Overall, we love hotel and the people. Also free water, coffee, and tea.....other hotels we visited did not offer those.

Rooms are big. Right on the elevated train line that quickly connects to subway. Solid American and Japanese breakfast buffet to start your day. Super quiet. Great views from the top. Several restaurants and shopping in the hotel and just outside the hotel. Service was perfect and staff friendly.

It was really wnderful stay. specially view from room was really amazing!!!!! i Tokyo tower and Sky tree both were in our hands.really enjoy view in evening and morning! also I enjoyed Gallery 21 and Fitness center as well. I really love pool area. it was perfect stay! next time i will stay again!!

our 1 st night we noticed MOLD in the bathroom and notify the management. it was cleaned but still had allergic reactions for remainder of our stay. They should have moved us to a new room!. We tried to be out of our room much as we could. Very dissapointed with the room.

Just loved our stay here, the rooms are spacious, spotless and the views are stunning. The staff are so helpful and pleasant. Location is spot on as the monorail is on the doorstep and runs frequently taking you over the Rainbow Bridge into Shimbashi, where you can change onto the rail network. If you do stay make sure you go up to the 30th floor for breakfast, where on a clear day you can see Mt Fuji. Overall a very enjoyable and beautiful hotel to stay in. P.s if you are fortunate enough to get on President level you can use the private lounge, the views from there in the evening are stunning

My fiancé and I had a great experience at this hotel. We stayed here for a couple nights at the tail end of our trip in Japan. The hotel is connected to Daiba Station, and very convenient to get to. The hotel is also connected to an upper level walking area which connects to the surrounding shopping areas, and you don't have to cross any streets.The staff was very responsive to all my emails before we even got to Japan. Upon checking in the bellman was nice enough explain all the features in our room. Our room was comfortable, very good size, clean and full of amenities. The lobby is beautiful and looks luxurious. Overall, is definitely come back to stay on our next trip. There aren't as many people around Odaiba, so you can walk around and not feel crowded or take a 20 min train ride to Shimbashi station and you're back in the middle of Tokyo.

We stayed at this hotel for the start of our first holiday to Japan and weren't disappointed. It is only 20 mins from Haneda airport by limousine bus and, in our opinion, ideally suited for transport links (boat, bus and rail) to central Tokyo and Disneyland. The view from our window overlooked the Rainbow Bridge and at night the scene was magical. We didn't eat at the hotel restaurant, as there are at least 4 malls nearby with lots of different food options, but breakfast was superb - great quality and lots of it. It does get busy on the 30th floor breakfast restaurant, so get there at 6.20 for when it opens 10mins later. Everyone at the hotel couldn't be more helpful, which sums up the Japanese.

Great Hotel. Nice large rooms and bathroom. Pleasant really all over. Comfy bed! Nice breakfast on top floor but somehow too busy at certain times so there is a waiting time. Great time as well but doesn't open till 9.00 or so. Too late for working people.

We stayed here as a family of four, the room was spacious we had one bed for each person. From the airport just take the airport limousine bus, but be wary last bus for this hotel leaves at 6:40pm our flight was delayed so we missed it, we had to take the bus to metro station then taxi to the hotel, the airport limousine staff will help you with this. This hotel is walking distance to shopping malls Aqua city and Diver city Venus Lego land etc..plenty of food and shopping to choose from. Gundam giant statue is not on display. Train is also just in front of the hotel, it rained all days on our visit 0 to 4 degree windy and cold, we didnt get to travel on train,we only had sun on our last day. Overall staff in the hotel were great and helpful room was clean, bathroom is bigger the most hotels. Would love to stay in this hotel on our next visit to japan.

We stayed in this hotel and while location, amenities and overall conditions are good, this property has an issue with capacity for breakfast at their 3 breakfast-enabled restaurants. Every morning there has been a humongous queue and a waiting time in excess of 30 minutes at 7 am, 8 am and 8:30 am, which can be disappointing and frustrating if you are on a schedule. The management really needs to calculate the space and capacity better or start a booking system but this whole thing really leaves a bitter taste, especially having never experienced anything like this ever before.

Stayed here for two nights in March 2017 with one other family member. Had a room with two twin (double?) beds. I don't think we paid for a nice view but got one anyways. At check-in they noticed we were celebrating a birthday and gave us a nice present. The room size is very generous when compared to the rest of Tokyo. I spent hours comparing room sizes and this hotel has about double the square meters of floor room when compared to other hotels. Found a very good price on booking dot com. Only 20-30 bucks more a night to stay here versus a business type hotel with small rooms. Didn't try the breakfast, so cant rate it. I heard many staff members speak English, so don't think that's a problem. Only negatives (which could be seen as normal/acceptable by others), were the amount of staff. Huge number of staff always in the lobby. Kinda feels weird with many eyes watching you as you walk in and out. However, they are there to help you if needed. Other negative, they help you with your luggage, and escort you to your room. This seemed to be the case with everyone. They take your luggage and give you a luggage tag, which I assumed meant that I would get it after check-in to take to my room. Nope. It was all loaded on a cart with someone ready to take me to my room. Great person, no complaints. Just an awkward what seemed like waiting for a tip at the end. Maybe they are used to getting tips from foreign guests, but having lived in Japan for many years I have never ever tipped for anything. It is custom to never tip, don't feel bad about it....maybe some of there staff is used to getting tips.

I stayed at this hotel which was not of my choosing as I primarily went here to attend a conference, so I wouldn't know how much the room rate was.In any case, this place would be suitable for those who are used to standard-sized western hotel rooms. As you may know, Japanese hotel rooms can be quite cramped but Grand Nikko's are comparable to international hotel chain rooms.
