Got a great deal on this hotel and was very impressed. Spacious rooms, attentive staff and a superb location for tourists. Easy access to many top sights and superb views from the bar at the top of the hotel.

As a returning guest off this hotel it is always bringing smiles when entering te lobby,The well motivated staff are very helpfull and welcoming. The check in procedure is one off the fastest when I compare my experiences wit oter hotels.Although many guests of this hotel are tourists whom are joining tours, as for business stays it has all you need to be able to work and leisure at the Hotel. Complimentery Internet of good quality. The roomSpacious and clean with great views from the higher floors on any side of the building.The bathroom is clean and well equiped in case one forgets an essential.Soap, Conditioner and shampoo are now offered in dispensers which does help the environment.TIP: For those having allergies from perfumed soap, Bring a neutral soap with you. The beds are very comfortable and the climate in the room is reacting well to your personal wishes.BreakfastAs this hotel's guests contain a lot of tourist groups it means that at certain times the restaurants serving breakfast can be very busy.This is very much the case Star Road which is on the 30t floor and offrs besides a wide variety of breakfast products also a great view. (On bright days mount Fuji is well visible). So come early or try to get advise on te best breakfast times from the front desk. The food served in Star Road and Le Bouquet (2nd floor) is of high quality and tastefull with a lot of choise.The restaurants in the Hotel offering great a great location for meeting up wit business associates. Tepan Yaki on te top floor offers a great view over the Rainbow Bridge and the colorfull lighted Tokyo Tower. While enjoying high quality and tastefull food prepared on the spot.Sushi at the second floor offers great service, great food presentation and one can taste the food has been prepared with great care. In the direct surroundings of the Hotel you'll find shopping malls fitted with fast food restaurants and luxury restaurants also.A metro station is in the direct vicinity offering oppertunitys to visit town.And one will also find a convenient store between the Metro station and the Hotel entrance.In total a great place to stay with a lot to offer.

This hotel is conveniently located 1 minute away from the subway and 30 minutes from Tokyo. Upon arriving you will notice a grand entrance, with a beautiful wedding ceremony area as soon as you walk in. The rooms are spacious, clean, and comfortable, overlooking the city skyline, bridge and bay below. Staff service is on par with most hotels in the Tokyo area. The only small complaint I had was the lack of continental breakfast, but that is excepted since the room we stayed in was a steal of a deal. Highly recommend this to families with kids, couples, or anyone for that matter. Would like to stay here again soon.

My family LOVE this hotel so much.Nice luxury lobby with a huge Christmas tree was my first impression to this hotel. (First time I visited during Christmas time) My little daughter was so happy when her first time visiting, and called this hotel "Disney hotel" because it's Disney shuttle bus services.-->So convenient for parents! (Reservation is a must for the Disney shuttle service) I stayed in this hotel more than 3 times. Airport Limousine Bus directly from/to Narita Airport, no stress & EASY!!! Rooms were large with different views.Location was not too perfect, it's a little too far from the downtown Tokyo, however, it's 1 min walk to the subway station; and there is so many malls just next to the hotel.(but sadly they mostly open late and close early! ><) You can easily walk to the Odaiba Pier Station and take the water bus to Asakusa-Odaiba direct line to Asakusa. Generally, I would def. come back if I visit Tokyo again. I will recommend if you like big room space, you travelling with kids, it's good place to stay! BTW, if you shopping too much. They even sell the packing boxes and help you to pack the stuffs. :)

The hotel is conveniently located near the shopping and restaurants. The train station is between this hotel and the Hilton. ( When we caught the train, we made the mistake of hopping off at the Odaiba Kaihinken Station instead of the Daiba Station.) Some of the rooms are discounted because the Hilton blocks off a complete view of the Rainbow Bridge. That is not a big deal. One can go anywhere else to see the entire Rainbow Bridge. A partial view is fine. The rooms have a nice view of the water and nearby shopping malls. The room is small but it's always kept clean. It looked like our sheets were changed daily, like they were ironed with no wrinkles. Guests were provided with two bottles of water daily. The shampoo, conditioner and body wash are Pola. Facial soap is Shiseido. We did not take the breakfast plan because we wanted to try different places. That was a big mistake. The shopping areas and almost all restaurants open at 11:00 and by that time,we are ready for lunch, not breakfast. There's a McD's walking distance from the hotel, downstairs, street level. That place opens early. Bill's opens for breakfast at 9:00. There's a convenience store right alongside the hotel. If you want a lighter fare, there are lots of bentos that the store clerk will nuke for you. The place also sells hot and cold drinks---coffee, tea, cocoa, juices that are carbonated.Other than those places, it's hard to find a simple breakfast before 11:00. We ended up having breakfast at the hotel at around $60 for two people. The buffet is good but pricey. The service at this hotel is great. We made arrangements for the bus to pick us up on the last day. The bellhop took care of taking our luggage to a waiting area, then when our bus arrived, someone hollered our destination's name. The bellhop loaded our bags onto the bus.

This Hotel is a little bit outside Tokyo, but very close to Tokyo Disney, specially if you have kids, this is the place. Grate rates and good size rooms, and amazing city views, even more beautyful at nigth. The staff is extremelly friendly. I really will recomend this place, my wife and I want to comeback soon.

A very smart and comfortable hotel that is a little distance away from the centre but not too far. The Daiba station on the private rail line Yurikamome (Japan Rail Pass cannot be used on it) is right outside the hotel and the journey into the centre – one change – is very interesting and scenic; it reminded me at times of the movie Metropolis. The limousine bus from the airport stops at the hotel and that makes the transfer much easier and quicker than using the metro. The restaurants and the food were good and the staff very friendly and helpful. Expensive, but not overly so, I thought it an excellent hotel.

Slick modern hotel well located for easy access by monorail link to city.Located on an artificial island with shopping centres and lots of restaurants close by within walking distance.Friendly staff and well appointed rooms

Stayed for two nights on a business trip. Usually I stay in the Intercontinental The Strings, but this time my PA booked me here.LOCATION: The hotel is on the artificial island Daiba, across the Nikko Hotel. Next door are two small malls, one with a cineplex. Subway stops right in front. Nice views to Tokyo Harbour Front skyline.ROOM: Small as usual in Tokyo, mid-range furniture and equipment, no minibar. Small but clean. Bathroom OK, but I personally don't like to take my shower standing in the bathtub with an ugly shower curtain.FOOD: There are three places to have breakfast (2nd, 3rd, 30th floor). I had traditional Japanese breakfast on 3rd floor, which was absolutely excellent. I had breakfast (buffet, mostly Western) on 2nd floor which was rather disappointing because of small variety.GYM: On 3rd floor, smallish but sufficient.STAFF: As to be expected in Japan very polite and professional.SUMMARY:Not of highest standard, but good enough.

I recently stayed at this hotel on business for two weeks. Whilst it's ok, it certainly isn't great. It is in dire need of a very deep clean. The carpet in my room, and under the bed, was particularly bad. The bathroom was fine and on the whole the room wasn't terrible. But two weeks felt like a very long time. In room wifi was ok, difficult to Skype or FaceTime though. General web browsing and emails were ok. If you're lucky enough to have a city facing room the view is spectacular, for this reason alone I'm giving the hotel 3 stars. The 30th floor breakfast area is great. On the whole this hotel is ok, but I would personally stay closer to central parts of Tokyo.

We spent 3 days at le Daiba Grand Pacific where we were having a business seminar. The hotel is very well located, with an amazing view on Tokyo's skyline. Rooms are quite large, clean and comfortable. The only small inconvenient I would see is that there is no cash machine for International Cards in the lobby, which may create some issues.

My first three nights in Tokyo before our tour were at this beautiful hotel. The decor was clean and very updated as were the guest rooms. The amenities in the rooms were more than numerous. The Staff was very professional, friendly and personable. They were extremely easy to communicate with even though they were Japanese and we were Americans. They actually recognized me and acknowledged me each time they saw me. The Concierge service was amazing. Highly recommend this hotel if staying in this area of Tokyo.

Planning a proposal?this has got to be the place.The hotel service is needless to say is good.View is wonderful,u can practically see the entire odaiba. Opt for the sea side view and u can see the rainbow bridge all night long.This is a pre honeymoon trip planned by my fiance and I'm really impressed by it, take a stroll by the beachside nearby and watch the sunset.it really brings you the romantic mood.

It was a beautiful modern hotel located in the centre of Odaiba and right in front of Yurikamome monorail station. Really good access to the shops and restaurants. You can book a limousine bus to Narita Airport. The view from our room was stunning.

This is a 5 star hotel on Daiba island.The lobby is magnificient. The rooms have a view of the harbor-pay for a room with a view, you will not regret this.The hotel staff deserves 5 stars. The are polite and will go beyond imagination to serve you.The restaurants are reasonable. The breakfast buffet is worth the price. For dinning in the area, you have Aqua City Mall with great restaurants with views and the food is reasonable priced.The location is central with the Yurikamome Line to Shiodome for the Oedo line or Shimbashi for the Ginza line. Would recommend a Pasmo card which can be refilled at the machines for ease of travel.Daiba island is far from Narita airport, a taxi would charge $150-170 US. Arrange for transportation by bus $28 US to the hotel. The buses stop running at 6:30pm therefore if arriving late call the hotel to arrange transportation.Consider a day trip to Kyoto. You can connect to Shinagawa to take the bullet train for Yen 1300. In kyoto buy a day pass on the buses for Y250 and you can see all the sites. Have a great trip.

We were very impressed with this hotel for various reasons. First of all it was situated in an ideal area of Tokyo, near the monorail, and also had easy access to many restaurants. Our room had a great view of the bay and was a good size for a three night stay.Staff were excellent and it would be unfair to find fault with any of the facilities.Whether on organised tours or do it yourself trips, the location is good.The one criticism would be that to use the swimming pool there is charge, which I have not encountered in other hotels.

This is a wonderful hotel full of welcoming surprises. When heard rumors that the hotel rooms were small in Tokyo, but this place was not the expectation. The rooms were large, the King Size bed was the size of 2 queen beds put together, everything about the place was a positive. The convenience of a station right on property, the shopping, entertainment complexes in walking distance and the parks in the area made our stay oh so nice! Highly recommended.

What I remember from the hotel which we stayed for 3 days, is the bowing of the staff each morning to greet us. What a wonderful staff. We had 2 rooms that were connected with great view of Tokyo bay. We were on the 20th floor and we felt the 5.4 earthquake. Nothing happened. We also came one day after Typhoon Etau. This was a typical September in Japan. One thing to pay attention for is: You have to pay and extra 7 USD per day per person for the Yurikamom subway line to get to shimbashi station in the center of Tokyo. This is a separate line and you have to pay separately. Consider this part of the price of the hotel. You can't get this low price in the center of Tokyo. The tennis players also stayed in the hotel and I knew some of them (WTA). There is a great place to eat "Aqua-Mall" which is connected to the hotel. The aqua mall closes at 23:00, so eat before that time. Also there is a small market at the hotel entrance which is very convenient. In addition there are 2 breakfast places also at the hotel entrance. I recommend this hotel to everyone. The only thing is that they charge for pool, but WiFi is free.

I stayed in this hotel before departing on a bus tour of Japan. This was the perfect start to our holiday. The rooms were a fantastic size. We had a great view from our room.We had the breakfast every morning and love it, great way to start the day. We made sure to eat in both breakfast rooms. The top floor room had great views but was very busy. Glad we did it once but were happy to eat in the ground floor room as the food was great in both. The staff were really nice.The location was great, Like most people say there are malls very close buy which was great for us. We did stay in another hotel in the heart of Tokyo after our bus tour finished but it was small, thats why when we return to Tokyo in 5 weeks we will be staying here again. Was one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in.

We spent 3 nights here for sight-seeing during our business trip. The service from all staffs were first-rate and our room was fresh, spacious and elegant. We had a double room on the 21nd floor with a view of the Rainbow Bridge, Downtown Tokyo, and all the attractions of the Adaiba entertainment district. The bed was huge - two queen beds pushed side-by-side together. The breakfast buffet was one of the best we ever have experienced. If we have another chance, we will stay here again.

I have stayed at this hotel several times and I like it. It's a fantastic luxury hotel with spacious clean rooms and great view of Tokyo Bay in Odaiba. The hotel is connected with Daiba station via a covered walkway to the front of the hotel. The rooms are very large and comfortable with comfy beds and wonderful bathrooms. The staff are very informative and helpful. There are many shopping centre near the hotel, such as Aqua City, Decks Tokyo Beach, and Divercity Mall. Odaiba is a little bit far from the centers of Tokyo: @20 min from Shimbashi by Yurikamome, thus @30 min from Tokyo and @40-45 min from Shinjuku or Shibuya. Therefore, this hotel is not good for those who wants to stay close to those centers. But, if you don't mind that and rather wants to stay in a spacious room in a quite relaxing atmosphere and surroundings, at very reasonable price, this is the place to stay.

We strayed in this hotel for 4 days. The hotel was spotless clean. The staff was very polite and professional. Odaiba area has excellent shops, restaurants and nice walk paths along the water. The night time entire place was full of lights and certainly helped our mood to feel happy and contended. The transport to hotel is excellent as well... The best of it the view from the room across Tokyo bay was stunning. I would recommend this hotel to all middle age people who seek the comfort at an affordable price....

The Hotel is located in Daiba area close to two big malls Aqua city which is having 4 levels of Food courts and Diver city Mall with international brands and close to the Daiba park and Rainbow bridge. The Hotel is well connected by Monorail (Daiba Station) which is very close to the hotel and Shuttle buses. As travelling by taxi is very expensive public transport is essential. They serve breakfast in three restaurants and you can have the breakfast in any one and you can also use the breakfast coupon for lunch also. They provide quality wifi in the rooms as well as in the lobby. The rooms are clean and the toilet is neat and filled with lot of toileteries. Staffs are very friendly.

I brought my wife and 1-year-old girl to this hotel on vacation. The hotel workers were friendly and considerate and made us feel comfortable and joyful.The room we booked was facing rainbow bridge, tokyo tower and Aquacity the mall. Although the view was partially blocked by Hotel Nikkotokyo, we thought the view was awesome. They also provided bed-guard and clean set for the baby. How sweet! The location was perfect for tourists visiting Odaiba, just next to tram station and 24-hr convenient store, shopping malls and restaurants were around the corner. There was also shuttle bus to Disneyland as a good neighbor hotel. The breakfast was amazing in the Star Road at 30th floor, great view and tasty food.We really loved the convenience and amenities experienced here and wish staying in a higher floor next time.

We booked this hotel on a super special internet price (superior twin) despite being a little concerned about it's location. The hotel was very easy to get to on the Daiba JR line having arrived in Tokyo on the Shinkansen. The Daiba station is connected to the hotel via a covered walkway to the front of the hotel (very easy!) The hotel itself is fantastic; Very opulent with welcoming staff and very easy check-in and check out. The staff are very informative and helpful and nothing was too much trouble! The hotel rooms are fabulous; very large, extremely comfortable and with first class bedding. The bathrooms are enormous! with nothing left wanting when it comes to consumables, (shampoos, hand-creams etc.). The view from our room was quite beautiful as it overlooked the bridge. Can't comment on breakfast as we did not eat in the hotel. There are plenty of shopping centre restaurants within an easy walk (but the shops don't open until 11.00am). We made use of these for dinner at night. The area itself is mostly commercial with a good number of department stores within easy access of the hotel. There is an "outlet" shopping centre close to the hotel. (We did not walk to the department stores but chose to take the free shuttle bus from the hotel.) All very easy. The shuttle bus also travels to Disneyland but we did not use this. We chose to travel by train to more "authentic" tourist areas for sightseeing which was extremely easy as the JR station is so close. All in all this is a very beautiful hotel and I'm sure had it been in a more "touristy" location it would have been three times the price. Now that I know how easy it is to use the JR system from the hotel I have no hesitation in recommending it despite it's location.

Nice enough hotel but they kept hitting us for hidden charges. The price of the breakfast in the info in the room doubled by the time you arrived at the restaurant. You had to pay to use the gym and leisure facilities. The location is also annoying, to go see the sights it takes a train just to get to the metro. Daiba is a nice enough area but either a ghost town during the week or a mad house on weekends.Otherwise fairly standard hotel, the key cards took a heck of a battle to open the door. We were there during a tropical storm, my mother is 73 and the water and marble meant it is not the best place for older people.The only good thing was the free wifi, that was a good quality and the staff, but I failed to meet a rude or unhelpful person in the whole of Japan so hardly anything unique.

This is the hotel to choose for luxury at a reasonable cost. It has around 30 floors and most with stunning views of the Rainbow Bridge which is floodlit at night. There are numerous restaurants close by catering for all levels of cost. The hotel has it's own exit to the monorail which provides easy access to the centre of Tokyo. We stayed for 3 nights which is really the minimum to explore Tokyo and the surrounding area as far as Mt Fuji.

The facilities and location could not be faulted. There was a good selection of restaurants in the building and several more within a few hundred yards - I have mobility restrictions! Bar and restaurant on the 30th floor offered amazing panoramic views of Tokyo and the Rainbow Bridge. Overground station was just next to the hotel and staff were very helpful in pointing out which trains and buses to take.

Stayed in this hotel, group booking with Imagine Cruises,25-28 August 2015. Located in room 1844 with views to rear of hotel. Very comfortable rooms to a very good standard, plenty of space, large bathroom with Japanese style toilet!!!! very clean room and serviced every day extra coffee makings on request. Hotel staff extremely helpful especially the Chief Concierge Philippe Muller who advised on train directions to down town Tokyo, he was very helpful and friendly.. thanks again... We were made very welcome on our arrival booking in very slick and the farewell was a nice gesture too with "come back soon" Imagine cruises chose a very nice hotel and like all Japanese people very friendly and helpful. Recommended hotel for all...

We stayed at this hotel for three days in August. It really is a good quality hotel and well located in Tokyo. Near to the rainbow bridge and Tokyo beach it commands magnificent views. We were on the 16th floor overlooking a theme park and the bay, but on the other side the view is of the rainbow bridge and top half of the bay. It boasts several restaurants, which some of our party found to be good, though we didn't try any. Choosing instead to eat at the many local restaurants nearby. The hotel is well located for nearby restaurants which we found to be good and a bit cheaper than the hotel, also convenient for several shopping malls, maritime museum etc. The hotel is well appointed and the staff very polite and helpful. The room was worthy of 5 star status, with a well appointed bathroom,( Both bath and shower) and a state of the art toilet with heated seat and bidet facilities. But the best by far was the wonderful view overlooking the bay. The area around the hotel and bay comes alive at night with some of the trees in the bay park and the rainbow bridge illuminated, along with a puzzling replica statue of liberty. There is a Metro station just outside the hotel along with the shops and local restaurants nearby. Some of the restaurants are located in the malls, particularly Aqua City on the 5th and 6th floors and well worth a visit. Also nearby is a Starbucks coffee shop. There is a pleasant raised walkway adjoining the hotel which takes you near the top half of the bay and is enjoyable in the evening when the area is illuminated.

I must say that this hotel is very elegant and has all the perks of what a high class hotel should have. All employees were nice just like any high class hotels in Japan. The view is always nice no matter which direction you are facing. You'd probably prefer the view that's facing more toward the Rainbow bridge but I am not too sure if you can get a nice full view as there is Hotel Nikko right against this hotel. My view was facing the outer rim facing the ocean which was nothing special but saw the planes decreasing the altitude one after another. The room was cozy with pretty big bathtub to unwind after all the work or shopping you have done before the stay. TV was big and all amenities were pretty decent. The weird thing about this hotel is how the entrance is located if you take the Yurikamome Train. You will get off the train and squeeze yourself in to a small corridor which definitely seems to be the back entrance of the hotel. For a hotel like this, they should still have a better looking back entrance. Location wise though, this place is awesome if you want to explore everything in Odaiba. Most of the malls and attractions are within walking distance. One thing I like about Odaiba is the fact that they have a very very big Starbucks inside Aquacity if I remember correct. Coming from outside US and being tired of the crowded situation, this Starbucks is the place to chill.The mini Statue of Liberty is about 3 min walk, there is a famous Kua Aina Hamburger restaurant walks away as well. If you are thinking about using the pool here, they charge so just make sure you realize that before you go down with your swimsuit. Overall, nice hotel!

We stayed from August 29 until September 2 at the hotel. The service was just great. Staff is extremely friendly and as helpful as possible. The location is good, near a lot of restaurants and entertainment area, and good accessible to the city center. Hotel room was spacious and very comfortable.

Mega sized hotel located in new docklands district .. Not best location but near haneda (5500 yen in taxi). Not on metro or japan rail grid but light rail system joins with network. hotel lobby feels a little like a supermarket checkout area.. Huge number of people and lots of "information" posters.. Room is clean, comfortable and well appointed. Decent value for money.

We loved this hotel, the service was good. There are several shopping centers in Walking distance with nice restaurants. The cafe right outside the door became our breakfast place with their toast that suited my 12year old perfect.The beds were really comfortable and the room nice and big. I loved the closet.We are going back in February 2016 and have already made reservations here.

We stayed at this hotel twice in May and June. Over 9 nights and two stays we sampled 3 room types as we'd booked different rates online. If you can get a good rate the Presidents floor is great fun with free cocktail hour and use of the leisure facilities, and breakfast included, the bathroom is more upmarket too (Note the swimming pool is a paid for facility if you have a standard room) We also had a high floor twin overlooking the Rainbow bridge, which was a slightly bigger room than the high floor double. The Presidents Room was the smartest, the carpet in the double was a little shabby. Book well in advance for the best rates.The service was very good throughout and the hotel staff were able to accommodate all our requests. Email response in advance of our stay was always within 24 hours. We found the location very convenient, the rate we paid easily covered the monorail fare. There is plenty plenty of mall shopping and various dining options for all budgets when you want to avoid the crowds in town.

We are just about to check out of the hotel, our stay has been excellent. On arrival the staff quickly checked us in and our bags brought to the room. The bathroom had a fabulous array of goodies including Sheishedo soap.That evening we ate in the Chinese Restaurant and the food was amazing. The breakfast buffet was good and as we were jet lagged we were up early so no need to queue, the food selection was good and the scrambled eggs were amazing.The food buffet in the evening was great a good selection of food. The whiskey bar was fun as the staff made some great cocktails.At all times the staff were kind and respectful and nothing was too much trouble.I would definitely return to this hotel if we are ever in Tokyo again the Managers and staff should feel proud of the ambience they have created.

Our family of 4 stayed at the Grand Pacifica in August and it was packed with tourists so the staff were pretty inundated but did a good job of coping with the crowds. The hotel is a bit pricey for what it is and could be more of a 4.5 stars hotel rather than 5 as it lacked a few finer touches. Our room for 4 could have used a few extra square feet to make it just a little more spacious especially for larger families that usually carry a bit of extra luggage. We had a room with 4 small double beds. Overall, it was a pleasant hotel with nice staff and I wouldn't mind staying there again.Our room itself was nice especially the bathroom and the other amenities. The bathroom was quite large in comparison to the room itself. Loved the toilet seats in Japan. I had never used a bidet and after getting over the initial oddity of it, it was rather nice. Nothing like sitting on a warm seat in the middle of the night ! Because we were usually out during the day and evenings in town sightseeing, we never tried the hotel restaurants but looking at the menus, they seem rather pricey. The hotel was well set up for weddings and banquets and I suspect in Tokyo, it's pretty prestigious to hold your wedding and banquet at the Grand Pacifica. As you walk out towards the train station, there is a convenience store where we often bought breakfast foods, snacks and some souvenirs. There are also a lot of restaurants in the malls and they range in price and types of cuisine. Most of the food catered to the tourist market though so don't expect to find too much traditional everyday family style Japanese food.In terms of location, the good points are that it is close to several large shopping malls in Daiba. A couple of these malls were rather on the cheap end of the scale which was surprising to us. The stores sold mostly cheap merchandise and some oddities. I am talking about AquaCity and Decks. For a more conventional North American type mall and better merchandising, you need to go to Diver City. All the malls are within a short walking distance over the viaducts which you access directly from the hotel exits so very conveniently located in that sense. Also, all the malls have their food courts and restaurants. In AquaCity, there are several floors of more conventional restaurants whereas at Diver City, there is a fabulous open food court on the first floor.In terms of location relative to sightseeing around Tokyo however, we found with a family, it wasn't as convenient as we first thought. To get into the city centre where the attractions are, you need to take 2 separate train/subway systems with a substantial walk between the stations. This added a lot to the commuting time along with additional costs and at the end of some afternoons after a lot of walking and sightseeing already, if you go back to the hotel to rest up, you are less apt to go out again for the evening just because it is a bit too much. This is especially the case if you have been sightseeing for most of the day over several days and have young children. Add to this the heat on a hot July and August afternoon and well, you get the picture. It takes about 20-25 minutes to get to the Shimbashi station on the Tokyo metro system and from Shimbashi, you can get anywhere you need within Tokyo. You can also choose to go to the Toyosu station on the opposite side of the line but that is a longer commute but you do get to see the city a little more as it is an above ground rail system. If I were to stay in Tokyo again, I might try to find a hotel more centrally located next to any metro station in the heart of the city. One note in regards to the staff. I have to say a special thanks to Ms. Yamaguchi who looked after our luggage for us. As we were carrying a lot of luggage, we wanted to send a few of our suitcases ahead to our next destination rather than lugging them all onto the Shinkasen. Ms. Yamaguchi who was working at the luggage concierge desk was very helpful in getting things set up for us. Overall, I enjoyed our stay at the Grand Pacifica. The hotel is clean, well designed and the staff helpful. Rooms are nice and well kept with a very nice bathroom and high quality toiletries. My only issues were the extra commute to get into the city attractions but then again, the Daiba train station to get started on your trek is very conveniently located just outside the side doors of the hotel.One last note of caution though. For families traveling with young children, there are age restrictions for the swimming pool and my kids were very disappointed when we learned they could not use the pool.

You take a monorail to reach the hotel which is at the doorstep of the station. It is part of a larger complex and is located on reclaimed land near the bay. The area is less congested and yet just a short monorail ride away from the city centre. It is very easy to access - a shuttle service is available to Haneda at appointed times. Around the hotel there are new shopping malls and lots of eateries which are just a walk on an overhead bridge away. It is near the colourful rainbow bridge which is prettily lit up at night. The rooms are large and the beds are very comfortable. Service is excellent, after all it is a 5 star standard hotel. The rate is reasonable in the winter season but can go up 3 times more in the summer. Suburban shopping can be done further up the monorail line, opposite the direction of the city.

Stayed there for 5 nights. Rooms were big, bed was very comfortable. Hotel service was exceptional. We had a small issue with sending our luggage to the airport. They had 4 people working on this, discussing if and what could be done. That night, there was a letter in our room apologizing for not being able to help us and the options for us. Unbelievable. Many thanks to the Concierge, Mr. Essaid, and his staff. They were always very helpful. Best service we have ever had and we like to travel. Great location even though far from center of Tokyo. No problem since Tokyo train system is so good. The train station was literally right in front of the hotel entrance. Did I mention the great views from our room? Did I mention the 4 malls and other great things to do within walking distance from the hotel? Free shuttle service available if you don't like to walk. We did not eat at the hotel but ate at the nearby malls most of the time. This has become my favorite hotel in Tokyo and we will definitely be back.

The lobby was nice enough, though it was crowded with tourists in mid August. The room was clean and nice, fairly large bathroom with soaking tub and nice fluffy robes. The positives end there. The service was horrible. The staff unhelpful and rude. The food was mediocre at best for both the main dining room and room service. The hotel was undergoing construction so we were instructed to park in the hotel garage but at the far end from the entrance. Then we were told without any hesitation to take our luggage up to the room on our own without any help, while two of our three children, all under the age of 8, were fussing from being tired after the long travel! I have never experienced such poor service in any hotel and we've travelled quite a bit around the world.

Good points:Staff all very helpfulClose to public transport systemWe didn't get a view of the rainbow bridge - but view over other side of river was pleasant enoughroom size adequatevery clean bathroom - but with very annoying toilet that started flushing as soon as you sat on it which frightened our 4 year old and there was no way we could find of turning it off.Free shuttle bus to disney useful - but book in advance as we only had the choice of 1 shuttle there and 1 back as the others were fullThere is a small 24 hour convenience store close to hotel entranceNot so good:The capacity of restaurants is not large enough for the number of guests. One morning we had to go to a "banqueting room" as first restaurant we went to was full with a long queue. The banqueting room didn't have much character to it and people were eating off trays - in a 5* hotel I don't expect to be eating meals off a tray. And after a day at Disneyland we just wanted a simple supper and go to bed but the buffet-style restaurant was already full and so we couldn't eat there. The buffet breakfast in the Star Restaurant on 30th floor was better than in banqueting room on 29th floor - but neither were of the quality we'd have expected for 5*, and we'd have said more like 3 or 4*.Check in is 3pm, so if you arrive in Tokyo on a morning flight there's a long time to wait before you can check in (unless you pay extra for an early check-in). There are 2 shopping malls with food courts close by - on the day we arrived we went to the one on the left (Aqua I think it was called) and it was ok, but then next day went to the one on the right called something like Divers mall and restaurants in the one looked better.Tours from the hotel need to be booked well in advance - we'd wanted to do a day tour to Mt Fuji but both tours that collect from the hotel were already full when we tried to book on them the day before (we tried to book on the day we arrived in Tokyo but should have booked in advance)

We chose this hotel for our wedding anniversary. We arrived on aug 8, we were in luck because of the fireworks display overlooking tokyo bay. The view is spectacular from our room, i never anticipated that we will be overlooking the rainbow bridge and tokyo bay. The hotel is very near the daiba station so getting to places is not a drag. Though you have to have the subway map handy with you if you don't want to get lost. Their staffs are so helpful, i forgot to get their names though. Just ask and they will patiently answer your questions. Our room space was average in size, but complete with what we need. I can never complain because of the view. We got the bed and breakfast package for 4 days. Their breakfast buffet consists of the basics, bread and cereals, fruits and salads, bacon, ham and egg. Nothing special. We were expecting some sushi or sashimi but i think we have to go to restaurants nearby or at ginza. I would recommend this hotel for first time travellers. And we will go back during the cherry blossom season.

This was our first stop after an overnight flight into Narita airport. As we arrived early morning our room was not ready but staff held our luggage while we explored the local area. Check in was relatively easy, staff spoke enough English to make it a smooth process. The room itself was very spacious with plenty of room for our luggage, the bathroom was also an excellent size, and they are very generous with the toiletries. The beds were fairly firm (which I came to realise is normal in Japan!). We stayed in a room which had a view of the Rainbow Bridge- the view is awesome, even more so of an evening. We didn't eat at any of the hotels restaurant except for the buffet breakfast, which is the best one we came across through our 2 week stay in Japan-it has a great selection of western food.Located within the hotel was a souvenir/food store which was great for any last minute food items or drinks. Just outside the main entrance was a 24 hour convenience store which came in handy for some fresh fruit or noodle cups! Within walking distance are 3 large shopping centres, with plenty of eating out options and more than enough shopping to fill a couple of days! Probably the most convenient aspect was the Daiba Station which is pretty much a 30 m walk from the hotel entrance, it was very easy to navigate our way to Tokyo station from here.I would definitely stay here again- we actually cancelled a reservation in central Tokyo to come back here as our trip was coming to an end. Excellent facilities and very helpful staff.

I very much enjoyed my stay here for a period of 4 days. The service is great, food is pretty good and rooms are fantastic. All this comes at a very fair price indeed. A family a four staying in two separate rooms including breakfasts on all four days payed ¥177000. My complaints are mainly on the location, in the area of odaiba itself there is little to do and there are few worthwhile places to eat. The areas of Ginza, Chuo and Shibuya where a lot of the interesting things take place are frustratingly as long as an hour away via public transport. On the other hand the public transport is excellent in Tokyo and generally fairly cheap so the travel is bearable.My other complaints are much smaller. The hotel pool costs ¥3600 yen per PERSON to use which is a shame really as this is really too much and annoying in a world where I have come to expect pools included.The hotel is huge and crowded and this leads to some annoyance when there are longish queues for breakfast although these are rarely more than 10 minutes.This hotel provides NO SOYA MILK and for a lactose intolerant person like myself this is somewhat frustrating. I have generally come to expect it in most good hotels so this annoyed me a little and is a cheap and easy fix.Finally the rooms are strangely lacking in power sockets which comes at a minor inconvenience where I had to unplug lamps to charge my phone and iPad.

Stayed here for 4 nights prior to joining a Round Japan Cruise.Great Location in fact the exit from the Monorail exits direct more or less into the Hotel.The staff are so polite and really cannot do more for the customer, their customer service is second to none.Our room had everything you could ask for, very comfortable in all ways and quiet.We did not choose to eat in the Hotel instead there are masses of restaurants in the nearby shopping malls. There is fast food and also on a separate floor separate restaurants and bars covering all tastes.The area itself is very nice with a beach if required and pleasant walks down to the water. It is possible to go on the River and cruise up to central Tokyo or ride the Monorail to Shimbashi station and change for the metro. All very easy. A free shuttle bus circumvates the local area all around Tokyo Bay.

Stayed here for a couple of nights on the last leg of our Japan trip and we did an excellent choice! The hotel is located in Odaiba (quite new development in Tokyo, I believe) and its a 2 minute walk to Daiba station. We got a good rate cause we booked a month in advance. The rate includes free breakfast. Our room has nice view as it is on a high floor. The room is big for Japan standards. The bathroom has all the amenities that you need. I would stay here again.

I liked the location of this Hotel a lot. Few minuted from Tokyo station by Monorail, this Hotel offers peace and tranquility in a hectic city. At night the view of the Rainbow Bridge and the boats is stunning. Hotel room is big, great mattress, linens and towels. Bathroom offered an amazing view of the port.Service was also good.

About to leave this place for Mt. Fuji, I am contemplating my stay here...good enough for my not wanting to leave. Our beds are most comfortable, our room is spotless, the decor is restful, the furniture includes two armchairs, China cups are laid out on a tray ready for coffee or tea, and the infamous Japanese toilet with all the bells and whistles is installed for our sitting pleasure. The amenities include shower caps, toothbrushes and toothpaste, special natural fiber wash cloths to take, but no sewing kit. The view is wonderful. (I am on the 20th floor.) The yurikamome station stops at the hotel, a 24-hour convenience store is available, although without any medicines. And a large mall is nearby connected with bridges, escalators, and stairs which is where you get your medicines. Not all the staff knows English but will find someone for you who does. The 30th floor dining area includes a bar for night dining, drinking, and dreaming with the magnificent view, and one can even see nightly fireworks for a few minutes at about 8 PM. (Disney?) So what is important to you to book this hotel? Reading others' reviews, one needs to see if any of their complaints would at all affect you. If not, go for it. My booking came from a tour company so I was pleasantly surprised at what we got. Do try the Japanese set-breakfast on the 3rd floor. It is worth the experience. And do tour the grounds. You will find a replica of the Statue of Liberty...no plaques telling how it got there and why. One needs to do research, maybe just a googling.

We absolutely loved Tokyo and our stay at the Grand Pacific just topped it off. Let me begin by saying that when we check in to any hotel I perform a cursory cleanliness check complete with black light. Let me tell you this hotel was absolutely spotless. In all our travels we have never stayed at a hotel as brilliantly clean and well maintained as the Grand Pacific Le Daiba. There were several in house restaurants from which to choose and all were superb. Overall, we were treated like royalty. The Japanese people are warm and welcoming and the hotel staff represented the best of the best. I simply cannot recommend them highly enough.One final note, and this is an important one, the beds. Oh my, they were like sleeping on a cloud. The support was just right for each of us which is hard to grasp since we have different preferences in mattress firmness. They clearly did not scrimp on mattress quality. We had the best rest I can remember at any hotel.

A great hotel with excellent & helpful staff. Highly efficient check in and check out (less than 5 mins). Large comfortable family room that are reasonably priced. 3 adults and 2 kids in the room comfortably. Huge bathroom with bathtub and separate shower. Great and ample toiletries provided.Great surrounding area for shopping, fun and eating establishments. Easy access to everywhere.- The monorail stop is just outside the hotel which connected to Shinbashi subway or JR. - Direct limo bus to/from Narita or Haneda airport.- Free shuttle bus to Disneyland/Disneysea (advanced booking required)- Free shuttle bus within the odaiba city (to Tokyo Teleport Station)- Rainbow bus to Shinagawa station (to take shinkansen)Highly recommended!

We specifically booked this hotel so my daughter could continue with her swimming training whilst on holiday. We booked a club room PAYING EXTRA to use the facilities only to be told children are not allowed in the pool??? We were also advised children were not allowed in the club lounge after 6pm. When questioned the excruciatingly unhelpful manager advised us that there would be no refund as these facilities were complimentary with that room type. Well yes but you have to pay EXTRA for the room in order to get that! Nowhere on their website did it state that children were not allowed in the pool (only the fitness centre) or the club lounge, however the manager pointed out that it did say that in the Japanese version of their website (thank you for that helpful little nugget). When asked why I was not informed when I booked a club room with a child in the booking he replied with they don't provide information to people who don't book direct!!!! This is utter nonsense! They are given contact details in every booking made through Booking.com. Surely customer service is not too much to ask for in a hotel?? Well it is here! The response Booking.com received to our complaint was that we were lucky they "allowed" us to take something from the lounge to go and sit in our room. Wow. Thanks guys. We paid extra for that supposed club room for 3 nights and got to use the lounge for a whole 15 minutes...Buffet breakfast was disappointing to say the least. Every hot item there was stone cold and the freshly made omelettes were really runny.The location is quite far out from most places in fact we had to take 3 different types of trains just to get to a location for a tour pick-up.I would not recommend this hotel to anyone, least of all families.

Hotel location is nice as it is directly next to Daiba station. We got a good deal by booking more than 30 days in advance which gave access to club level. This includes rooms on 27th and 28th floor with a nice view, included breakfast and free access to the lounge, fitness club and swimming pool (which is normally not included, a bit funny for a 5 star hotel).Room was spacious (for Japan) and the bathroom was really great: marbled floor, walk in shower and a separate tub.Staff was very friendly and supportive: booked a restaurant via the concierge in advance and got super-fast responses in perfect English. Bell boy service was also great as they can even freeze your purchases of beef etc. before checking-out.Only point to improve are the elevators: they should declare one or two of them to 'express elevators' that will only serve communal floors and higher floors of guest rooms. Can take you up to 5min to reach lobby when going down from 30th floor after breakfast...

This hotel is very large and luxurious. The room is not spacious but good. Situated between 2 shopping mall. The view from my room is very nice. Unfortunately did not get to taste the breakfast because of early morning flight.

Stay in this hotel for 6 nights with 2 little children. We took Corner Suite Room: 1BR with living room with reasonable priceSo it comes with suite perks such as b/fast, all day club lounge benefits, private c/in-outRoom was very spacious almost 90sqm, not modern but clean and well maintained also equipped with OSIM massage chairHotel is big and many china tour group use this hotel so sometimes it's quite busy and crowded and noisyStaff was polite but not everybody can speak english so for those who can't they seems not very friendly but maybe it just because they can't interact properlyBut if we asked something they try as best as they can to understand and answer our question and fulfill our requestSome policy is not so flexible though like if we asked for more mineral water bottle they said only 2 bottle is free. We are suite room customers with club lounge access but still they said they can't give more than 2bottles/room event though we can go to lounge to drink as much as we want. It's quite strange. Not very good for their branding though.In other 5hotels that we use in Japan, only this hotel limit 2mineral bottle/room.Breakfast choice also limited and hotel facility is ok.Since its location in Odaiba, we rely on yurikamome or rinkai line or shuttle bus to Shinagawa to connect with Tokyo downtown / Tokyo mainland. It needs around 35-45min so it's a min point stay in OdaibaBut if you want to shopping / duty free, there are at least 4-5 next door mall linked with pedestrian to the hotel. So, it's very convenient for tourist.That's why mostly tourist stay in this area while local Japanese / office people seems to prefer stay in Tokyo land. All n all recommended decent hotel if you want to stay in Odaiba

Comfortable and clean rooms with comfy regular size beds which is a nice thing compared to a number of 4 star hotels in Tokyo.Location isn't great, accessible by 5 stations' train (monorail) ride from the main train / metro lines. There is a direct bus to from both Haneda and Narita airports - the two main airports of Tokyo - that stops at the hotel, which is a plus.Disappointing breakfast and dinner, overpriced average meal with limited choice.Beware of using swimming pool or even sun beds in this hotel.There is a hefty charge for using the facilities and the charges are outrageous.

I stayed 3 nights in June with my adult son,booked through Booking.com.We had a very large Club Deluxe Twin room for two nights (25,000 yen per night including breakfast) then a much smaller Superior twin room for one night( 24,000 yen,no breakfast but it was a Saturday and Saturdays are always more expensive).I can't normally afford club level at hotels but was lucky to get this excellent rate.Email communication prior to arrival was excellent.I arranged a 9am check in for an additional half the room night charge.We were given our room at 8am which was very appreciated after an overnight flight.The club lounge(complimentary evening drinks) is not large but has beautiful views towards the city and Tokyo Tower with the beautiful Rainbow Bridge.We went before sunset and stayed till the lights came on.There are multiple choices for the breakfast included with club rooms.We chose the buffet breakfast in the panoramic restaurant (? 30th floor).Other options were the same buffet minus the view,Japanese breakfast or room service breakfast.The buffet breakfast food was quite good.The capacity of the restaurant was large with no waiting(unlike Hotel Nikko).I like the location of Odaiba.It doesn't take long to get to Shimbashi(with onward connections elsewhere) on the monorail which I find fun.We arrived at 7am at Haneda and took a taxi for about 6000 yen.The hotel was let down by not so good service.No one helped us with our luggage when we arrived by taxi.We checked in at the lobby level and the gentleman was most reluctant to attempt English.I have also stayed at Hotel Nikko at Odaiba.Its service was far superior with very welcoming friendly staff.

A spectacular hotel just minutes from the Haneda Airport. Large comfortable rooms that are reasonably priced. The 30th floor restaurant has a spectacular view of the harbor and surrounding area - especially at night. A series of wide walkways lead to all of the surrounding shopping and eating establishments. The monorail stops outside the rear entrance and connects to the public train system for access to downtown Tokyo. You can catch the Airport Limousine Bus service from the main lobby to get to Narita Airport, which I had to do for my flight back to the USA. The food in all of the hotel's restaurants was better than expected. I highly recommend this hotel even if its just for a short stopover between flights into and out of Haneda airport.

We stayed here for 2 nights and have to say the facilities are excellent. Rooms even have heated toilets! The hotel is a short walk away from the La Daiba entertainment and shopping area and the transit system to get into Tokyo centre is just outside the hotel.Rooms are clean and comfortable with full facilities. Staff are helpful and courteous.

Comfortable, well-appointed, helpful staff, interesting location that was only *slightly* away from city center. I requested a firm mattress and upon check-in found that a bedboard had been very thoughtfully placed under my mattress, thus providing the comfortable night's sleep I was hoping for. Room was large and comfortable with a great view. A little pricey.

Excellent -- especially for international travelers. This hotel is upscale and spacious. About 20 minutes from Shimbashi station. Staff is very friendly and attentive. Many speak English. Rooms are well appointed. Amenities include sleepwear, tea/instant coffee, toiletries, and Shiseido face products, Beds are firm and comfortable. Views of the bay and Rainbow bridge. Aqua City and Diver City malls nearby (5-10 minute walk). Daiba station for the Yurikamome Line is 2 minutes from the lobby. (We tried to take the Yurikamome train as much as possible, but sometimes it was better to take the Rinkan train from the Tokyo Teleport station, which was about 10 minutes away.) Chose to stay here because of reasonable rates for a triple room. Easy access from Haneda and to/from Disneyland and other parts of the city. It takes a bit of time (~20 minutes) to get to Shimbashi to access other areas of Tokyo, but it was worth staying at such a luxurious hotel.About $50 USD taxi from Haneda (International Flight was delayed, so Haneda airport limousine bus was unavailable at the time we needed it).Tip: Tokyo Disneyland access from hotel with minimal walking: 1. Yurikamome Line: Daiba Station to Ariake station, then 2. Change to the Rinkai Line at Kokusaitenjijo Station (towards Shinkiba) to Shinkiba Station, then3. Change to the Keio Line (towards Kimtitsu) to the Maihama Station.4. Either walk to TD or take the monorail to TDSea.

We stayed here in June and found this a very comfortable hotel with all amenities required to make our stay well worth the stay. Our room we had ample room and view over the sea. The staff were exceptional in ensuring everything was up to high standard and made us very welcome. We did not always eat at the hotel but when we did found the food choices and quality very good. The train station a minute away also choice of three shopping malls only a short walk away. I would recommend this hotel be aware though it is probably 30mins by train to Tokyo city centre.

This hotel was so organised, clean and comfortable rooms. Everything was perfect in the bedrooms. Loved the choice for breakfast. Little difficult with language at times. Very convenient for the Monorail and lots to do nearby.

While visiting Tokyo, we found our stay at the Grand Pacific Le Daiba very pleasant. They excelled at customer service - our experiences at reception, check-in, concierge, bell captain desk, and restaurants were all very positive and exceeded our expectations.

We took the Narita airport bus to the hotel. The hotel is very grand and clean. We had a room with a beautiful harbor and city views. The train station is also close by. The room is very spacious and I especially like the large bathroom and shower. We took an early morning stroll in the Hama Rikyu Gardens and the surrounding area before the shops open. The hotel is not far from the Harumi Passenger Ship Terminal.

If you would like to stay in Daiba, or visit Disney but prefer staying close to shopping area, this hotel is one of your best choices. It's strongly recommend to check out its Japanese website for various staying plans if you could read Japanese, because you cannot find them in English or Chinese versions. There are plenty of packages including breakfast, dinner, tours, that could be combined with different room types and staying periods. You can even choose a cheap plan to check in late and check out early.The hotel provides free shuttle services to facilitate you wonder around the neighbourhood or to/from Disney land/see park. But you have to book the Disney neighbour bus in advance from its official website.As the other reviewer stated, the room was very clean and comfy and the services were with high standard. The only complaint I would say was the breakfast. There are three restaurants that you could choose for the breakfast: the one on the top floor with great views, the one in the lobby, and the Japanese style restaurant on the third floor. I would not recommend to take the set dish from the Japanese one, because most of the set dish food you could also eat from the buffet restaurants. The buffet restaurant on the top floor has an amazing view from the harbour but it's also crowded. The one in the lobby has same type of food but with less people. There were few vegetables and fruits in the buffet which is similar as the other Japan hotels. Though the types of cooked dishes (meat, soup, eggs, breads, etc.) were not as sufficient as the other 4-5 star hotels.All in all, this is one of the best standard hotels in Daiba area.

We stayed here for 4 nights on first ever trip to Japan. I chose this hotel because I was able to get 3 beds as we are traveling with our teenage son and needed a bit of room which this hotel is great for room size. The other reason I chose this hotel was because it has an outdoor pool and as I knew the weather would be quite warm we were looking forward to relaxing by the pool in between all the busy sightseeing but unfortunately I didn't know it only opens July/August so we missed it by a few days & very surprised to find you have to pay to use pool anyway. Other than the pool we were happy with our stay & enjoyed the area around the hotel

This time, I would like to share my recent experience in staying at Grand Pacific Le Daiba which was located in Odaiba area. This hotel is located across from Nikko Tokyo Hotel and it is accessible by Yurikamome Line which is located just outside the hotel. This hotel is also basically right across from Aqua City Shopping Mall which is located in the same side as Nikko Tokyo Hotel.Both of me and my friend arrived in the hotel property slightly before midnight in a rainy evening. The hotel lobby was grand. Check-in was average (a bit slow) as it took the receptionist staff more than 10 minutes to hand over the room keys. Within 15 minutes of our arrival, we entered our room.Our room's size was average but it's considered as large in Japan's hotel. Bathroom was nicely designed but pitifully, I saw many of their furniture in the room as well as carpets (inside the room and in public areas) were not in good condition. I also saw many of their limestone had black stains on them. Yes, I did understand that this hotel was built many years ago and apparently, it also catered heavily to group tours from overseas.In my personal opinion, it's about time for this particular hotel to proceed with room renovation. Otherwise, the hotel may start losing its appeal to their loyal guests who are looking for quality accommodation in the next few years. I don't provide a 4 stars' rating for this hotel due to condition I had described above.If I were stay in this particular hotel 5-10 years ago then most likely, I would give a 4 stars' rating. However, this hotel is strategically located in Odaiba area, in the middle of many interesting spots in Tokyo so that such fact certainly gives an advantage over other competitor hotels in Tokyo.We didn't have any chance to try their breakfast as we woke up late the next day but I personally believe they were capable to serve quality dining in one of their dining outlets. Also, there is a bus just outside the hotel's main entrance that will take us to Shinagawa train station for a small fee.Overall, I would recommend this hotel to every one who is looking for good quality accommodation, based on the condition I had described, in Odaiba area as long as they don't mind paying their nightly rate.

This hotel is grand in its own way, from the lobby to the rooms. Getting there is easy as there is a train stop practically in front of the hotel. The hotel staff are friendly and they greet and smile with you. The room is clean and so big you wouldn't believe all the stories about small rooms in Japan because this is the exception. Even the bathroom is so luxuriously decorated and well equipped with all amenities you would need if you didn't bring any. The beds are big and so comfortable that you would want to sleep in longer. Besides the train, there is also the rainbow shuttle bus that crosses the bridge to Shinagawa station and Tamachi station. In fact, by taking this bus it's like a short tour of Odaiba, a beautiful, quiet and peaceful part of Tokyo.
user_name:
M L K
Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia

review_body: A luxury 6 days stay in Tokyo.This hotel has everything you ask for,even much more! Room was big,lots of facilities in the room.Staff was helpful.Every morning an English newspaper was in front of the room door.At first I was afraid of the distance to tokyo-downtown but metro was almost "inside"the courtyard of the hotel.The area around just great.Shopping centers with restaurants ,any kind of shops.The shuttle bus was free and it took us around Odaiba.Only breakfast was a bit expensive.I want to be back to Tokyo.I want to stay again in this amazing hotel!

Not the new hotel, as I see, it is 17 years old, but it looks like new. But the best of the best is your staffs, they are at service all the time. They keep room tidily. They take care their customer with kindness. Your hotel need to be the most recommended from us.

At my first trip in Japan, I stayed at this hotel. The services, breakfast, the view are great!! The rooms are super clean, the employees are very polite and the breakfast is wonderful! Also is next to Disney Sea and Tokyo Disneyland.

After 2 weeks traveling Japan we decided to have a treat back in Tokyo before heading home. Be prepared for very attentive staff. Our luggage had been delivered and was in room prior to our arrival (luggage delivery service in Japan was exceptional). For not much more, we were surprised to find that we had booked a Club President floor which meant private check-in and a private lounge offering a cocktail hour every evening overlooking stunning views of Tokyo. The room was spacious, the view amazing (Rainbow bridge side), the bed comfy, and the area is a delight to explore, especially in the evening. Breakfast was great, with 3 options. We chose the buffet on the 30th floor, and while they do cater for a Western style, you have to appreciate the wide range of patrons they have there and are trying to appease all. The chef will cook an omelet if you want, but overall a high standard. The staff we dealt with all had a good understanding of english and were very courteous. Access is via the pleasant above ground monorail (?) which runs as regularly as trains and has sweeping views as you swirl onto the bridge. Nearby is the Ferris wheel that once held the record for being the worlds tallest. Airport access via coach on checkout was seamless, straight from hotel to terminal, no stops, 2800 yen each, no fuss. A great luxury hotel away from the hustle and bustle, but easy access. Will definitely visit again.

This was our third and final hotel on a two-week dream vacation around Tokyo and Kyoto. On a trip filled with wonderful experiences and exceptional memories, Grand Pacific really was a high note to end it on. Directly connected to Daiba station, the hotel is a breeze to get to from the Yurikamome line (which can be taken to Shiodome/Shimbashi for connections across Tokyo). All of the public areas are astonishing - high, vaulted ceilings, wide open lobbies, antique-style furniture and chandeliers remind you more of an ultra-luxe European hotel than one found in Japan. But the spaces still feel clean, bright and modern. There are an abundance of elevators which are again very swanky. Our twin room was stunning - so much space, which really is a rarity in Japan - with huge, comfortable beds and wonderful views across the river and the Rainbow Bridge. Double doors lead into the huge bathroom, which had dual vanity sinks, a walk-in shower and a bathtub. There's a lot of storage space in the wardrobe, too. Staff were very professional, friendly and efficient. They helped us organise taxis and transfers, answered our transport questions, and assisted us with our luggage we had delivered to the hotel via takuhaibin service (worth looking into if you're travelling around). The hotel offers free transfer services to the Disney parks, and is a short walk to Aqua City and Diver City shopping malls and the other attractions nearby. One thing I would say is that when the malls close (about 10:30pm) there isn't a great deal to do in the area, with few bars or restaurants to end the night in. There is, however, a 24-hour convenience store right in front of the hotel to pick up snacks and drinks. If you want to enjoy a little luxury while still being able to easily navigate around Tokyo, Le Daiba is a great option.

Traveling a lot and having always very high requirements, I am glad to admit that this Hotel met practically all my expectations. Staff is really helpful and willing to please you. Purists may somehow complain on level of the command of English of some of them, but we all are foreigners in some places and should show some understanding. Speaking slowly and some empation breaks all the barriers. As for the location, everybody knows Odaiba is not Tokyo's downtown. As an artificial island it is considered tourist attraction itself. We reached the hotel from Narita by Taxi (prearranged) paying 19500yen. Last Hotel bus left half an hour earlier, otherwise we would use it (2800yen p.p). We took the bus on the way and it was flawless - even a little cosmical with multilevel tags for the bags, multiple checkups by the staff and Japanese style bowing. High class safe way to reach the airport. As for commuting to the downtown, you should use Warerfront line. Ticket is 360yen - twice the usual Underground. View is scenic - especially passing the Pearl Bridge. Having some luck you may even take the pilot seat :)As for the breakfast - definitely use 30th floor restaurant - cost 2800yen. Take the window seat and enjoy the view. Food is really tasty and you may risk having two breakfasts at once - European and Japanese. On you own belly fat risk ;)Rooms are very clean and well furnished. I cannot agree with some reviewers finding them obsolete and worn out. With my wide experience I find them classy and in a very good taste. Shiseido cosmetics in the bathroom is only a partial proof. To cut some costs you may shop for groceries and beverages in the little 24/7 store just in front of the Waterfront Train doors. Wines and spirits there are real bargain. You can get acceptable Chilean Sauvgnon Blanc around 1000yen. If you like shopping - you have few huge Malls in the walking distance. Internet is included and works very well. In one word - excellent hotel.

Michael L must have been staying in a different hotel to the Grand Pacific that we stayed in!The staff are most cooperative and pleasant. The rooms are delightfully presented and clean. Beds are luxurious. Shower, bath etc excellent.Breakfast and buffet lunch are of a high standard and delivered with a smile.Travellers in Japan are used to limited English but always conversation is courteous.We will definitely return to this true gem of a hotel.

I had the pleasure of spending two nights here for sight-seeing at the end of a business trip. The service was first-rate and my room was spacious and elegant. I had a king room on the 22nd floor with a view of the Rainbow Bridge, Downtown Tokyo, and all the attractions of the Adaiba entertainment district. The bed was huge - two queen beds pushed side-by-side together. The train station was just outside the front door and was convenient for getting into town. All of the shopping malls and attractions were within walking distance as was access to other rail lines. There are express buses to Haneda Airport and Tokyo Disney that come to the front door.The breakfast buffet is one of the best I have encountered. There was an omelette chef plus a wide assortment of Western and Japanese dishes - even Belgian waffles. There are seven or eight options for dinner, but I was away from the hotel at dinner time. I would definitely stay here again.

We spent our two nights at Grand Pacific Le Daiba. It's just 15minutes by direct limousine bus from Haneda Airport (cost around 500 yens). From the hotel is near to few attractions like Tokyo Disneyland, Japanese hot springs - SPA in Odaiba area, few shopping malls and port promenade with gorgeous view. The Daiba train station is just next to the hotel and with Waterfront line you can go to Shidome or Shinbashi where is easy to change for another lines. Interior of this hotel is a bit old fashioned, design is not new but the hotel has really good service and staff is extremely kind, helpful. We got an upgrade to executive large room on the 27th floor with breathtaking view and spacious fully equipped bathroom. Grand Pacific welcomed us really great.

This hotel is little away from the main area...but still a good stay for couple of days....nice view of the city....rooms are big with comfortable beds....staff is helpful...lots of things to do and shop nearby...direct bus from the hotel to airport was a big relief!!!

Hotel is right next to the Odaiba monorail station with easy access into Shiodome and Shimbashi across the river. Also easy access to Disney with a free coach service to the parks.Hotel has great views across the bay and Rainbow Bridge and is ideally situated for the various tourist type shops and events on the Odaiba Resort Island. Direct access from the airport using the Limousine Bus service is also a benefit.The hotel is large, clean and offers good service. The rooms a reasonable in size, especially for Tokyo.We stayed at this hotel for a total of 6 nights across the beginning and end of our 2 week holiday to Japan. We were able to leave luggage at the hotel after the first 3 nights to avoid carrying them to our next destinations.This is a nice hotel and great location as long as you can get a good rate.A pool is available but with an additional charge which is a bit disappointing and unnecessary really given the rates.

I stayed for one night there and I could see Rainbow Bridge in my room. My colleague's room was on the other side of the hotel and its view of Tokyo seaports was good, too.The room was well maintained and very clear. Staff was always ready to help us. I had a Japanese breakfast, which was recommendable.The hotel offers various ways of access. Two metro stations are within a walking distance and you can take buses to major stations, HND/NRT airports or places in Odaiba. If you go to Haneda Airport, Tokyo Teleport Station - Tennozu Isle Stn route is much better than going to Keikyu Shinagawa Stn by bus.

This was my first trip to Japan and I had stayed here (4 days total). The bed was extremely comfortable with ample space for an American sized couple (true queen size bed) - so much so that I wanted to import the bed! Room and bathroom were spacious compared to other hotels (I stayed in 2 hotels depending on my itinerary the week I was in Japan). Free wireless wifi was consistent and stable with no fuss in access. Free amenities and toiletries (since I forgot a few things in my packing) were available and always in stock. They even stocked 2 free water bottles every day for you when they cleaned your room. They were extremely helpful in helping me get to my schedule bus leaves. They even helped store my luggage until I was ready to leave. The area is a bit touristy but to my liking since Odaiba island on Tokyo bay is spacious. I didn't feel cramped or claustrophobic like I did in other places in Tokyo. You feel as if they designed the island and the hotel around the international traveler's comfort. If am ever lucky enough to return to Japan I will DEFINITELY stay here again.

Our friends have stayed at Grand Pacific Le Daiba and recommended it highly. The advantages are a spacious, western style hotel with great service, large rooms and lots of surrounding open space. There is lots of nearby shopping, restaurants, even an onsen. The disadvantage is that it takes a shuttle bus ride or short train ride to get to the nearest train stations in Tokyo. This can easily add up to an hour to get into Tokyo.

Staff are unfriendly and most definitely useless!Why should I have to fill in my passport details on a piece of paper when the check in staff have just taken a photocopy of my passport? Absolutely pointless and waste of time. Staff English level is also well below average, even by Asian standards.My air-conditioner is just a bit better than a fan. I had to set it to 15C on high fan power just so that the room can just maintain 24C. I had two staff come into my room who can't tell the difference between temperature and fan speed. They keep on saying it is working but can't explain why the high fan setting is the same as medium and low.Appalling service coupled with incompetent staff turned this holiday into a nightmare. I shall never stay here again!!!

This is a luxury hotel with best service and prime location. I stayed here for 5 nights with 4 adults and 1 child. We are all love this hotel and enjoy the stay. The first thing you will love about this hotel is the shutter bus service (you need to buy ticket at the arrival hall) which go directly from Narita Airport to the hotel's door. This is very convenient when you travel with kinds , big luggages or elderly. The staffs are very helpful and friendly , They are trained to be professional , knowing how to service customers. You will never feel being left behind. You can live your luggages at the lobby if you arrive before the check - in time ( 3 p.m) .The rooms are clean , the bed and bedding are very comfortable.The area around filled with shopping mall tourist attractions and museums. The major shopping mall and the famous TV broadcasting building are in a walking distance. there is a public park just next to the hotel where you can enjoy the view of Tokyo bay and Japanese style garden. Travelling to and from the Tokyo centre area is very easy as there is a train station right at the hotel door. However, it takes about 10 minutes to arrive at Shimbashi Station where you can change to other train line to your destinations. If you don't want to pay for the breakfast or dinner you can buy foods from convenience store located a few steps from the hotel. You will love staying here .

I booked this hotel in Tokyo for two nights and was not disappointed. From the moment I arrived by taxi from the Bus Terminal in Tokyo City, I was greeted with lots of friendly, helpful staff. The concierges were great and helped me book restaurants in Tokyo and provided good advice. I had a great view of Tokyo Bay and the Daiba monorail terminal was at the door. You must check out the view, cocktails and food at the Star Bar on Level 30. Fabulous night skyline of Tokyo. There's a 5km running track along the foreshore and a free shuttle bus every 20-30 mins around Odaiba. There's free wifi in the hotel and the speed was great. I would definitely come back here to stay!

Only stayed here for one night, wish it was longer.Lovely staff, great view, close to train station, shopping, very comfortable. Food and drinks in the hotel are a little pricey, but that's to be expected, there is a 24hour shop down stairs that has everything you might need, and restaurants along the waterfront.

After spending 3 weeks in hostels, I cheekily spent my last two nights in this hotel because sometimes you've just got to taste the good life for a wee while! I was not disappointed- I had a spectacular view of Rainbow Bridge, the staff were lovely, the bathroom was luxurious, the whole place was well kept and it's right next to Daiba Train Station- very handy! It's also got a 24/7 convenience store next door- super handy! But the highlight was definitely the view- particularly amazing to see all the lights at night.

Arriving in Japan at 7am, I asked in advance for my room to be available from 9am, which was organised with no problems. Everything was as expected when I arrived and despite being in a smoking floor, the hotel staff were very accommodating in making sure that the room was aired out before my arrival as I am a non-smoker. The view from my room on the 26th floor was fantastic and the staff around the hotel were very friendly. There are plenty of restaurants to choose from in the hotel complex itself though slightly pricey, but if you want alternatives then a short 3-5 minute walk takes you to two different shopping complexes with about 30 restaurants in each. Daiba station is literally outside the front entrance making for easy access on the Yurikamome line into central Tokyo. I would definitely stay here again and recommend this hotel to others.

We stayed at this hotel for 6 days. It is a fabulous hotel. I would rate it a 5 star. The rooms were big and very nice. The higher floors have fantastic views. The breakfast buffet on the top floor was great. We could see Mt. Fuji on one of the mornings there.

The hotel is well located with the Daiba station only 1 minute away & surrounded by AquaCity & Divercity & 2 other smaller malls. Easy access to the Big Sight convention hall too. You get 3 restaurants to choose from for breakfast, so it pays to book the breakfast with the room. I was able to get to the exhibition halls easily after breakfast, work till 4pm & then back to the malls for shopping & dinner.
