I stayed in the Club room so I had accessed to the lounge on the 27th floor, it has the most magnificent view. The restaurant on the 30th floor also offers a spectacular view. I was not too happy with the pillows, I prefer the latex pillows that supports the neck. The ones here feels firm but you head sinks into it. I woke up with neck & back ache. The breakfast is very good, we had the International Buffet twice & the Japanese Restaurant twice also, one time we ate the breakfast with rice & another time with porridge. Enjoyed both.

We chose the Grand Pacific Le Daiba for its proximity to Haneda airport. It proved to be great choice.they advised us beforehand to take a taxi rather than public transport to get there, and so it proved. We booked an executive room, and even though we arrived mid morning, we only had to wait minutes before a room was ready. The room was superb, with great harbour and city view, the bed was so comfortable, the bathroom well equipped, with tub, shower ( and multi choice toilet too! ) we have rarely seen such a great range of toiletries provided in any hotel room. The concierge helped us make the most of our time, even directing us to a nearby Onsen to help recover after our long overnight flight from London. Similarly the concierge helped us make the most of our rime in Tokyo, advising on public transport routes to take, marking maps appropriately The executive floor breakfast was excellent, varied, generous and it was a delight to eat gazing out over the harbour. In the evening a cocktail hour was offered, with a range of snacks and drinks to enjoy. We really enjoyed our stay in this welcoming, busy hotel, and would recommend to anyone flying into Haneda, or leaving by cruise ship

We spent three nights at this wonderful hotel and enjoyed every minute of our stay. Our room was large and in very good condition. The beds were comfortable, the bathroom ample and offered good-quality amenities. Like most places in this lovely country, the Grand Pacific was immaculate and well-maintained. The hotel is on Le Daiba island and has wonderful sea views, including the famous Rainbow Bridge, which connects the island to the rest of Tokyo. The best view was from the Breakfast Room on the 32nd floor. The staff were polite and welcoming. The buffet breakfast served a variety of Western dishes as well as local ones. There are some elegant department stores within walking distance of the hotel.

The Yurikomome metro station begins here so access is easy. We had a great view of Aqua City which has a Disneyesque feel to it and jugglers, acrobats and magic acts can be seen here. The Fuji building is illuminated at night changing with the music played. This is a beautiful hotel and offers many amenities including Shiseido products in their bathrooms. SErvice is excellent and respectful. One evening we had a note in the threshold stating that we had not had our room serviced as we had left the privacy electronic sign on all day and all we had to do was phone a number provided and they came within twenty minutes. The concierges Mr. Muller and another French gentleman were very helpful to us and receive our gratitude. This was our first visit to Japan.

Two night stay at the end of a month long trip around Asia. had a few nights at different Air B n Bs in Japan first and was nice to finish my trip here. Beauitiful hotel sitting on the water just next to numerous shopping malls and outdoor attractions. Literally a 30 seond walk from the Daiba metro and very easy to find. Its located at the new waterfront so you will have to buget an extra 15-20 minutes of travel time when you want to go into Tokyo proper (as well as 320 yen). The room was very large (especially for Japan), clean and organized. Very nice china and coffee, good ammenities in washroom, big TV. I wrote that there was exceptional service because I had a few issues with house keeping and movies. Three different managers came to my room to apologize, offering business cards and provided complimentary access to the fitness center; what great service!I only gave 4 stars because I felt that the mens-only spa area was too small, not enough private tubs and no steam room. as well, the gym was quite small with little space for fittness exerices. Also, the TV only offered one English channel (CNN) and one movie channel to pay for. There are not options for movies to rent, simply one channel to pay for and hope you get something you like!All that said, if back in Tokyo I would stay here again.

My first Choice of Tokyo Hotel. Quiet and large hotel in Odaiba, served by monorail Yurikamone. Helpful concierge always consulted for up-to-date events. Large and open outdoor spaces for jogging or walking in modern Odaiba. You will see Mount Fuji on a clear day, during breakfast on 30th floor.

I stay here for four nights and never stay in this area before. But because of last min booking so all these hotels which is in the city are full. So come across this hotel and just have one room left. Did not really expect anything as never heard of the place Daiba as well. I normally just stay in Shimbashi area Turns out this hotel is really good and my room had the best view overlooking the rainbow bridge and Tokyo tower. And is 1 min walk to the station. The gym however is strange as need to pay extra. The area is full of shopping centre and food places.

Fantastic service from the overall staff, yet, a few that simply destroys your stay. 1) Arrived late from a long trip, ordered room service, and paid over 40 Euros for a Caesar Salad, which had enough sauce for one leaf of salad, and which was from a bottle (not freshly made) and a fruit platter that beautiful to see, but nothing to eat = robbery vs. a light dinner. Absolutely ridiculous.2) day of departure, required an extra bottle of water, and was denied due to checking-out date; where in the world a 5start hotel, will deny a bottle water, where? I could not believe it.

We stayed here for three nights recently as part of an Imagine Cruising holiday. We'd read the positive reviews T.A. beforehand but hadn't expected such opulence. Our double/double room on the 18th floor was probably as good as any we've ever stayed in. Despite overlooking a busy dual carriageway traffic noise wasn't a problem. The air con was very responsive and the free wifi worked well. The nicely appointed bathroom was crammed with all manner of toiletries, plus a toilet with a heated seat and several other features we didn't risk using. Hot water was constant and plentiful and the shower pressure was good. There was also a fridge (but no mini bar, thankfully) and a kettle and tea tray. As breakfast was a fairly ridiculous (but pretty standard) £18 each we chose to either eat at one of the nearby shopping malls or create our own - there is a shop within the hotel precincts that sells pastries, etc., plus a 24 hour convenience store mere yards away. The staff were uniformly polite and helpful (isn't everyone in Japan?) but, as noted by some other reviewers, quite a few had limited English. However, all of them had better English than my non existent Japanese. We really didn't have time to experience the other facilities at the hotel, including an outdoor pool, but I did hear from another guest that use of the gym would incur an extra charge. Strange if true. The hotel is not near to the centre of Tokyo but the monorail final station takes you pretty close - maybe a mile from there to the middle of the Ginza district. The area around the hotel is, however, pretty vibrant in its own right. Tokyo is a great city: clean, well ordered and not hard to get around once the relatively straightforward metro system is mastered. This hotel is genuinely five star.
user_name:
Julian B
St Austell, United Kingdom

review_body: Just spent 3 nights at this lovely hotel, the rooms were very spacious and clean( bedding changed daily). Excellent location for monorail and underground, views from hotel room of the rainbow bridge so the higher the floor the better. Shopping malls within easy walking distance which have numerous restaurants and food courts. 24hr supermarket just outside hotel which was very convenient for drinks and snacks. Would definitely stay here again if in Tokyo. There was only one snag and that was that the swimming pool was not open even though it was hot and sunny ( they do not open the pool until their summer season starts).

My wife and I stayed here in room #1501 on our last night of our JANESCO 13 day Japanese Experience a this hotel was again brilliant. Big, clean comfortable, nice breakfast, lots of small shops for a snack or a quiet drink in the room. We were easily able to walk with our bag to the station to get the train to Nikko.

the hotel is just facing the exiting of odaiba station Tokyo Japan. Nice sea view around the Bay Area. Room very big compare other hotels and very convenient near odaiba station. It can view tokyo tower from far so no need to go to tokyo tower u get a view. Huge shopping mall can buy anything you like many local brands.... And if you are gundam fans you can see the huge gundam near the shopping mall. There is a food court selling many food at level 4: and their ramen at the left coner is the best !!!!

Stayed here for two nights on a short visit to explore Odaiba. The hotel sets up very conveniently as it is on the Daiba station, about 10-15 minutes by the scenic Yurikamome rail from Shimbashi (320yen one way). Fromthe station, its a 5 minute walk - 100 yards to the hotel entrance. The rail loop also connects to many Odaiba attractions. There are also other options to get there by rail or car/bus from the airports.The Grand Pacific is also convenient to all Odaiba attractions, shopping and parks situated immediately adjacent or close to to Aqua City, Diver's, Deck's, Odaiba Seaside Park, and the water bus access point. The Seaside Park also has a 10 km running loop for those so inclined.The hotel has a grand entrance, spacious clean rooms, great views and a very nice (but expensive) breakfast buffet.Overall, we found this hotel a great and highly recommended setting for those who may want to enjoy an Odaiba stay. It had great convenience, great value, and comfortable rooms. However, it may not well serve one as a base for those who want to explore Tokyo as the transportation to many Tokyo sites will take an hour or more.

Stayed here a few days ago as part of our inclusive cruise tour. Thought it may be a bit far out of the centre of Tokyo but had other advantages. Nearby there are quite a few shopping malls where you can eat at a reasonable price as well as shopping. Our room on the 12th floor which In assume was standard was excellent 2 large beds a bathroom full of amenities with marble effect décor and the water pressure something to experience, the shower nearly knocked me off my feet. The view over the water was stunning and we watched our cruise ship leave for the next port of call. Everybody in the hotel was very attentive but their Engish was a bit basic. There is a fitness centre with a large swimming pool. Its quite easy to access Tokyo centre via the rail system. The hotel has a definite 5 star feel about it. In the evening its nice to see Tokyo lit up and the various buildings nearby. I think its the Fujitsu building that lights up to music.Some friends stayed in Ginza and found the area very expensive so recommend this hotel.

Spent three nights here and it is recommended. Immaculately clean, good rooms especially if u ask for one with view of rainbow bridge. At night it looks amazing. Tea and coffee in rooms, although no English tea. Cosmetics in bathroom, everything you need. Two minutes walk to the monorail that you can pick up the metro on. We were on room only and to eat or drink in the hotel is not cheap, but plenty of places around to get supplies or meals, the rooms do have a fridge. A real plus is WiFi is free and very quick.

The hotel itself is large but service is still very good. Room was nice and clean and we had paid extra for a view of the rainbow bridge on a upper floor and bathroom with marble counters, nice touch. Airport Limo bus to the hotel door beats lugging your luggage on trains and subways. Close to malls( including Divercity with the giant Gundam Robot) restaurants and Legoland and elevated walkways with no cars in the whole neighborhood so its great for kids! Just a short train ride to downtown Tokyo and the train station is one minute from the hotel. Free shuttle to Disneyland has to be booked at least two weeks in advance, booked full when we tried to book a week before. Lots of restaurants and breakfast buffet is very good with fresh fruits and and baked good along with usual Asian breakfast.

I had some trepidation when my sister booked this hotel as it is far from Tokyo and sounded a bit isolated from the action. Whilst it is all the above, I want to list all the pros and cons so you can decide for yourself:Pros:- price is less than half of what you'd pay in Tokyo but for a much bigger room.- Hotel is impressive and service is very courteous - Rooms are spacious (not the norm for Japan) and comfortable. I loved the spacious bathroom and generous bath amenities - from Haneda Airport, it is much cheaper to commute to this place but not from Narita (¥590 vs ¥2800 bus)- location within Odaiba is very central with malls such as Diver City, Toyota museum, and parks within walking distance. The subway is also right next to it. - Odaiba is definitely worthwhile to devote a day or so exploring around here. There are even marked running routes. - 24 hour convenience store at the hotel's footstep- New looking town: clean with wide open spaces outside the hotel vicinity. There are even marked running routes. Cons:- I can't stand goose down pillows. By the middle of the night I was awake trying to plump it up (useless). The next day we were able to request for hard pillows - expect a 30-50 minute commute that involves at least one transfer via trains and bus to get out of Odaiba into Tokyo and other cities. So once you're out, you are out for the day.Overall if I plan to travel to Japan with family and a relaxed pace, I would return.

Splurged a little on this to conclude my Japan vacation. Hotel takes some effort to get to by public transport, but it's worth it in my opinion. (For those concerned, the hotel has shuttle services to the airports, and a line of taxis) Hotel complex itself has a distinctive European romantic feel to it, all the marble, European motifs, piped music etc. Rooms are spacious and clean, packed with all sorts of amenities. And of course there's the view. I believe every room should have some view of Tokyo Bay to an extent. Mine, the second room on the corridor, faced the industrial (Tennozu) area. But Rainbow Bridge was still mostly visible on the fringe.No shortage of fun in the surrounding area. Walking distance to almost all the shopping complexes of Odaiba. One minute to the photo-spot for the bridge and the liberty statue. And just two stations (5 mins) to Oedo Onsen. Was really great returning to my room after a long evening at Odaiba, and gazing at the nightlights before going to sleep. Will definitely remember that view for a long time.

This is a good hotel with nice rooms and good breakfast. However, it's not in the heart of Tokyo: 15 minutes on the monorail, plus 5 minutes walking, to get to the Ginza. I think that there must be hotels that are better located for sightseeing.

My partner and I stayed at this hotel for $140/night (found a deal online) and expected to get a mediocre room.Thankfully, the room was huge with heaps of amenities! I had a really amazing sleep here! The view was lovely as well and the beds were humongous!It's a good place to stay if you are wanting to explore odaiba although I wouldn't recommend staying here if you are wanting to do a lot of Tokyo exploration.However we were backpackers in a 5 star hotel and I personally didn't feel that welcomed and we were looked down upon by some staff, especially those who spoke English. The Japanese staff member who showed us our room was lovely though!Don't pay full price for this place.

Nice views of inner harbour and 5 minute walk away is Statue of Liberty. Just a small one but nice to photograph. Breakfast was average and as usual slightly warm. Need to go for breakfast early as long wait. Gave room number to doorman and waited 35 minutes for table. Many more people still arriving. In eating area lots of empty tables, lots of tables still waiting to be cleared. Good value, rooms ok but service needs improvement

Booked on the recommendation of a hotel booking's website. Decent reviews all round, but what we experienced was excellent.Our visit didn't get off to the best of starts as the taxi driver from Narita Airport had no idea where the hotel was, despite us supplying him with full address. Not to worry. We eventually got there and found a fantastic hotel in a relatively quiet part of Tokyo, but with great local facilities and a short run into the city.Can't praise the hotel enough. Excellent service. Lovely large room with great bathroom. Our room overlooked the harbour.

We had great time staying here and found this hotel and the whole Odaiba having excellent atmosphere and great value. There is an express bus to Narita airport, which was very convenient compare to hectic transfers in Tokyo subway/railway system, which you would need when staying in central Tokyo. It has free shuttle bus to Disney land/Disney Sea and outlet stores of Venus fort. We found the shopping and dining experience in Odaiba the best in Tokyo. Also, as a perk it has great views of downtown Tokyo with rainbow bridge and tower and amazing at night.

We checked in this hotel for 3nights and it was awesome! This hotel is situated and located in Minato with great transportation network (Daiba Station) and shopping outlets (Decks, Aquacity & Diver City Tokyo).The breakfast was normal but adequate. Nothing much to choose from but enough.The staff are quite helpful and friendly. Overall, it is good stay in this hotel but we didn't spend much time in the hotel as we were on tour.We'll stay here again if we come to Tokyo in the future.

not far from the city, it is a comfortable and quiet hotel.yet, the service for breakfast is simply unacceptable for an hotel of this standing:at the lobby level the Café was full and 30 persons Queuing up with 20mn waiting time, so i went to the top floor, and then again, 15 minutes wait.need to be more organized!

Stayed at this hotel for 6 nights on the 20th floor. Fantastic views of the rainbow bridge and buildings particularly at night with all the lights, large room with 2 small double beds and spacious bathroom. This property is excellently located close to a station so getting around is easy (Maps have English wording and coloured coded for ease) If you love shopping this is the place as there is four large shopping complexes within walking distance and many places to eat.Staff amazing and very helpful even with the difficultly of the different languages.Transport by limousine bus from Narita/Haneda airports is available at reasonable costGreat place to stay if you are in Tokyo.

We stayed at this hotel for three nights on our trip around Japan after reading trip advisor reviews. It was a nice hotel that nearly adjoined to the railway with many good features. We booked the rainbow bridge view room. We were allocated a room that was likely the " lowest level" for this room as we could ' see the bridge' but the nikko hotel was the main feature of our view. The room itself was nicely appointed and spacious by Japanese standards, the bed was comfortable and the room clean. The highlight was the lovely bathroom that had heated toilet seats, ( I wish we had these in Australia), a good sized bath and the daily ( high quality) facial products provided. The other bonus was the 24 hour convenience store that had provisions for late night munches ( and alcoholic beverages as well).We were lucky to get a good deal on the room by booking in advance had a breakfast included in the package. Whilst the breakfast had a nice selection I was very disappointed about the wait. I had read that at peak times hour you may need to wait a while to get seated but this happened for us Everyday! Two of those occasions were before 7 am!We tried all three restaurants ( there seemed no delay at the traditional Japanese breakfast- but by choosing to eat here so we could get seated sooner meant that we had to pay 500 yen each for a cup coffee ( that seemed a bit over the top to me given it should be an inclusive package. If you have lazy days planned waiting around breakfast around might suit you, but we had action filled days that made this a disappointment for me.I was we'll aware the diaba station was a little out of the city and made the decision to sacrifice location for quality, however this travel did get tedious. Once you were back at the hotel to get changed after a long say of sightseeing it seemed ' too hard" to go back into the city for dinner. Of note the metropolitan japanese train lines have more than one type of ticket, ( we had to use three types to get around the city each day) if you want to be able to come and go as much as you like this can add up in time and money. I did like the hotel however would not stay here again if I returned. I would choose to stay in the more central tokyo area.

I stayed two night in this hotel. Fantastic view and well sized clean room. The breakfast and choice of food was excellent. This property is excellent located close to the Tokyo exhibition area. By metro just in front of the hotel, is only 10 – 12 minutes and about 20 -25 minutes to city centre. If you looking for shopping, forget about going to the centre of Tokyo, here you could find a lot of shopping just close nearby. Transport by bus to Narita / Haneda is offered. Great place to stay if you are in Tokyo and have business in this end of town.

We split our stay at this property to two sessions, with a 2 days break in between for a trip to Hakone. First stay for 4 nites and 2nd stay for 2 nites. The 1st stay, we were allocated a nice rainbow bridge room at the presidential floor. Fantastic view and well sized room. Check in and out is at the floor itself (27th floor). Breakfast is inclusive and choice of food excellent. This property is excellent in locality. Its one of the major hotels in Odaiba area and surrounded by 4 huge malls. If you are into shopping, forget about hunting for good buys in Tokyo city, all the brands and choices are available in this area. Location wise, it seems far at 1st but Japan transport system is world class. Daiba metro station is just in front of the hotel....20 mins into Tokyo city and you can connect to any metros / subway lines from Shimbashi station. There's another line that also connects to the city , Tokyo Teleport Station. We used both and both gets you into the city with the same speed. I am not sure why they need two lines to cover the same area. If you are into family entertainment and a quiet less congested stay, this is highly recommended area to stay, eat, play. The view of the city is to die for....from any angle of this huge man made isle. Its a futuristic area with the massive Fuji Television Station in the center of it all. Transport wise, the airport Limo Bus connect direct from Narita / Haneda to the front of the hotel. Its a wise mode if you have luggage and kids to handle. Free shuttle to the disneyland and disneysea theme parks as well. Great place to stay if you are in Tokyo.

stay for 3 nights with family, since we have amend the dates makes us need to move the rooms for 2 days, a bit upset but no choice, the hotel is always full during our stay period.friendly staffs, smart reception, nice room and love the bathroom amenities very much.shuttle service to disneyland and disneysea is very helpful, wish to return again.

We check in at 12pm midnite and guess what? We got the upgrade to the luxury room...( woohoooo...). The room was so big (maybe about 50m2), and the bed is super king size. The staff was very helpfull.There is a convenient store at the front of the hotel who open 24/7.The location of this hotel is just the front of daiba station and the liberty statue of tokyo. This is really cool place to stay, and this hotel become our number one place to stay at Tokyo now.

This was my second visit at this hotel. My first one was back in 2006. Restaurants close very early at night, so better have dinner before 9 PM. There is, however, very convenient convenience store steps away from the hotel lobby. Here you can find everything from food, drinks and personal hygiene items. Probably, what is best about this hotel is the location: easy access to the Yurikamome line.

Good for the airport (Haneda) and Disneyland but not so good if you want to spend time in town - worked out quite costly to travel about.Rooms on the big side for Japan, still quite pricey for what you get. Staff friendly and courteous and a few restaurants on site.Couple of local attractions eg the Ferris Wheel worth a look.

AccessConveniently accessible from Narita Airport (Narita) by airport limousine bus. Travelling time to hotel is about 80 minutes and costs JPY2800 one way.Bus drops you at hotel door step. There was no bell hop in sight when we arrived at about 10 am and we had to find our own way and carry own bags to the check-inCheck-in / Check outAlthough we requested early check in , we were unable to do so and were told to wait till 3pm even though we offered to pay for early check-in. We checked out at 6.45 am. No queues and hassle free. When we requested for help with our luggage to the bus waiting area outside the hotel, we were told, quite oddly, to carry/push our own luggage. RoomWe had a room facing the sea and the maritime museum. The room and bathroom were very clean and considered large by Japanese standards. Both were well lit and bright pastel colored. Coffee and tea (English and green) were complimentary and the room fridge was empty of amenities which allowed you to stock up your own stuff. Bathroom was fully stocked with toiletries; soap, shampoo, toothbrush, schick razor, hair brush including complimentary shishiedo products. Housekeeping was excellent and didn’t miss a beat when it came to cleanliness of the room, replenishing amenities, complimentary bottles of drinking water and towels, even refilling the hot water boiler and the humidifier daily.LocationHotel is located in Odaiba and within walking distance to Diver City ( <15 mins), Aquacity (< 5mins) and Decks (<10mins), Venus Fort (<20 mins) shopping centres, and close to two train stations; Tokyo Teleport (<20 mins) and Daiba line (<5mins)ConciergeHelpful and knowledgeable concierge especially Mr Muller. Other Japanese employees spoke simple but competent English.MealsAlthough we stayed for 6 nights, we opted to eat at the many restaurants and cafes at the nearby shopping centres which served a variety of japanese, western, Italian, American cuisine and fast food etc. WifiCame with my room package.Speed was decent.ProsHotel location is far from the madding crowd. Convenient access to Disney parks with 30 minutes travelling time by Disney bus.Sheltered walkway to Daiba train station.Plenty of attractions (nearby onsen, museums, eating and shopping places including a factory outlet).ConsTo get to downtown Tokyo (Shinjuku, Ginza etc) you need to shuttle out of Daiba on the Yurikamome line (JPY320 one way adult) to Shimbashi and change line and pay another fare. Alternatively, you have to walk to Tokyo Teleport and then take Rinkai line (about JPY500 to Shinjuku one way).Timings of the departure of the Disney buses from Disney should be aligned to the Disney fireworks timings as the fireworks display start at 8.30pm but the buses depart for the hotel at those times unless you book the last bus back to the hotel which leaves after 10 pm OverallA pleasant stay.TipsFor better value and if you have a fair amount to buy, go to the local supermarket Marueto (next to the Odaiba kaihinkoen station) For Grand Pacific, it is highly recommended that you make online reservations for the Disney buses via the hotel website especially during peak periods as there are limited seats on the bus as soon as possible. I was fortunate that I did so at least one month before I arrived as the Disney buses were full when I arrived.To enjoy the sights, you should take the Yurikamome line train once in the day and once at night and make sure you're in the front seat of the driverless trainPuzzled or lost as to how to get out of or back into a train station ? Just follow the yellow tactile markings on the ground which is intended for the visually disabled – I found it useful and effective 8 /10 times when I relied on them.

The size of the rooms are big compared to the usual Jap hotels. Cleanliness can be further improved.Hotel is just located next to Daiba station. Concierge is helpful despite the language difficulty. This is an a nice area outside Tokyo city. To get to the city area, it takes about 45min to an hour by train and you will need to keep changing trains. There is a rainbow bus which cost 200yen per pax that goes to Shinjuku station and it's about 30min long.

Odaiba is a great location to spend a couple of days while in Tokyo. Great sized bathroom, convenience store at base of hotel and easy walking distance to Odaiba attractions. Has free bus to Disneyland and public transport to Tokyo nearby.

This hotel is on a manmade island on the outskirts of Tokyo. It is accessed by a monorail which has a station outside the hotel's front door. It is a great place to stay on a first trip to Tokyo as it is easy to get to, close to the city, but not in the middle of the city. It is a large hotel and at times appears to function like a little town. It is clean and spacious and has lots of shops on its doorstep. Would recommend

Arrived in Tokyo via Haneda International Airport and greeted by the windchill which was somewhat high on that particular day. Airport Limousine Bus took us to Grand Pacific le Daiba, to my surprise, was very near the airport. We were greeted by the hotel staff, and were able to check in in a breeze. The bathroom has a shower room, a tub and the toiletries are mostly branded. We had our breakfast buffet at the 30th floor, overlooking the Rainbow Bridge and the Tokyo Tower. There were lots of food to choose from, but the offers are all the same on the 3 days that we were there. One flaw tho, if you would consider it a flaw, were the pillows. They were too soft... even if you use the two pillows, you will still feel as if there were none at all.One of the staff (a slim lady) in the Concierge was very helpful on the tours that we could take on the next coming days. Since city tour is full already and we were after the cherry blossoms, she recommended that we go to Asakusa and Ueno. She got a brochure, a map and 3 or 4 colored pens and started explaining to us (using the pens) the train and the water bus routes to Asakusa. The location of the hotel is very right for shopping, since Diver City, Aqua City, Palette Town and Decks are very near to each other. The following day, we were lucky enough to experience a bit of cherry blossoms because 3 trees have started to bloom even if the weather is still chilly. I'd say, overall, our stay is one of the best and this hotel is highly recommendable!

The hotel is conveniently located next to the Daiba station of Yurikamome MRT station. By walking distance, it has good access to mall, seaside and Hotel Nikko. The view from higher floor is stunning, it provides nice view to the city and the Rainbow bridge. Although the hotel did not respond to our request on shuttle service to Disneyland sent to them few weeks before our arrival, the bell service staff (MR. Gomi) did great job to arrange one for us as there was a cancellation from other guests. The breakfast was monotonous and hardly changed the varieties for 3 nights we stayed.

Stayed in this hotel during winter and it's really a grand hotel. I think it has at least 7-8 restaurants but personally did not try any of them. The room has great view at the bridge and spectacular during the night when lights are on. Can actually see the tokyo tower from here. It has free shuttle to Disneyland. But you have book early because usually it's full. They also have shuttle bus around the area bringing you tokyo tv station, divers city etc. During the night, you can go downstairs and walk along the area to appreciate the views and there is musical light dancing at Tokyo tv station. If you walk to divers city, you can find a giant gundam robot near the entrance and there will be shows for the famous robot. During the shows on the big screen, the robot can actually move! There is also a 24hrs convenient store just below the hotel. Try order the curry ramen from room service. It's nice. Daiba train station just next to the hotel. You can take this train to just anywhere in tokyo including shibuya, shinjuku etc. Of course you need to change to other trains at the interchange. It's not difficult to travel around Tokyo as there are English words train route in almost every station. And most employees in the station speaks English. Overall a great place to stay.

Great views of Tokyo Bay area and the Rainbow Bridge. Large rooms and bathroom with some different tv channels, free wifi, 2 bottles of water each day and friendly room service. The gym was nice although I had to pay over $10 for 1 workout. Breakfast was served on either 2nd, 3rd or 30th floor with great views of the Bay area from the 30th floor. Although they were so busy I had to wait 10 mins before being seated for my breakfast. Good choice of both western and eastern food. Disney free shuttle bus needed to be booked before hand and was almost full due to them being super busy. Departure times vary, they have different options for departure and returning. The ride there was 35 mins in a tiny bit of traffic. There is a family mart store just outside the hotel and the train station is right there on your doorstep. Some large shopping malls are all around that area within walking distance. Overall it's a very nice hotel, maybe slightly over priced with not super friendly reception staff like in other Japanese cities. The feel the hotel need to work on their customer service a lot as I didn't feel welcomed or greeted nicely each day....stone cold faces with no soul. Please work on this and then the hotel will be almost perfect.

Spacious and light room with a breath-taking view of Tokyo and Tokyo bay. Nice bathroom with both shower cabin and bath tub.The hotel is close to onsen, shopping mall with restaurants, JR station, monorail, etc.I've stayed in quite some hotels in Tokyo. This one is definitely the best one I've stayed in.

We chose this place because of the size of the rooms which are considerably larger than most in Tokyo. We stayed for five days in March and were very satisfied with the standard of the property and the staff. Special mention should go to the concierges Phillipe and Ikuyowho were very very helpful and obliging. The hotel is on an island reclaimed from Tokyo Bay, but is well served by a monorail system which connects with the underground at Shimbashi station and has stops near Ginza and the Tsukiji Fish market . There are a number of interesting shopping malls, accessible buildings and entertainment options nearby and the lack of crowds was appealing.Don't miss the Toyota display, use the free commuter bus

Check in a bit late from Narita Airport. Warm welcome by all staff right after you stepped down from bus. Very BIG room with nice view facing Rainbow Bridge and Japan's Statue of Liberty. Super king size bed for me and Shiseido's face soap for every hotel guest Near to shopping malls i.e : Diver City, Aqua City, Gundam Mall and Fuji TV headquarters. Breakfast from level 30 was so plentiful of choices and you can opt to other level for breakfast if fully occupied. Near to train station and easy for public transportation like public buses and taxis. Service is absolutely great. For muslim, there is nearby Halal restaurant that cater halal food instead of eating sushi or udon everyday. Next to the hotel has 24 hours convenient shop. If you want to send package to your friends, the charge for this kind of service is absolutely reasonable for you to courier the things out.

Odaiba is a really weird location. It's a mix of western culture and Japanese culture. It feels a little tacky. The shopping is amazing! Everything is spread out and it seems really vast and alienated.We paid 13400 yen for one night as we found a deal on hotels.com (look around for better prices).The bathroom is clean and opulent with multiple bathroom products like shampoos and conditioners.I loved the toilet! It warms up! The bed is so big it could fit 4-5 adults comfortablyWe got a room on the 24th floor and had a lovely view.

I was first time in Tokyo or Japan (running Tokyo marathon), but I'm sure, that this hotel was great choice to stay in Tokyo. It's very good hotel with big rooms. Beds are one of the most comfortable ever. Bathroom was also very stylish. Free wifi was really good.Service is absolutely great! I got here best service ever in hotels and they even don't want to take tips, when I try to give it. Location was very good for me. Odaiba area is western style area and there are four big malls in five minutes walking distance. Nearby AquaCity mall is many good restaurants (we didn't eat at hotel, even breakfast was quite expensive). Yurikamome-line station is outside of hotel and in 15 minutes you can get to Shinbashi and central Tokyo. From Shinbashi we walked in 10-15 minutes to Ginza or Tsujiki market. Yurikamome is little bit more expensive than other metro lines. One way ticket (with Pasmo card) was 319 yen to Shinbashi. Airport busses (limousine) come straight to hotel door, so it was really easy. Still, one of the best part of this hotel was heating toilet seat ;) First time I met this luxourious thing. I so missed it.... I highly recommend this hotel!

Stayed 3 nights here and was most impressed with this hotel. Beautiful view of the Rainbow Bridge and water area. The room was large and well appointed, bright and clean. Bathroom was stylish, a good size with lovely amenities. If you want to leave the island of Daiba you have to catch the monorail but it is literally at the door of the hotel, so not an issue. About 35 mins to Shinjuku station. Close to the fish markets too. Traveling in Tokyo is a breeze, so don't get bogged down in the location of your hotel. We bought day passes on the train for about A$10 and you can jump off and on as often as you like, a good investment. This hotel has the widest, most impressive corridors I've ever seen...sounds odd but they really are quite beautiful.

We just had 3 nights at this hotel on our way to Vietnam. It was our first time to Tokyo and first time experiencing Japanese hospitality. The hotel is in the Daiba area of Tokyo which is over the Rainbow Bridge on a manmade area. It has a train station right at its door on a private line Yurikamome Line which is not part of the bigger JR etc lines which serve a greater part of Tokyo. Therefore on the first day we paid to get a train to Shimbashi Station where we could get a 2 day unlimited pass for use on the JR lines. This worked well except we had to get tickets each time for this Shimbashi to Daiba part of the journey. Our room was on the 24th floor with the Bay view (view of the Rainbow Bridge etc) This was a nice view of Aqua City, the colourful bridge and the buildings of downtown Tokyo. We got to experience an earthquake from the 24th floor while we were there. Apparently centred north of Tokyo but felt in Tokyo. The hotel just gently rocked for perhaps a minute and the hangers in the closet knocked against the wall of the closet. These are common occurrences and the buildings are built to withstand these quakes so wasn't concerned. The room was large, the bathroom well equipped and the bedding very comfortable +. There is free WiFi and lifts that you cannot feel or hear move but suddenly you are on the 24th floor. The staff couldn't have been more helpful and the concierge desk very informative, patient and eager to assist. There is a private limousine bus service to and from the airport which was comfortable and efficient and costs the same as the train with the advantage over the train as there is no having to get on and off with suitcases while transferring to different stations. When I booked the hotel I was given the info re getting to the hotel with different options but really the taxis are exorbitantly priced and the Limo bus costs the same as the train and takes the same time so really it was a no brainer for us. Aqua City is right at the door and contains shops, restaurants and a Starbucks which is open until 11pm (last order 10.30pm) if a late night coffee is needed on the way back to the hotel. There is also a 24 hour convenience store right at the hotel door also which is very handy. The hotel also runs a programme which if you are staying a certain number of nights or more, you can opt for a number of days where your room is not serviced in exchange for a donation to a charity or a credit to use in the hotel- a good idea which is environmentally friendly. The hotel was really well priced and we would definitely stay here again.

Just spent 1 business week in Tokyo. I usually stay in hotels in Ikebukoru area but this weekend all hotels where fully booked.Found this hotel in Daiba area.The hotel is very nice and the room I got was large for being in Tokyo.The bathroom was very well equipped and clean.Ok breakfast, but a little too expensive.Can recommend the bar on the top floor, a really nice view over Tokyo.The hotel has a small gym, but you have to pay to use it.

By Tokyo standard, Grand Pacific Le Daiba is a HUGE hotel, with HUGE room size. Coupled with an awesome view (although we didn't pay for the Rainbow Bridge view room) and great service (full concierge and all), it's a great place to stay in Tokyo... if staying in Odaiba area is fine for you - it's a manmade island close enough to Shimbashi and Tokyo Sta via Yurikamome Line.There is a Limo bus direct to airport in front of the hotel as well as the free Odaiba shuttle bus to bring you around all the attractions in Odaiba. Aqua City is a few minutes away and the whole Odaiba entertainment area is within walking distance anyway.I like to stay in this hotel towards the end of my trip, just to enjoy a bit of luxury for an affordable price (around AU$120 per night if you're lucky).

super hotel , everything was very well organised. choose a room from the 26 floor up and you will enjoy the best view of Tokyo you can get. super top bar with a view of the bay.Facilities are perfect for the amount we paid.Very easy connection through the metro line Yurikamome to the centre and to the congress centre in Odaiba. Odaiba is nice ,new area plenty of malls. ans green spaces.Yurikamome line is one step outside the door.

Our group of 11 stayed here and loved it, wishing we stayed longer. Five Star service from the very friendly staff. Great location close to the city with fantastic views. We used the Disney shuttle which came in real handy for our group. Nothing bad to say about this wonderful hotel. If you are thinking of staying somewhere in Tokyo, this place is Fantastic.

Its one of the best hotels I visited in my life. We stayed here for 4 nights. Its just far from tokyo center but the area itself has a lot of attractions to offer and the train station to main tokyo is just about 3 mins walk.Oh and I think the only thing I dont like about this hotel is that they serve the same selection in the buffet breakfast; whether you go in the 30th floor w/c has a awesome view or in the ground floor near the reception.

Stayed here for 2 nights, it is a bit of a trek from Narita airport but is in a nice area. The staff are very pleasant and the rooms were of a high standard with plenty of little extras. Main complaint was the super complicated kettle and no milk in the room by this was not a big deal. It is close to a shopping centre with restaurants and cafes also nearby. The hotel itself is a bit lonely, there was no one in the bar when we were there and the restaurants looked very empty. Not much atmosphere. Having said that the stay was nice and I had a really good sleep, the beds were comfy and the linen soft. Probably wouldn't stay again but mainly because of location rather than quality, I would rather be a little closer to the centre.

This is the hotel for me next time I'm in Tokyo. The hotel staff go above and beyond to make your stay the best that it can be. Beautiful and clean rooms and our room had a view of the Rainbow Bridge. Monorail is right on the doorstep of the hotel so if you want to head into central Tokyo you only have to hop onto it and before you know it you are in a different section. Lovely shops, cafes, attractions and restaurants around the area too. 10/10.

We stayed 4 nights in Grand Pacific Le Daiba, and got a really good offer, using their early bird price.With European style, the hotel is located next to the Rainbow bridge. So, please ask for higher floor, for a stunning view looking at the bridge and harbour.The service is excellent, many staffs can speak English fluently. The room condition is very big for a japanese standard (around 30 sqm), and have a bathtub (it's very handy for soaking our tired feet after a long walk, or for the childreen to playing around with the water). It's very clean, but only limited English channel on their tv cable.And there are a convinient store right in the front of hotel lobby (open 24 hours). It's really CONVINIENT, especially you decide not to take breakfast at the hotel restaurant. There are several breakfast box menu, that you can choose from.It's very close to railway/subway : 1 minute to Daiba station (Yurikamome line) and 15 minutes to Tokyo Teleport station (Rinkai line). It depends where you want to go.And it's surounding with big malls : Diver, Aqua, Decks and Venus.I have to remind you about the entrance of the hotel, especially if you come from the street level. The hotel entrance is in the second level, and the same entrance for Daiba station (Yurikamome line), so please take a look for Daiba station entrance.You can reach this hotel by (beside taxi) :- Limousine Bus (stop at 23.00) : it's very handy, because the bus stop directy in the front of hotel.- Subway, there are 2 alternatives (stop at 00.30) : Alt 1 : Take Tokyo Monorail line, stop at Tennozu Isle station > take Rinkai line, stop at Tokyo Teleport station > walk 15 minutes to the hotelAlt 2 : Take Tokyo Monorail line, stop at Hamamatsucho station > take JR Yamanote line, stop at Shimbashi station > Take Yurikamome line, stop at Daiba station > walk 2 minutes to the hotel.Alt 1 is qucker, but you have to walk more, while alt 2 is the other way around.

Location, people, facilities loved it all. Rooms spacious and so comfortable, service fantastic, location everything is in reach, shops, restaurants there all at your door. If not train station right outside. Would definitely return and highly recommend Grand Pacific Le Daiba for the place to stay in Tokyo.

I stayed there 6 days for my holiday, the room is cozy and clean, the staff were all kind and well trained, we really enjoyed it.One thing I should mention is transportation, which is called yurikamome, only one method we could use. You have to be careful 8-9 am and 4:45-7:00 pm, I recommend you to avoid it. Odaiba area is also new built business area there are many commuters use this public transportation system.Unfortunately most of the typical Tokyo sight seeing sites are on the main part of Tokyo, which is about 30-40 mins on yurikamome. But overall you can enjoy gorgeous relaxing time at this hotel.

Three days in the Grand Pacific Le Daiba is not enough please give me more….Getting to the Hotel from Narita airport is a snap just catch the Limo bus and its door to door, we were lucky as the bus had only 10 people on board.When you first enter the hotel its WOW I counted about 9 staff in and around the check-in area which was completed very quickly.Our room was of a good size and clean, the bathroom the same.DO you want to shop…well this is the the place the hotel is next to the Odiba shopping malls, and the monorail station.It was just nice to sit in our room ,have a coffee and watch the world go by…then after sometime pick a mall and go for dinner.

Stayed on the 25th floor overlooking the waterLiterally next to Daiba station which made it easy to get there from Narita Airport (hotel website has good instructions on train route)Breakfast was reasonable - awesome view from the 30th floorVery close to a large shopping mall

My family and I stayed at the Grand Pacific Le Daiba in November for our very first trip to Tokyo. We found a good deal through Qantas for a triple room and ended up staying in room 1234 - an easy number to remember! We flew into Haneda which is much closer to the hotel than Narita. Though the hotel offers a shuttle bus there was none at the time we flew in (nor were there any early enough on our departure day for our flight out) so we got a taxi to the hotel. Just to be safe we had the lovely girls at the customer service desk at Haneda write out the hotel and address in Japanese for the taxi driver. The taxi cost around AUD $60 each way. Onto the hotel room! The hotel room was a little dated but clean and large enough for 3 people and 3 large suitcases which I'm led to believe is not common in Japan so that was good. I didn't like the beds or pillows, I thought they were too hard but my dad thought they were fine - so I suppose it's just a personal preference. We had a fair amount of noise issues with the room above us, but that's also just the luck of the draw unfortunately and nothing we would fault the hotel for.Make sure if you're not a smoker you select a non-smoking room as the smoking floors absolutely reek of cigarette smoke even in the hallway.The hotel is in a great location for access to the city outside of the hustle and bustle (and the sky high prices of inner city hotels). There is also a lot of good shopping and dining around on Odaiba to keep you occupied if you don't feel like venturing into the city some days. There's a monorail station just outside of the door on the 'Yurikamome' line which you can catch to 'Shiodome' or the following station 'Shimbashi' and then change depending on where you'd like to go. You can also walk just outside the hotel and onto the footbridge towards Aqua City and get a great view of the Rainbow Bridge and the Statue of Liberty replica. Room service was a little expensive so we never tried it and the pool facilities were closed when we were there so I can't comment on those either. Overall, we would probably return here again if we came back to Tokyo as it was convenient and suited our needs. A few tips for you if, like me, this will be your first time in Tokyo:-Make sure you bring your own adaptor as the one the hotel provided to us didn't fit our Australian plugs. -If you're like me and use data when you travel, a data sim from b-mobile will do the trick. You order them online and have them posted to your hotel and they'll be with the concierge when you check in. http://www.bmobile.ne.jp/english/-Get a Suica card at the station for the train so you can just top it up with cash and tap on and off the train - so much easier than buying tickets every journey. Also, make sure to get a complete rail map! Different lines in Tokyo are operated by different companies/the government, etc so some lines aren't on some maps and in some places there are two stations (one for metro and one for JR lines) - my lonely planet guide only had the Metro lines on its map and it caused us quite a bit of confusion at first. -For shopping the best nearby malls to GPLD are Diver City Tokyo Plaza, Aqua City Odaiba and Venus Fort - all within walking distance via the footbridge connected to the hotel. -The best western dining we found was in Aqua City. Sizzler, Eggs n Things, Kua'aina and La Pausa to name a few. Hope this helps on your trip to Tokyo! :)

We ended our 3 week trip in Japan at the Grand Pacific Le Daiba - and was it good to finally sleep at the hotel in a bed after all the ryokans and futons (which we thoroughly enjoyed). Great location to the surrounding sights and multiple shopping malls, they offer a bus service into shinbashi station to transit out to the rest of tokyo. Otherwise the light rail experience is also highly recommended but slightly more expensive. We got upgraded with a direct view onto the waters and it was magnificent! Decent sized rooms for a Japanese hotel, the concierge was also very helpful with surrounding services (i.e. hairdressers/ shopping malls). Great hotel with 5 star service.

Had a fantastic experience during my 4 nights stay at this hotel. Not so far from Haneda airport and has easy access to public transport, shopping centres etc. Spacious room with a great view of the sea front. Reasonably priced and ample multicuisine options were available. Great hospitality.

As most reviews have pointed out, This is not the hotel to stay if you are looking to spend late nights in Shinjuku. The hotel is out of town in Daiba but is very well connected with a elevated railway station outside the hotel entrance. Its also near quite a few big malls to satisfy one's shopping needs. The rooms were large with views of Tokyo Bay and are well appointed. The decor of the hotel is a little dated but the common areas are huge and don't feel crowded even with a lot of guests around. The restaurants are nice. We had a fantastic steak lunch in one of them. Good for lunch and dinner but not recommended for breakfast as its very expensive and you can get very good breakfast in cafes near the hotel. Wifi is free and in room dining though expensive was very good.This hotel was known as the Le Meridien Grand Pacific Tokyo and service levels are what you expect in a large five star property. Very good but a bit impersonal from some staff.The hotel was very prompt in answering emails and accomodated our requests including early check in (for an extra charge). Overall a very good stay.

A lot of reviews about this hotel is about it being in a different island from mainland tokyo. I believe this is exactly what makes this hotel perfect. A getaway after the hustle and bustle of crowded tokyo. For quiet seekers, look no further, this is the perfect hotel for you.Train Stationis within 3 mins walk, and they have setup a pedestal bridge for hotel guests to get to the station. This station gets you to mainland in less than 15 mins. If you're confused on which tix to buy, just call and ask the guy in the ticket ofc. They're mostly helpful.RoomClean, efficient, properly done, yet small for a 5-star. Afterall, this is tokyo, most hotels have small rooms.Locationaside from the station, you have 2 big shopping centres and amazing view in front of the hotel looking at Tokyo mainland and its golden-gate-like bridge.Service:Its Japan. Expect the best, you'll get the best.I'll definitely stay here again next time in Tokyo

Big and nice hotel. Good place to live if you will attend or visit trade shows in The Big Sight Tokyo - there is a train station in front of the hotel and in 7 minutes you are in the show - train goes every 5 minutes. Has 3 or 4 breakfast places - we tied 3 and were very satisfied. 30th floor restaurant is open till late night for menu or drinks. SPA also quite good - swimming pool, few jacuzzi, steam sauna, Japanese sauna - everything you need you will get there towels, swimming caps, even cosmetics, but there is some not so big charge for SPA.One thing is little bit annoying - noisy rooms. Our room was to the big street and it was not so quite. And we tried a second room few floors above - was little bit less of noise, bet still.. We lived on 10th floor.

We took the Limousine Bus from Narita, no stress & very efficient. Arrived at about 8pm & check in was a breeze, with our bell "person" personally escorting us to the room & explaining all the mod cons (not the WC) &, would not accept a tip !!The hotel is of the old school, our first real visit to the "Switzerland of Asia" this reminded us of the top Swiss hotels. Breakfast was comprehensive, and, where can you go & see locals serving in a restaurant?? Service was impeccable.Rooms were large with views of Tokyo Bay & location provided easy access to shopping malls & the rail system into downtown Tokyo. Definitely, if you want a larger room at a competitive price this is the place to stay in Tokyo.

This is probably the nicest area of Tokyo to stay. It is a scenic 10 minute above ground train ride to the busiest hubs in downtown Tokyo, less than 30 minutes to Haneda airport and more shopping malls than you can visit in a week within walking distance. This area is open, nice to walk and not crowded and is populated with amusements to the Science museum (home to Asimo the robot).Now about the hotel, its great for tourism and for business. For runners or early morning walkers, this is the best location in Tokyo as it is virtually impossible to get lost. It is also among the nicest hotels in this area called Daiba in the middle of everything. The rooms are large by Japanese standards and very well appointed. The views over Tokyo and the harbor are beautiful both day and night and since this is a sparsely populated area for skyscrapers, (and people) they offer the best views in Tokyo. The hotel itself has about 7 restaurants, but if you walk to the nearest waterfront mall just 2 minutes outside the main entrance, you will have more restaurant choices than you would ever need. Again this is a very friendly area to walk as everything is visible due to the open spaces and unique landmark buildings that surround it and your mall and entertainment choices are second to none in the Tokyo area, things to do for all ages. Of course as with all of Japan... Very safe.The reason I did not give this hotel a 5 star rating is that in a city where service at high end hotels is super attentive and engaging, the front staff at this hotel was neither. What was remarkable was that as we arrived into the lobby to check in, no-one came to take our bags despite there being several staff available. Even as we walked by on multiple occasions daily, there was very little staff interaction or acknowledgement. (This was a first for this level of hotel in Japan.) The service at the restaurant was also remarkably slow considering that it was hardly busy when we ate there. The food though was very good.

To book into this hotel you need to think ahead, well ahead, this hotel is full most of the time, and having booked a few months ahead of our trip to Tokyo, was very excited I managed five nights in a superior room. I had no idea the reviews of the hotel were so true until I arrived and from the start greeted by polite and helpful staff who escorted my wife and I to the reception area, but just walking into the main entrance foyer was amazing!Christmas decorations at this hotel are amazing with a huge tree in the main lobby, and on the 30th floor entry very nice table decorations.Easy access from Narita and Haneda Airpor'ts direct to hotel on Limousine Bus.This is a huge hotel in a superb location, an hour from central Tokyo, depending which part of Tokyo you want to visit, but the Yurikamome monorail outside the front door will get you into Shinbashi and Ginza in 40 minutes and by train to places like Akihabara, Shibuya and Shinjuku, Further afield JR rail to Nagoya, Kyoto, etc from the rail stations at Ariake or Shinbashi.The main foyer has eight lifts to the guest rooms, very little waiting and the view from the Bay side on the 25th floor was amazing. Can see right across to Haneda Airport, Tokyo Bay, the under the bay tunnel, the monorail system, and just a delight at night.On the other side (more expensive rooms) for the Rainbow Bridge views.Breakfast is served on the 30th floor, very crowded, little choice, and small room, on the morning we visited, their was no view due to the rain and fog!The room was very nice, except the TV was on our left with the bed facing towards the window!! Bed was very comfortable, and you can call housekeeping for pillows that would be more suitable. I requested firmer pillows as the ones were very soft, and they were delivered within minutes. But taken away the next morning, and had to request them again the next night!! From the second day they got the message and left the firm pillows on the bed!We needed to iron some clothes and a very modern Panasonic iron with small ironing board was delivered to the room, and we had for the rest of our stay!The room had three phones, one beside the bed, on the main writing desk and in the bathroom!On the writing desk and beside the bed were charging points for electronic devices, plus free use of adaptors will be delivered when requested. Calling by phone for items is easier than waiting at concierge or at the front desk anyway!The English language was very good throughout the hotel, and communication was excellent in most cases. Housekeeping staff were very difficult to talk to, as they run around looking for someone who understands, and really it is not necessary for them to do that, but they willingly help. Just fabulous attention to guests at all times.Television for English guests is deplorable. There doe's not seem to be television provider in Japan that has the possibly of transmitting US or British TV into the country to be made available to hotels by satellite, but they do provide MTV, CNN and NHK, varies by hotel. Hard watching constantly repeated news and sports all the time. Therefore, when the weather is winter as we experienced, theres not a lot do, other than shopping malls, and Odaiba has the best. DiverCity, Aqua City and Venus Fort, palette Town. Transport around Odaiba from hotel is free with the Bay Shuttle, timetables at Bell Captains desk. Runs from 11am to 8pm.The hotel also provides the free Disney shuttle to Disneyland and DisneySea, bookings a must, leaving three times in the morning and returning from the parks from 6.20pm. You can purchase Disney tickets from the Disney store at Aqua City, and avoid the wait on arriving at the parks. They do run out for Saturday and Sunday sales, which means you need to purchase at the park booths.Other than the buses trains will get you to Maihama from Tokyo Teleport station with a change, and takes 17 minutes. Just by the front entrance are shops including a 24 hour convenience store, but only a five minute walk to Aqua City mall with the best hamburgers at the Hawaiian restaurant looking out to rainbow Bridge and the bay. Tokyo Tower is easily a stand out at night just beautiful views.The guest rooms do not have mini bars! That is surprising as everything else is just fabulous and to have some drinks and snacks in the rooms even at a cost is better than not having a choice at all!I strongly recommend to hotel management to consider the modern use of mini bars and then this hotel would be beyond perfect for sure! Seeing an empty mini fridge was disappointing!They provide complimentary mineral water free every day, fantastic toiletries, bidet toilets, our bathroom had a window with views of the harbour, just fantastic.Room service menu was good, but in reality very disappointing. We ordered the steaks, thinking we would have a huge meal with vegetables, and requested bread rolls. What was delivered on a mobile table, set up like dinner for two, was a small piece of fillet steak, small serve of fries, two slices of carrot, small piece of broccoli, two glasses of water with ice!! and this cost for two $88.00AUD! Very expensive and hardly a meal of substance. Plus we did not get any bread rolls!Overall, this is a beautiful hotel, with restaurants, specialty shops, an art gallery, gift shop, bridal salon, spa, massage rooms, pool, fitness centre, and it is breathtaking just taking a walk around and viewing this spectacular hotel.Guests dress very formally here in this hotel, and we felt a little uncomfortable in our Aussie shorts and tees, however, we never felt the cold as the other guests obviously did, and we must have been a bit of a surprise, as we were enjoying the cool days compared to the hot days in Queensland!All in all we were made welcome at all times, and were shown respect at all times, and enjoyed the amazing experience at this wonderful hotel in Odaiba, which even provides souvenir postcards in the writing compendium in the desk drawer and freely available from housekeeping staff.Wifi was instantly connected and there was never any problem or drop outs, perfect wifi connections in all of the hotel.Free Shiseido samples are provided amongst the toiletries, and 'milk' available from convenience store, not in the room.I would without hestitation recommend Grand Pacific Le Daiba and hopefully will get ton stay again in the future, leaving was the hardest thing ever!

This hotel is a 20 minute taxi drive from Haneda International airport. The staff are excellent and do their best to please and they all seem to have a good grasp of English which is more than can be said of our rather basic attempt at a few simple phrases in Japanese. Our room was large and very luxurious and we got an excellent deal with Expedia making the cost very reasonable. The hotel is situated right next to the monorail which takes you directly into Tokyo and therefore links straight into the underground system and the overground rail network. The fares on the rail network are very reasonable so we found this hotel to be perfect for visiting all areas of Tokyo. The hotel also has a coach service taking you direct to Disneyland which is a must. Just on the doorstep of the hotel is a convenience store selling everything a local convenience should sell. A large shopping centre is just round the corner, as is the Museum of Emerging Science which is well worth a visit at 620 yen.(See Assimo in action and see the planetarium). Our visit to the Grand Pacific was for only 5 days and when it came time to leave we were all very sad.
user_name:
Ian F
Otley, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Very nice hotel. If you book early, you can get an excellent rate deal. Personnel attention is one of a kind. The hotel has a beautiful view of Tokyo´s Bay. The only little thing is the location, but you can take the monorail in front of hotel and get to Tokyo's center in 7-8 minutes paying just $2.50. The hotel decoration is European conservative. The bathrooms are very beautiful. Yes, I recommend this hotel.

My family of five booked two rooms for two nights at bay view and one last night at rainbow bridge view. The view was excellent and the room was spacious. The services we received was excellent. They helped to shift our stuff to new room. All staff have no problem communicate in english.

We choose this hotel for our Tokyo extension (11 to 16 October, 2014) after our package tour in Hokkaido. Our friend recommended it. It situated at Odaiba, an artificial island at Tokyo Bay. I thought it is a good location which served our need, and not as crowded as compare to other area in Tokyo.Distance to Haneda Airport is quite close. If you won’t mind paying a little bit more, a taxi journey take only about 20 to 30 minutes (depend on traffic), around ¥5,000. Otherwise you could take the Airport Limo, which costs ¥520/pax.We booked for 5-nights which include breakfast. Check-in/Check-out service was efficient. We were given a double-bed room at the 18th floor, overlook to DiverCity, Fuji Television and Aqua City! Also great view of Rainbow Bridge! 2 pillows provided for each bed. Included Wi-Fi average speed is about 15 Mbps. There are multiple power points for all our charging need.We have a choice to 3 restaurants for our included breakfast.- Star Road, at 30th floor. It served International buffet breakfast, with great view of Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo Bay! Because of this reason, it is also the most popular one, and could get a bit crowded. You might have to wait a little if you are late!- Le Bouquet, at 2rd floor, Lobby level. It served almost identical stuff (buffet) as Star Road, but without the view. So it is more peaceful. Quality of food is good. Service was fine. This restaurant also served afternoon tea, and their cheesecake is marvelous!- Oshima, a Japanese restaurant at 3rd floor. It served Japanese breakfast set. We give it a try on our last day. it was mostly Japanese clienteles. If you want to know what is traditional Japanese breakfast, you should give it a try! Amount is sufficient, unless you are a big eater!Transport wise, Daiba station of Yurikamome Line is right outside the hotel. Westward it end at Shimbashi Station, which you can change to other JR/Metro lines to connect to the rest of the city. Ginza is just a short walk from Shimbashi Station.If you plan to visit Tokyo Disney Resort, this hotel is one of Disney’s Good Neighbor Hotel, and Tokyo Disney Resort Friendly Neighbor Bus make schedule pick-up/drop-off at designated time, but you have to book in advance. Once it’s full, the booking will close. The booking website is in Japanese, so it will be a bit difficult if you don’t understand.Alternatively, you could go to Tokyo Disney Resort by public transport. You could take Rinkai Line (from Tokyo Teleport, a short walk from hotel) to Shin-kiba Station, then transfer to JR Keyio Line (eastward direction). Alight at Maihama/Tokyo Disney Resort Station. Entire journey take only 30 minutes.I highly recommended this hotel, especially for those who are already familiar with areas like Ginza or Shinjuku. I find Odaiba area very comfortable with good shopping and dinning nearby (DiverCity, Aqua City, Venuse Fort). There are also some tourist attractions (Statue of Liberty, Rainbow Bridge, Giant Ferris Wheel, Gundam Statue). Ginza is just one direct train ride away, and also great as a base if you want to visit Disneyland and Disne

This is my first time been to odaiba and lived this hotel. I didnt disappoint as very easy took a shuttle bus from haneda airport and stopped at hotel. Meanwhile friendly and easy check in and bell boy pick your luggage up this was not my expected as i lived another five star hoteli needed to take my luggage up to my room. The room is large and with good view especially night view for rainbow bridge. The breakfast is expensive but you can choice to eat at 30f ,really good view to eat your breakfast. And there havw two shopping centre so you can easy to find a place to eat. You must spend a night in decks shopping centre as night view outside of harbour view is verynice. Althought this is a goodhotel but i think this is not recommend for first time traveller or love night life person as it is quite far away there but spend one day to there is not a bad choice. Althought this hotel is far way tourist side ,it is not difficult to go outside by train and bus only needs to spend more time only. So recommend who want to get away busy area but want to have a relax place to stay person

Previously we've been staying in this neighborhood, so we're quite familiar with this area.Location is just perfectly located next to Daiba station, so it's very convenient to take the metro to the city centre. Nearby there are a lot of shopping malls and attractions (Legoland Discovery Centre, Ooedo-Onsen-Monogatari etc).The hotel itself is very spacious, from the entrances to the front desk. The check-in process was pretty simple but unfortunately as most of hotels in Japan, they will allow the check-in time at 3 p.m. So the only way is to leave your luggage at the concierge before exploring the city.The room and bathroom was spacious and comfortable. We also got a very nice ocean view from our window.We would love to stay in this hotel again for our next trip to Tokyo.

This is but one of many excellent hotels in Tokyo. It is slightly high end, but worth the money for comfort and convenience. Ultra clean and neat. Rooms are very large and the decor is quaintly 60ish but in top condition. Overall it is comfortable and good for long stays. My stay was over 20 days so I upgraded to the Executive level which includes a private lounge for drinks and light snacks as well as private check-in and check-out. Many restaurants in the hotel and they are pricey. With all the great eating places in Tokyo, eating in is not an option for me.Hotel is very close to a rail station which will take you to all the subway stations and so access to all the sights, nightlife and restaurants is very easy. Buy a PASMO card and load it with Yen to use on the subways, trains and some attractions and some restaurants. Saves trying to figure out the train fare for each trip. This will probably be most people's one and only visit to japan, so go and splurge and see all the sights in this magnificent city. Bon voyage.

Hotel is big, grand lobby, rooms are spacious with nice toiletries. :-) Odaiba is quite far from the city center though. But if you'll be staying only in the odaiba area, this is a good place to stay. It's located near the monorail though so it makes going around easy. Airport bus stops here as well. Service is good too, most can speak english, and very courteous. There is a convenience store and gift store too in the lobby. :-)

Great area to walk your socks off! Shopping, food, walking, parks, cruises, train station all in the vicinity of this comfortable hotel with spectacular views. Breakfast within sight if Mt Fuji on the 39th floor. Most enjoyable stay.

Stayed for three nights in October 2014. Elegant hotel based in Odaiba, an area built in reclaimed land in the Tokyo bay area. 2 minutes-walk from the Daiba station which is a 15mns train/7 stops train/monorail ride to Shimbashi Station on the JR Yamanote line. This ride takes you over the beautiful Rainbow bridge which you can also walk in about 30mns. From the hotel you can also walk a bit further to the Tokyo Teleport station a take a train to Shinjuku. Narita airport is a 75mns bus/coach ride away at a reasonable price on the Airport Limousine service. Even though the hotel is located in the Minato ward, be aware this might not be your typical Tokyo location (neon lights blinking everywhere you look, streets buzzing with people, etc.). It is in a calmer area of town but still within walking distance of malls/shops/restaurants and a short train ride to more central parts of Tokyo. And the views from Daiba are breathtaking, not only across the Tokyo bay but also of and from the beautiful Rainbow bridge. The hotel feels luxurious and elegant, the rooms are spotless and quite large, even for western standards. The marbled bathroom is big with both a shower cabin and a whirlpool tub and also comes with a huge selection of branded toiletries both for him and for her including face lotions, headbands, hairbrushes to name a few .There is an extra charge to use the gym/fitness area. You can however request in advance for your room not to be cleaned/serviced (for a maximum of two night in a row) to help the environment and you get a 1000 Yen (approx. 10$) voucher you can use towards the gym/restaurants/shops. There was free wi-fi in the room and the air-con was quiet. The service was outstanding and the staff was super helpful, kind and courteous from check-in to check out.

Location: Next to Aquacity in Odaiba. For those who want a quick getaway from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo, Odaiba is the place!Transport: It's like having your own personal transport, as the Daiba Yurikamome station has signs straight to the hotel, so it's an easy walk back "home" after a tiring day. Oh and, one of the reasons we chose the hotel was because of the direct access to airport via Limousine Bus! A great plus if you have 5 luggages between 2 of us girls.Room: Large, especially for Japanese standard. Great amenities, nice view (even though we didn't get a Rainbow Bridge view room).Lobby: Grand! Not my cuppa (I prefer boutique), but mum was thrilled. Staff were all English speakers and professional. Definitely got that 5 star hotel feel...Area: Plenty of shops around the building area, some open early with bread and snacks to purchase. And there was even a nice place for weddings, we saw a couple who were getting married that day. Gorgeous!Experience: Wonderful. We were there for mum's birthday, they gave her a birthday present - some yummy cookies. It's the thought that counts, and that was lovely...

Very smart hotel. Amazing views_across Tokyo bay and lots going on within walking distance. Easy access to the underground system.Plenty of staff at reception makes checking in easy even when busy.Comfortable rooms.Will definitely stay here again if in Tokyo.

I spent four nights recently in Tokyo at the Grand Pacific le Daiba. It's located in the Odaiba, a man-made island in the middle of Tokyo bay. The location is a bit of a mixed bag, depending on what you want. If you want to be in the middle of the action as you've either seen in media or experienced in real life -- Shinjuku, Akihabara, Shibuya, etc -- then look elsewhere. But for myself, having lived in and worked in Japan in the past, I didn't need this. In fact, I needed the opposite -- what the Grand Pacific le Daiba provides: A relatively calm location - but still accessible via train to the cool parts of the city. My agenda was to relax in Tokyo for a bit before embarking on a difficult two-week business trip. And they delivered the goods. I booked a room that overlooked the Rainbow bridge. At night, it's a beautiful scene and I slept with the curtains open and it became the last thing I looked at before dozing. Lovely. Large bed with just the right amount of firmness. Shower had plenty of water pressure. Room is relatively large by Tokyo standards. (Though it'll remind you in size of a Courtyard by Marriott kind of room). If you don't book a room with breakfast included, would recommend you pass on eating in the hotel just on price alone. There is a 24-hour store (similar to a 7-11 or Lawsons) on property. In short walking distance are two huge malls with both restaurants and food courts to serve your every culinary desire. Much has been written about the hotel's location. This really is NOT a problem unless you proactively view it as one. Getting there from Narita or Haneda is simple -- the Airport Limo Bus stops right at the hotel (and departs there too). I came in via Narita (about 1 hr 20 minute ride to the hotel), then departed via Haneda (15 minutes from hotel to airport). Getting around Tokyo is actually easy. You want use the Tokyo Teleport train station on the other side of the nearby Diver City Mall. Trains there go directly to Shinjuku in a few short minutes. Piece of cake.I like this hotel. Would strongly recommend it to my family and friends.

Two years ago we stayed at the Nikko hotel next to this hotel and were hesitating if we would go back there or try this hotel for a change. The Grand Pacific was offering a nice promotion for longer stays on their website so we decided to go for it. We didn't get disappointed. The reception seemed to be more efficient compared to the Nikko hotel but this can be a coincidence. The location is wonderful, easy and direct transport from Narita with the Airport Bus, what a relief.
