The monorail to the city center leaves next to the hotel, but OMG did we spend a lot of money on transport, you need to take a train to go to places in Tokyo, each and every time :-/With two shopping centres and plenty of restaurants in the neighbourhood we did'nt take breakfast included. We went once to try the breakfast, I would say it's average 3/4 star quality, but then again I'm used to a lot so more critical. Never tried the breakfast at the Nikko so I can't compare. The room was normal size, smaller than the one we had at Nikko but spacious enough with seaview, and a comfortable bed. I would definitely come back again. Odaiba is a modern, romantic place with a beautiful skyline, terrific shopping and excellent hotels.

Asked for an electric adaptor , sent to. My room 5 minAsked for an iron with board , at. My room 5 minutesUse of Hotel safe , no problemWakeup if you do not answer the phone , you may ask for some one to knock on doorService great

I stayed at the Grand Pacific for a couple of days on a business trip. A very smooth checkin. Rooms are nice and spacious. The view from the rooms is spectacular of the Tokyo Bay. The room service was quick and efficient. A pleasant stay.

Elegant hotel-excellent room and views of Tokyo BayThe location was very interesting with all the amusement facilities and close to the subway for easy journey to Ginza and all the other special places in TokyoHighly recommended !

Was supposed to stay in this hotel for three nights unfortunately due to a typhoon delaying our cruise we stayed a further night. Unfortunately the hotel made us check out of our room by 12am and we could not check back into a different room until after 3pm. Which seemed at bit daft and meant we had to waste part of the day. and have to repack everything. They then gave us a better room than the first one. Still.The hotel is in a great location on the waterfront with lots shopping and restaurants on the doorstep and plenty of things to see and do in the area. It has the advantage of being right next to the suburban train system which takes you into the centre of Tokyo in a matter minutes and the transport system is worst seeing in itself being efficient, on time, and everyone using a mobile phone or tablet as they travel.Both our rooms were large comfortable and well furnished.The hotel charges you to use the swimming pool.Staff are really friendly and helpful especially the concierge who provided us with all the information required to get around Tokyo including the train information, fares, stop details etcWorth seeing is the Imperial Palace and Gardens, Tokyo Tower, The Toyota Centre (a short walk from the hotel and free). Also visit the Shibuya scramble crossing which is organised chaos with a traditional shopping area.All the Japanese people we met were really friendly and helpful. If they see you looking a bit lost someone will come up and offer assistance. In the case of the stations which are very busy one gentleman came up to assist us and took us to the platform we wanted.Note, when using public toilets no hand drying facilities are provided in most so take a small towel with you. Also Tokyo is clean yet there are few waste bins around as the Japanese take their litter home so pack a small plastic bag just in case.Would recommend this hotel and Tokyo and would love to go back.

This is my second time to stay in Grand pacific Le Daiba Odaiba, very nice atmosphere not only because so many place to shop but also good environment.I booked this hotel through the internet so I can not get breakfast, well it's not hard to find food to eat here, there's convenient store around the hotel.

I used this hotel as a base for visiting an expo belt at the big site. The hotel was particularly good for access to Odaiba station where you can get the mono rail / underground into other more interesting districts. It is approx a half an hour pedestrianised walk to the the big site itself. The rooms were of a reasonable size and came with the usual soaps razors etc. However I stupidly opted for a smoking room by accident, they said it would cost me more to change to a non-smoking room and I really didn't want to spend the extra considering it's price already. The smoking floor was horrible and stank. Unless you are going to big site I wouldn't recommend staying in Odaiba it's a fairly dull sort of area. Given my time again I would have stayed central and commuted in.

Really fantastic hotel. We had booked a normal room but were upgraded free of charge to an executive room on check in. Rooms are very large and well equipped, bed very comfortable and bathroom luxurious. Restaurants are very nice. Location is superb as it is a bit out from central Tokyo with spectacular views of the Tokyo skyline and rainbow bridge at night, that you wouldn't get if more central. Travelling to central Tokyo is very easy as monorail stops just outside the door. It's only a 10 mins ride and less than £2.00 per person. Would recommend for couples or families.

We stayed at this hotel as part of our cruise package. From arrival to checkout it was seamless. We had had a long journey to Tokyo so to find our room key and all the details we needed upon arrival in reception was very welcome.Our room was huge with 2 queen size beds, flatscreen, and coffee and tea making facilities. The bathroom had a 2 person walk in shower, bath and all the toiletries you could ever want.Breakfast was excellent and the views across the Rainbow Bridge were amazing. The WTA Women's Tennis tour were in town playing a tournament at the Ariake Colosseum, this was their official hotel so bumping into a few players over breakfast and in the lobby was an added bonus, Caroline Wozniacki, Jelena Jankovic and Angelique Kerber to name a few.The hotel itself is situated on Odaiba (Daiba) Island which is a man made island in Tokyo that is renowned for its entertainment venues - Palette Town, DiverCity,Decks Tokyo Beach etc. The monorail station is at the hotel itself and it's perfect to getting into Downtown Tokyo within 15 minutes. Rainbow Bridge and The Statue of Liberty are great to view at night too. We are already planning our next trip back to Tokyo in 2015 and will definitely be staying here again

This hotel is great and worth for the $. For the price you can only get a small room in Shinjuku area. Rooms are big and the bed are very comfortable. Surrounding plenty of place for activities. I was here for a one night stay,

I would come here again just to ride the elevators! Seriously. I have never been in elevators so quiet. Not only is it like riding a down pillow, but the accelerations and decelerations are programed so precisely, that one barely notices motion.The pricing is on the high side, but given the:- friendly, helpful attitudes of the staff, - the adequate English skills of most of the staff,- the location: right @ Daiba train station,- the great view from the rooms on the harbor side, - the size of the rooms (not cramped as is typical for Tokyo), and- a bar with a respectable selection of Scotch,it was worth it. I would gladly pay it again.The only negative I will report is the price of food. I reported for breakfast my first morning there, saw the price, and promptly walked out. I attempted to have lunch there my second day, but simply could not justify it morally.There is no lack of great, reasonably-priced places to eat in Tokyo, so I would gladly return to Le Daiba and recommend it to all travelers.

The hotel was pre-booked as part of a cruise package but we could not have done better if we had booked it ourselves. The efficiency was second to none - several coaches arrived from Narita Airport at the same time and so my wife went to check-in before the rush but all the room keys were laid out on a table in alphabetical order for collection, so in no time we were in our room together with our luggage. The room was well appointed with a plentiful of toiletries in the bathroom, being replaced daily. Located on the island of Odaiba it is linked by road to the main part of Tokyo by the Rainbow Bridge, also the monorail is connected to the hotel and crosses the river into downtown Tokyo. Several shopping Malls are close by and are easily accessible along elevated walkways. Although we didn't eat at the hotel we heard it was very good, but expensive. We would certainly recommend this hotel.

We stayed for 3 nights before embarking on a cruise around Japan and South Korea. What a fantastic hotel! Firstly, we upgraded to the executive floor, Rainbow Bridge side. This is located on the upper floors of the hotel and hosts the most desirable view of the Tokyo skyline!The executive room was large, 2 double beds, beautifully decorated with complimentary wifi. A large bathroom with both shower and bath and the famously multi functional Japanese toilets! All toiletries were top spec and consists of a range like I'v never seen before. They think of everything.We ate every morning in the OSHIMA restaurant which served a beautiful Japanese breakfast! Highly recommend if you like your fish and savory breakfasts. We got the breakfast included with the room. Most of the staff we encountered were friendly and efficient, something which was apparent with most of the Japanese we met. Nothing was ever too much. A little patience, a smile and a few simple words of Japanese will get you a long way in situations where language is a barrier. The hotel is conveniently attached to the Daiba metro station which takes you to all ten tourist hotspots withing 20 minutes, it's very simple to use and I recommend getting a PASMO card which is like an oyster and debit card! It has a great shopping mall nearby (Aqua City) and loads of restaurants and bars. Taxi from centre (Shinjuki) costs around £20 and takes about 25 minutes. Highly recommend this hotel.

It was selected purely for the variety of accomodation locations as we stayed in Shinjuku before going to Kyoto. It was a great hotel in a great location, would recommend to all. The convenience of the place is second to none, as the island of Daiba has its own shopping centres and best of all THE VIEW, WOW! The night views to the City of Tokyo and the rainbow bridge were amazing. The built up boardwalk around the area makes perfect sit down and gaze the 180degree Sky scrapers with neons. Perfect last night in Tokyo to celebrate our trip as it ended. Oktoberfest festival was taking place practically 5 minutes walk away from the hotel, and Japanese youngsters knew how to party. Yet so orderly n respectful to one another. Great memory to keep for a long time.

We stayed here for 3 nights before a cruise holiday as part of a package and had the most wonderful time. We upgraded ourselves (for and extra 10,000 yen/night) to the 27th floor, giving us access to breakfast on 30th floor, cocktail “hour” from 6-8, business lounge access (8am-8pm) and health club access, however, we didn’t manage to use the health club as there was so much to see and do! To be honest, if we’d paid for the breakfast separately, we might well have been disappointed, but the view more than made up for any shortcomings and the food was okay. There are plenty of other, cheaper options available very closeby, although I’m not sure what time they open.Our room, although upgraded, didn’t look out onto the Rainbow Bridge, but having “cocktail hour” meant we could see sunset over Tokyo, making it even more magical! It seemed that other cruise companies had put people in very basic, but more central hotels, however, we were exceptionally happy with this hotel - it’s no problem going into Tokyo on the monorail. This hotel is not basic – our room was small, but exceptionally well appointed. On arrival, we had fun putting our card in to make the electricity come on as we were doing it upside down! The water heater also took a bit of working out – you have to press the two buttons on the right to make water come out. Oh, and trying to be quiet, I went to the very snazzy toilet in the middle of the night and sat down, only for it to make quite a noise and frighten me to death!There is a lot to see and do in Daiba itself – four shopping centres in spitting distance – the restaurant selection is simply out of this world. We went to the Premium Sushi Bullet Train Restaurant in Divercity (2 minutes walk) – what an experience! Oh, and for a proper Japanese experience, do visit the Fuji TV building next door!On our first day, we went on a panoramic tour of Tokyo – it’s great as they pick you up at the hotel, then it drops you back in Daiba at the end of the tour (you can go back into Tokyo with them if you wish). On our second day, we simply took the monorail into Tokyo – it stops about 10 minutes walk to Ginza. When you’re there, it’s lovely to have a coffee on the garden floor of the Mitsukoshi department store, away from the crowds below.As a first time in Japan, this was an exceptional experience and without doubt, it classes as one of the nicest hotels we’ve ever stayed in.

I'm amazed that this hotel has such good reviews. My only explanation would be that guests have not stayed elsewhere in Tokyo, and so this is all they know, and they were perhaps mesmerised by the experience of being in Japan? Forgive me if that's being patronising, but it's astonishing to me that so many people could rate this hotel highly.Firstly, it's not really in Tokyo, rather it's Odaiba, quite far from the centre. If you have any plans to be in central Tokyo after midnight, you're going to have to budget at least $40 per taxi ride back to the hotel.The hotel is not set-up for foreigners. It's probably the least foreigner-friendly hotel I've stayed in in Asia. Few of the staff speak good English and the written English in the rooms is comedic.The atmosphere is subdued and the hotel feels old. It reminds me a bit of hotels from the Soviet era - it's soulless.Nevertheless it's relatively cheap and just a few hundred metres from a very good shopping centre.I'm conflicted: you could stay here and have a great time, but there is so much more to Tokyo than staying in a cold hotel on the outskirts of the city.The rooms are small and uninspiring. The room service menu is pretty strange, and was probably not conceived with foreigners in mind.The opening hours of the fitness facility are nonsensical and the equipment is very Japanese: expect to spend 10 minutes trying to figure out how to change settings on the treadmill.To make the most of your stay in Tokyo, I'd strongly suggest staying elsewhere. If this is the only option, you'll still have a great time because Tokyo is a wonderful place. I could sleep in a cardboard box and enjoy the city.

We stayed at The Grand Pacific Le Daiba for 3 nights prior to our cruise around Japan in the Diamond Princess. The hotel is very comfortable and spotless. The rooms are well equipped. Have to agree with a previous reviewer that the buffet food at breakfast is uniformly cold - however there is a huge selection of Japanese and European food. The view from the top floor restaurant is magnificient. We were lucky to be in a room with a fantastic view of the Rainbow Bridge. Beautifully lit up buildings near the hotel make for super night-time photography. Give the hotel restaurants a miss and go to the nearby shopping centres for a variety of reasonably priced food - and if you must there is a McDonalds within less than a 10 minute walk!! Tours around Tokyo and to Mount Fuji are available at the hotel. Mount Fuji is best seen in Winter - all we saw was a heavy fog when we were taken to the 5th level on the mountain and this is very common (over 70%) in Summer and Autumn. Le Daiba rail station is virtually outside the hotel for an easy trip to downton Tokyo.

I stayed here for 3 nights for a business meeting. Room was clean, spacious and offered all the amenities deemed acceptable. The bathroom was nice and clean. Staff was extremely cordial but then that's what you do expect and receive in Japan. The only qualm was that it was a little far from Central Tokyo but then it had a train station right outside for one's daily commute. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who wants a comfortable stay with high expectation of both service and hotel amenities.

Beautiful hotel excellent staff and rooms very close to le diaba station really handy for getting around Tokyo free shuttle service to Disneyland and excellent tours on offer for Mount Fuji etc would highly recommend this hotel and hope to return myself

Hotel we stayed for three nights before our cruise this hotel was spotless although first impression it reminded me of the old Warsaw pact type hotel big and brash !!Eating here well in my book its a none runner seems to be franchised out to various company's well expensive . Take a five minute walk to the local shopping mall much cheaper & better deal can be had. Sight seeing recommend Japancan pick up from this Hotel Mono rail station outside the hotel yes and they put British Trains to shame THEY DO RUN ON TIME !Staff here are both polite and fall over them self's to be helpful nothing is to much bother even showing you how to work there kettles recommended
user_name:
Harvy B
South East England, United Kingdom

review_body: What a fantastic hotel this is, spot on. This is a must to stay at. The view from the top floor restaurant wow, the rainbow bridge is the highlight but there are other sights to see. Night is the best to get that important photo.Room excellent, staff, are immaculate Thank you to all

I decided to fly from China to Tokyo to see the two Disney Parks. As a past Imagineer for the Paris Park, I'd really wanted to experience them first hand but not in the moood for the kids and prices of the park hotels.I took the Narita airport Friendly Bus for about 2100Yen, one hour to this Bay region and had about three stops before my hotel. On the google map of hotels near Tokyo Bay, this hotel seems "close" (NOT really) and taxis are very costly (a 5km taxi was almost $50 US!).The hotel is close to, but not really close to the subway either and requires an unclear 2 km walk but up and down huge staircases over busy roads. The whole Tokyo metro is probably the least user friendly I have ever experienced in a major city and there are few people to support or answer questions. You also have to take two separate lines to get to the Disney front gates. Total cost about 420Y.The lobby is pleasant and first impression is good. The staff were as polite as one seems to find everywhere in Japan and most spoke English well. I checked into my room which had a nice big bathtub and a view to Rainbow Bridge and the Bay. The room size was good with two beds, a chair and ottoman. Odd corner room so the beds faced the windows with the TV far left, a little hard to watch in bed. I think there was one English channel, no BBC, no CNN that I recall.The hotel has free shuttle to the parks but they were full when I arrived or most the time which resulted in most of my spending to be on taxis! Why such low quantity of seats? Annoying.The hotel has a spa and indoor pool however its closed at 7pm!?? If this were a business hotel, one would assume after a day of business, its open to swim? If a luxury hotel, be open. If using the hotel as a Disney base, again, be open when I return exhausted form a day at the park. Never been to a hotel with indoor pool and gym not open at least until 23:00...and then of course, one has to pay for its use. Rubbish!In the evening, the lobby bar is a nice place for a nightcap. The bar on the 30th floor is closed at 23:00...are you kidding me? Why? Also annoying after a day at Disney to sit and have a drink and a nice view. Wasted real estate and bad F&B policy. At 9:30am for breakfast, there are two locations, lobby level or the 30th floor. I went to the 3oth floor and was given a table of two next to the window. I personally don't like sitting at a table next to the wall, facing out with my back to the room, so I asked to move. With initial hesitation, they agreed. I got up to go to the buffet and approached the omelet station where the chef pointed to a sign that had a big 7 on it???? I said I don't understand? 7 choices? I thought I might have heard 7 points....did the buffet have a total point value and as you selected items they deducted points from the allowable....so I went back to the front waiter to ask his assistance. We both went back, he asked some questions and also had no idea what 7 was about? I decided to just leave and try the ground floor, which now by 10:00am, was closed. The European concierge on the ground floor called up and learned that the sign says "No eggs can be served before 07:00!" Really? who cares....all that chef did was cause a bunch of annoying confusion and wasted time for me and others.I finally determined to return to my room, watch the news and order room service. At least four calls to room service for them to understand their own menu and bring me an omelet, toast, juice, sausage and coffee. Only $41US! Good meal but what a hassle for the most simple meal of the day. The room service chef taking the order could not speak enough English to even repeat the hotels English menu so again i called the concierge for help (same guy)...he's a keeper Mr. Manager!All in all, clean, renovated, but I would recommend staying at the parks or closer if with kids. When you have a highrise hotel that is most definitely catering to weddings or business, think of US business people or visitors that want to partake of the amenities on OUR schedule, not these limited schedules you have. The time frames are more like a small town location with limited staff?

We went to japan in winter last year. We had an excellent service. The room was 'huge'. The buffet breakfast's delicious and have so many varieties. Free fast wifi. Sleep soundly for 2 nites. The location is near shopping area( aqua city)and tv station.

We only spent a night at Grand Pacific Le Daiba on the way transferring from a hot spring resort to Haneda airport. The hotel deserves an excellent rating although it is not a brand new hotel, ie the amenities are not sparkling new, but it is a clean and well presented. The staff are helpful and speak good English. There are various reasons I would stay in the hotel again. First, it is conveniently located right at the exit of Daiba station (monorail 'yurikamome' line), and it is especially convenient for travelers going to Haneda airport since it is quite close by, and we can easily arrange for coach transfer from hotel with the kind help of the staff. It may also be a good place to stay for tourists to Disneyland as they seem to offer direct transfer to Disneyland too. Second, the room is spacious with three single beds for us and this came at a reasonable price when compared with other hotels in Tokyo. Third, the location is great, although it is not right at the heart of more familiar Tokyo like Ginza or Shinjuku, it offers a new modern side of Tokyo, it is next to big shopping malls and also beach walk area, has the feel of open space in the otherwise crowded Tokyo city. For me, it was refreshing to experience a different side of Tokyo after having stayed many times in the more familiar crowded parts of the city.

Nice hotel, clean, etc etcBut no use for business travellers. I needed to print off a 2-page document from my laptop and was referred to their "business center" - a PC with a 100 yen ($1) slot machine which gives 10 minutes of PC time. Went to the front desk, explained that I needed to print a document, not use a PC. The clerk stood there, open-mouthed, possibly understanding English but unable to respond. She disappeared into a back office a number of times, each time she emerged again she tried a couple of words of English but made no sense and stood there open-mouthed.After a few of these fruitless back office visits I suggested that maybe if I sent the document to them as an email, they might oblige by printing it off for me. After a few more visits to the back office, some English finally emerged: "do you have hotmail?"So l requested that she send out someone who could speak and understand English; a management type came out and confirmed that: * Yes this is a 5-star hotel * No, they do not have a business center * No, there is no facility for printing documents nor would they oblige by printing off an email from me.So if you are on vacation and can afford to pay $30 per head for breakfast, this might be the place for you, even though it's not in really in central Tokyo. But if you are coming to Tokyo on business, I'd recommend that you find somewhere else to stay.

I have nothing bad to say about this Hotel. The staff is very friendly, the rooms are huge, very comfortable beds, great views from the Bay, wifi quite good and a A list bunch of amenities.Besides that the location is spot on if you want to be outside the craziness of downtown Tokyo but at the same time very well centered in a area full of malls, attractions and with a Station just a few meters from the Hotel reception. Stayed there for a week and later moved to a Shimbashi hotel in the city with almost no price diference. The comparison is unfair. Grand Pacific le Daiba is great by all meas. Very recommended for older travelers that want to be spilled.

We had just done a home swap in a tiny but nice Kyoto house and were in need of some stretching room in Tokyo. Grand Pacific Le Diaba was just what we needed. The room for 3 was huge and very comfortable, as was the bathroom and the views of the harbour from the 22nd floor were great. You have to pay more for Rainbow bridge view but it didn't matter - we were able to see it from the top of the building anyway (staff were quite happy for us to go up just to admire the view). We particularly enjoyed the wonderful ride on the train (spectacular views of Rainbow Bridge etc) every morning and evening and the proximity of the train station to the hotel made things so very easy. We bought nice pastries in the evening from the 24 hour convenience store and had them in the room with coffee in the morning. The place is efficiently run and staff are very helpful.

The Grand Pacific le Daiba is a modern hotel Staff are excellent. Very clean and well presented place. RoomFood /Shopping well catered for. Rail link near the hotel.Very good 24 hr shop near hotel. Very good service. The Japanese are very hospitable , helpful and well mannered.No beggars, drunks ,litter.
user_name:
Joe C
Newcastle upon Tyne, United Kingdom

review_body: This is the second time we stayed in this hotel in 7 months. Without hesitate we decided to booked the same hotel for the second visit, somehow using their Japanese website is cheaper than global website.It was a hot and humid summer at Japan around late July.Yurikamome Line is straight up to the hotel, squashed between 4 big shopping centre, attractions, don't forget to visit onsen Monogatari in Odaiba.We came early at 1pm, Check-in counter open at 3pm, but they happily to hold or bags while we decided to go Diver CIty in the mean time.Room was very spacious for Japan standard, full amenities that you can think of. Missus wanted a bathrobe, called front desk, they came in no time.Good restaurant at 30th floor, Star Road, had a beautiful dinner with Rainbow Bridge view.Free round trip shuttle to Disneyland, booking required for limited seats.Can't go wrong with this hotel, after second visit we could not find any reason not to comeback. Would love to stay in this hotel again in next visit.

We spent four nights at this hotel before going on a cruise around northern Japan and Russia. At the end of the cruise we decided to stay an extra night in Tokyo and did not hesitate to book into the Grand Pacific Le Daiba again. The hotel was close to everything we wanted: Palette Town; great shopping at several shopping malls, excellent range of restaurants to suit everybody's taste within close walking distance;a train service second to none virtually at the front door, a free shuttle service around Odaiba Island and also to Disneyworld; The Mega Web which is a "Look, Ride and Feel" Car Theme Park that houses Toyota's City Showcase (which is a must-see item); and so the list goes on and on.  Another plus factor for this hotel was the easy access to and from the Airport using the shuttle bus service that picks you up and delivers you to the front door of the hotel. The only downside is that if you wish to go into Tokyo or the other suburbs you need to catch the train (or bus) which does cost a small amount of money and may take approx 30 minutes depending on where you want to go. But that is no problem as it is really no different to what you would find in most major cities in the world. In saying that, the train services run frequently and provide a service that is the most efficient in the world and As for the hotel, we found our rooms to be clean, spacious with a view overlooking Rainbow Bay and the water of Tokyo Bay. The bathroom and toilet area were excellent with a range of toiletries provide free; such as hand shavers, face towels; tooth brush & paste as well as the other usual toiletry items. With regards to organizing our daily travel plans, the concierge and the other staff were most helpful in giving advice and offering alternative ideas when the days weather was unsuitable for what we had planned. All in all it is a wonderful hotel in an excellent area that has something to offer for most people be they young or old.

The hotel is clean, modern, excellent wifi and very friendly staff.Things you should know:-The location is isolated so every time you want to go into Tokyo you need to take a monorail at 640Y return.and 25 minutes.-The breakfast is not for Western tastes, besides being outrageously priced at 3,000Y the choice is very limited with cold scrambled eggs, fatty cold bacon stripes and really nothing else of consequence. A NOT TO DO- If your looking for a late check out be aware they calculate a charge that in our case was 1/3 of the room costs for two hours !!!!Other than that the rooms are spacious, clean and very comfortable

This is a good option to central Tokyo. Easy access by metro to central Tokyo. Easy airport access via shuttle bus. Free bus to Disney. We had connecting rooms to accommodate a family and found a great rate on hotels.com. If you know NYC, think of it as the Hyatt at Exchange Place in Jersey City for about 1/2 the price.

We were staying in this hotel for three nights before a cruise around Japan and Korea. We couldn't believe the size of this Hotel. We were given a lovely large twin beded room with a lovely bathroom full of lovely toiletries . There was a water boiler with different teas and coffee's this took so time to get used too. The bed linen was beautiful and great big pillows. We slept very well. The next morning we went up to the 30th floor Resturant for breakfast. The views over Diabia are wonderful from here over the bay of Tokyo. The breakfast was quite expensive but there was a very good selection of cooked and continental food. We breakfasted here every morning. There is a very good supermarket attached to the hotel and a lovely bakery if you want anything else. I had lovely orange French pastries here. There is a monarail attached to the hotel and this takes you into the centre of Tokyo. There is also several Malls within walking distance. We are in our 80s and thought with this hotel being in Tokyo Bay it might have been a bit out of Tokyo for us. But in fact it was just right. We went on several tours including Mt.Fuji and the bullet train and a tour of Tokyo and were picked up at the hotel door. The hotel staff were very helpful and the WiFi in the rooms were a extra bonus. We would certainly stay at this hotel again. And now we are clued up on the Metro system it would make it idea. You don't need to eat at the hotel as there are several restaurants within walking distance.

Loved this hotel.only a monorail ride away from Tokyo Central stations .Lively atmosphere along waterside in the evening with bars & restaurants.Super room overlooking the harbour - the higher the better. Breakfast excellent buffet. Had same trouble with vouchers as stonemen reviewer so went downstairs and managed ok.Depends on airport for grading of good access.

We stayed here for three nights before going on a cruise, which gave us time to recover from the long flights and time difference. As a base for seeing Tokyo it was perfect, although the hotel is on a man made island the transport system is clean and punctual. There is a monorail station next to the hotel which links to the JR and metro lines. The area around the hotel is a shoppers paradise and there are plenty of places to eat in the shopping centres. For a bit of peace from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo take a walk by the river, where you will also find Tokyo's statue of liberty.The hotel staff were welcoming and very helpful, printing off maps and giving advice on the best way to get to places. They even loaned us a transformer (bought up to our room) so that we could charge our camera batteries. We didn't eat in the hotel as we like to explore and try the local food but others that did, said the meals were amazing.Would recommend this hotel to others and if we go back to Tokyo will stay again.

I am writing this review 1/2 hour after eating $30 per person breakfast at the hotel's 30 floor buffet restaurant. We entered the restaurant at its opening time, 6:30. The first thing we faced was a gauntlet of staff who wanted to find out if we had a service ticket (we didn't), then another person lead us down a hall to turn us over to another person who finally seated us. We went to the buffet line. My wife and I we immediately disappointed with the food selections. The pancakes were cold, the only potato offering "tatter tots" were obviously an out-of-the-box variety, the rolls and breads looked and tasted as if they had been acquired at the local convenience store and the overall presentation of the food was downright awful, nothing looked appealing. Then suddenly at 7:00 the entire wait and buffet staff changed, a chef appeared from nowhere to offer custom made fresh omelettes but we had already eaten some rather tasteless scrambled eggs. When we left the restaurant we noticed that the omelette starts at 7:00. Why this hotel doesn't offer its full breakfast when it opens at 6:30 is beyond my ability to grasp! I suggest skipping the hotel's breakfast and go to Bill's Restaurant where we ate yesterday morning. It's half the price of the hotel's breakfast buffet and was really delicious. It's about a 10 minute walk from the hotel.The hotel room was great, we were on the 19th floor looking out over the water.

The Grand Pacific appears to be a little way from down town Tokyo, but for around £2.00 per person you can reach most other tube lines and thereby most other destinations in Tokyo. We visited many Temples, Shrines and shopping areas on our own using the Grand Pacific as our hub. The Japanese people are very friendly and helpful, making even the most adventurous jouney a pleasure. The staff in the hotel are also very helpful and will print out maps and directions for you if required.

We stayed at this former Le Meridien hotel on La Daiba island in late May before going on a cruise departing from Yokohama. We had been traveling around the island of Honshu for 10 days before reaching Tokyo and rather than carrying our big suitcase (cruise-wear tuxes and formal gowns) around, we had it shipped from our first stop in Osaka. ($15 to ship a 50 lb suitcase from Osaka to Tokyo!). Ten days later, as we were still checking in at the Grand Pacific Le Daiba, our suitcase was brought forward. How did they know? Amazing.After checking in we needed to print out our luggage tags for the cruise, but couldn't get the pay printers to work. So the staff refunded the money we spent on the printer and gave us access to their own computer, which was able to print everything for us.The room was very large and although we did not have a view of the famous Rainbow Bridge, our view of the harbor was excellent.Upon checking out we were concerned about getting the proper trains to go to Yokohama. This is where the extraordinary care was given. The assistant manager, Kenichi Nihonishi, who had been at our beck and call throughout our stay, introduced us to Essaid Sadoudi, the concierge, and together they pulled up our cruise ship on their computer, located its pier, and printed out detailed instructions on how to get to our destination train station, and then which exit to take and how to walk to the ship.Then Mr. Nihonishi actually left the hotel and walked us to the monorail station and helped us buy the necessary tickets. Although this was a bit of overkill, we nevertheless appreciated the special care and attention extended to us.As for accessibility,l the hotel is on a man-made island accessible by bus from Shinagawa station or by monorail from Shimbashi station. Either way, don't be intimidated about its location. A large mall is adjacent to the hotel, complete with restaurants and several floors of upscale shops. We will return gladly to the hotel on future travels to Tokyo.

We were in Grand pacific in july as the first hotel of our trip in Japan.the hotel is really good, clean and with nice rooms ( bigger than the average in japan ).it is very easy to reach because the monorail stops in front, and very near there is a mall in which have dinner or breackfast. There is even a shop open 24 hours for food. Only note not positive is that it is far from the centre, and u need to buy an extra ticket for the monorail, so the costs raise every time u move from there. But if u like to see all tokyo from a differen perspective and stay in a releative quiet zone it is a must. The hotel is reachable in 20 minutes by taxi from haneda airport

I stayed several times at this hotel, spread over several years. I noticed how the hotel has slowly changed from an excellent international hotel (in previous years under the French Le Meridien group) to a more independent luxury hotel, serving local clients visiting the nearby Disneyland Tokyo, or using the hotel for wedding celebrations.Rooms are very luxurious (although there are significant differences in size of the room and the bathroom) and very clean, with all kinds of toiletry amenities in the bathroom, according to Asian practice.Very diversified breakfast buffet, with all kinds of choices from European continental breakfast, American breakfast or Japanese/Asian style of breakfast.However, I was very very disappointed by the service of the reception desk: upon early arrival from an intercontinental long distance flight from Europe, it was impossible to get a room before 12 am! Standard check-in time is only at 3 pm, and for a 25% additional day charge, I could bring it to an "early" check-in at 12 am. So upon arrival in the hotel, I had to wait for 2,5 hours in the lobby! Reason not to go back, since most flights from Europe arrive in the early morning.For this hotel, it is most convenient to arrive via Haneda airport, which is only 20 minutes and more frequently connectly to the hotel by the white-orange Friendly Airport Limousine busses. Narita is 1h20 and only 4 or 5 connections per day.Another big disavantage is the waiting times at the breakfast restaurant, because of all the Disneyland-goers. Never experienced at any other hotel a waiting time for breakfast of 20 minutes!Conveniently located for business travel, when visiting trade shows at Tokyo Big Sight.Splendid view from 34th floor with the breakfast restaurant over the Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo skyline with Tokyo Tower.

The location is perfect. Shopping and restaurants nearby. A train stop is right in front of the hotel. There is also a convenience store open 24/7. The room size is adequate for three people (we have three beds for three people). The hotel is not cheap but I can definitely say that it's worth the money that I paid for.

We booked through booking.com and got low price for this hotel. The hotel is not in Tokyo therefore you have to take a train (not cheap) to go anywhere. Hotel itself is excellent. Huge lobby, large size room and friendly staff. Surrounding area is nice too. Due to the jet lag, we got up early every morning and got to walk around, check out the rainbow bridge and Statue of Liberty with no one in sight. It is a good choice hotel is the price is right.

This is not a cheap hotel, but the location was prime, in the heart of Odaiba. Within walk distance to replica of Liberty statue, unique Fuji TV building, Diver city mall, Aquacity and Decks. Train station located right in front of lobby. Convenient if you want to go to Tokyo city. This hotel was great. If you lucky to have your room's windows heading to Rainbow bridge, you can see spectacular Tokyo night view with Rainbow bridge. Unfortnately if your room's floor doesnt high enough, Nikko hotel blocked your view.

My Japanese colleague booked this hotel for us as we had a fair at the Big Tokyo Sight.The train stops in front of the of the hotel so this is a perfect location for people who need to visit a fair there. Only 4 stops away.Although the hotel is not in down town Tokyo there are plenty of shopping and dining opportunities on walking distance.The rooms are clean and well equipped. Sufficient space, for Tokyo's understanding even big.The hotel price is absolutely worth for what you get. This is not true if you have to pay for breakfast , price was not in comparison with what was offered.Language was sometimes a problem when communicating with the bell desk. The tv remote also was quite a puzzle.All in all good hotel.

We spent three nights at this hotel prior to going on a cruise. The room size was fantastic (see my pictures) and extremely comfortable. The external areas around the hotel lobby level is a totally traffic free zone, providing safe and easy access to numerous shopping malls and eateries. The park area between the hotel and Rainbow Bridge provides a lovely setting for evening walks, or even jogging for me! There is a small sandy beach area along this stretch. The monorail line, which is directly outside the hotel provides quick and easy access to Tokyo City (after changing at Shimbashi station). Staff at the hotel are extremely polite and helpful and the breakfast meal (included in our package) was superb, with plenty of choice for both Japanese clients and westerners such as ourselves. Without question, this is a 5 star hotel that lives up to its rating.

We spent two nights at this hotel. Given we live in a large city, the location of this hotel was a peaceful respite for us. The surrounding area, while not really 'authentic Tokyo' was still very interesting to walk around and there were some tasty restaurants to eat at. The highlight restaurant for us was the sushi train in diver city, and the one in Venus fort. Really fresh, reasonably priced and the digital side of it was fun too! There's stacks of other restaurants and cuisines to choose from too.The monorail line was directly outside the hotel and, as it connected with Shimbashi station, it made it pretty painless to get to the central city. The room size was wonderful and extremely comfortable. We were lucky to be put on the 27th floor so had great harbour views.If you want to stay in the heart of busy Tokyo, this is probably not the place for you. But if you're keen to stay in an area that's quiet and has fresh sea air this is a great choice.

Our family stayed at Club rooms for a week. Checked in direct at L27. Service was delicate and friendly. Hotel staff remember our name. Club lounge offers free flow of drinks, lliquor, champagne and snacks at happy hour. Our room was marvelous with Rainbow Bridge view. Connectivity is easy with Daiba station + Rainbow shuttle Plenty of shopping malls and eateries around within the same neighbourhood. We dined at Teppan-yaki "HAMAYU", it was value for money and food & service was impeccable. Dinner at L30 Dining&Bar "STAR ROAD" was okay. Free transportation to Tokyo Disney Resorts. We stayed 2 nights at Disneyland Resort Hotel.Value for money and comfortable and relaxing stay for Family and young children.

This is a perfect corner for business or family traveller. The money is for the value. Located in a modern reclamation landscape, the hotel offers awesome surroundings for sightseeing, dining, and shopping, primarily Japanese food product. The room is superb: fantastic view, elegant interiors, and hi-tech appliances. Warm water is available even in your toilette. Should you have to wait longer for international breakfast floor, just decide to move to the Japanese-style breakfast lounge. It is far better! Remember that the check-in time is 15:00. The Japanese is very discipline with timing. Without having to leave further to the town and spending your value time in public transport or expensive taxi, this hotel and its nearby surroundings serve integrated travellers’ life-supports, all just within walking distance.

The Grand Pacific was a bit of a disappointment. Located a fair distance from the city, it is its own little island surrounded by shopping malls. If you are visiting Tokyo to shop for overly priced items, then this is the right place. The hotel views are mainly blocked by the property in front except for the very top floors. We had to argue with the reception desk in order to get the room we had purchased on the web. Breakfast was marginal, a wait of 30-45 mins due to crowd, and mostly gone by the time we got seated. Overall, the hotel was way overpriced, isolated, crowded, and noisy.

We stayed 4 nights in this hotel.The room is in good size and we feel comfortable during our stay there. We can rest well at night. We have breakfast at the top floor every morning, the view is good but the food is almost the same every day. There are many shopping centres nearby and we have no problems moving around at all.This hotel is a good choice for staying in Tokyo.

We stayed here for one night. The hotel is very luxurious and in a great location, with amazing views across the bay and the rainbow bridge. Our room was large, very clean and equipped with everything you could need. We had cocktails in the main bar and were very impressed with the atmosphere and the skills of the bar men. We went out to eat at Bills restaurant at Decks and thoroughly recommend it, especially the wagyu beef burgers! We would love to come back to this hotel.

We booked 3 months in advance and was able to secure a very attractive room rate. However, the hotel was packed, and we were unable to get the Rainbow bridge facing view.Rooms were big by Japanese standard. The double bed looked like 2 king beds combined. The room for 3 persons had 3 super single beds, good enough for a family.Hotel is connected to the Daiba monorail station on the Yurikamone line. But tickets were expensive. Hotel also offers shuttle (cheaper than the monorail tickets) to Shinagawa station. There is free shuttle to/from Disneyland, as well as the area within Odaiba. Airport limousine also stops in the hotel, so it's very convenient to/from airport.Across the hotel is Aqua city, which offers cheaper alternatives to restaurants as compared to the hotel, which is overpriced, and food is only average. Connecting the hotel and Aqua city is a fantastic view of the Rainbow bridge and the miniature Queen of Liberty. Good photo-taking place.This is a good hotel if you are travelling with small kids, as the rooms are big enough, and there are plenty of attractions for kids nearby (LEGOLAND discovery centre, Trick Art Museum, Madam Tussard, ferris wheel, Disneyland etc).

We stayed here before picking up our cruise .the room was was great ,big bathroom ,amazing views over the bay , we had a snack in the bar on our first night with a drink which we found very expensive ,so the only meals we had was breakfast as we had vouchers ,the hot food was only warm. amazing views from the restaurant which is on 30th floor , we had our evening meals in the shopping malls near by .which we found very reasonable priced . All in all great place to stay location great.easy access to city by monorail which is only across a walkway outside hotel .
user_name:
Winnie1950
Isle of Man, United Kingdom

review_body: As Tokyo is so large, and so hard to find any CBD as such, it was hard to choose a hotel from afar in which to make a base for four days to sightsee Tokyo from. We chose Grand Pacific, and as it turned out was a great choice. Why? It has it all! Spacious, luxurious rooms, good food, fantastic views, capable & friendly staff in all parts of the hotel but most of all in a GREAT location Why? - 1. can walk 7 mins to ferry which goes across the harbour under the beautiful Rainbow Bridge, sparkly by day & all lit up at night, so very pretty & always busy! Connects with other sightseeing ferries to go up and down the harbour, as well as the river too. 2 can train it with the driverless train which runs literally at hotel door into the city for a very cheap price $3AUD each way where you can explore, shop and walk about. 3. you can walk across 3 different ways using overhead bridges to 3 major shopping centres which all have good eateries and restaurants which some overlook the Rainbow Bridge & so can enjoy good food & a great view whilst eating for a very reasonable price. 4. Can walk to the "Statue of Liberty" copy and admire as it's just at most 7 min walk. Can get free bus from hotel to Disneyland Tokyo , leaves 2 times a day and also returns & is for free each leg of the journey. 5. Can purchase airport bus transfer - about 1 hr travel time straight to airport, no fuss and hotel will handle your luggage, all makes it easier on that last day! 6. Is a great hotel with restaurant on the 44th floors for breakfast & dinner for everyone to enjoy, with spectacular views all over the harbour, all huge glass windows to admire through, of the Rainbow Bridge & all the boats plying back and forward - makes memorable scenery & gives a feeling of class and living the "high" life for a very reasonable tariff per night. All in all a fantastic experience! We would highly recommend it.

Stayed there on vacation with family. Large, luxurious rooms, great service, great location in the center of Odaiba and literally across from the train station. Not very convenient to the western and central Tokyo, but great if you are interested in a few quiet days or hitting the malls and amusements in Odaiba. Spectacular views of Tokyo or the port from most rooms.

I was travelling with two friends and had booked a triple room and i have to admit so slightly apprehensive as i wasn't particularly expecting much in terms of space but was very pleasantly surprised. The room was large enough for the three of u to give each other some space after a hard days sightseeing and the bed was also extremely comfortable. Our room also had a excellent view over the rainbow bridge and if you knew where to look the replica of the statue of liberty. Also tour buses made pick ups at the hotel which were convenient for visiting mount fuji and the like.The hotel is conveniently close to Haneda Airport but only if you take the irregular shuttle bus or a taxi as the metro and monorail options seem to bypass this area, and to get into the heart of Tokyo you do have to rely on the Yurikamome line which being a private line you need to have a separate ticket to the day passes available on the tokyo metro and the jr lines which can be a little annoying.We didn't use any of the dining options in the hotel as they looked very costly for what they were

The most comfortable hotel in my recent 8N japan trip. The hotel was also nicely located just beside Daiba station. Whilst it cost more about 300 yen each way between shimbashi to Daiba on the Yurikamome line, I feel it is alright for the hotel rate . The hotel has provided alternatives to taking the Yurikamome train by offering shuttle service to shinagawa or free shuttle to teleport station on Rinkai line. The hotel has a 24hr convenience shop to cater to all your needs. Daiba is a great location with plenty to do ie shopping malls, park, places of interest etc. Will stay here again, especially if planning to go Disneyland .

I was on a tour of Japan last summer. This happened to be the first hotel that I stayed in. I got to Japan a little early so I stayed a couple nights early. The hotel is really amazing. Very friendly people, the service is great.The restaurants in the hotel are top notch. I miss the Japanese Oshima restaurant. Really good breakfast.Shopping is everywhere in and around the hotel. Most in walking distance.There is the unmanned tram that takes you across the bay to Tokyo within walking distance of the hotel.The staff is very friendly and courteous.There is no Wifi in the hotel. Just on the main floor. However, every room does have a wired eithernet connection.I will be staying again on my next trip to Tokyo.

We stayed here for two nights. We had the other view: the highway, parking lot, Ferris wheel, unmanned train, mall, some pier views. The wide window and being on the 20th allowed an expansive view. Although not a view of the bridge, I thought this view was impressive. The room was roomy and comfortable. This bathroom did not have a tub, but the shower stall was wide and long. It had all the amenities as usual in all the Tokyo hotels I stayed in. I never worry about forgetting anything because the Tokyo hotels have about everything you need or don't need. We had the breakfast buffet on the top floor for one morning and the next morning in the lobby restaurant. Because of the view from the top floor, the restaurant can be crowded. I much prefer the lobby restaurant especially if you already have the bridge view from the room. It is not crowded and the variety of food is better. The only thing not impressive was the hotel lobby. The access to shops and restaurants is easy from here, but only if you are going to stay in the area. You can take the unmanned train to areas outside of Odaiba, or take bus to Shinagawa Station. Buses are at street level.

Room: Clean and relatively spacious. Our room had a great view of the rainbow bridge.Service: The most outstanding point of the hotel. Absolutely impeccable. I would give it 10 stars if possible. Everyone was extremely helpful and friendly.Location: Depends on where you are going. It is rather far from the typical city locations (about half an hour to Akihabara, Shinjuku), and the Yurikamome line is rather costly. But it is rather close to Disneyland and Haneda airport. Moreover, it is actually at walking distance from various malls at Odaiba (Diver city, Aqua city, etc).

Stayed here for three nights prior to cruise, it was fabulous. Amazing room overlooking the water and Statue of Liberty!!!! Excellent location, with amazing links into Tokyo City, a gentle introduction into Tokyo. Room very spacious, and bathroom the biggest I've ever seen in a hotel. Lots of lovely goodies provided, never ate in the restaurant so cannot comment. Fabulous meal in Indonesian restaurant in mall opposite. Would highly recommend this hotel and it's very helpful staff.

This was our last hotel stay in Tokyo before heading off to Narita and the UK; we stayed for 2 nights in a superior room with excellent views over the bay, Rainbow Bridge and Tokyo tower in the distance. Access to the hotel could not be simpler - 2 minute walk from the monorail Daiba stop.Our room was spacious with plenty of storage and hanging space, the bathroom was a little extravagant with double doors and ornate light fittings! We did not eat at the hotel as there are plenty of eateries within the shopping malls such as Aqua City and Diver City. The hotel is large and business like but we felt more welcome here than we did at all the other western style hotels. The desk clerk did look a little surprised when I checked out with cash and not a credit card!Close by there are many shopping malls, a Ferris wheel, the Emerging Science and Innovation Museum, Webcam and GUNDAM! Everything in the area feels artificial and characterless, but what do you expect on a manmade island? A train ride back to the city takes around 30 minutes or so.

The hotel is just next to the station with convenient links to Tokyo. There are shopping centres and supermarkets nearby. The hotel itself was fine, the room we had was big and had a nice view, we stayed for two nights in a superior double room.

This hotel has really nice rooms with nice views overlooking Tokyo bay and the rainbow bridge.The food in the hotel - I ate at the Chinese restaurant was really niceThe location is good because the sky rail is at your door - and just an inexpensive hop into Ginza or Tokyo The area itself (not being a Disney guy) is a bit motherless - its seems to have been built by a property developer - and sometimes you build it and people do not come ! I do feel with these large hotels (I mean it took us an hr to find the pool) that they need to spend a little more time informing guests about their facilities - we discovered the bar and the Chinese restaurant almost by accident.The other think for us is that we are nonsmokers and I do feel Japanese restaurants need to separate smoking and non smoking areas - we would have stayed longer in the bar if the guys next to hadn't lit up. The Chinese restaurant was actually non-smoking! Its the first Hotel too that I have had to pay to use the pool - although this seems to be a Japanese 5 star thing where they lease out the gym and pools to a club - and you have to pay to get access to them.In the end we really enjoyed our stay in this hotel - the room the view were really nice

Hotel is near to shopping malls -- Diver City, Aquacity & Decks. There are a lot of attractions surrounding the location. You can even see the Tokyo Tower at night, its quite romantic.The view outside the room has a very nice view to the sea.

This is one of the best hotels I have stayed in Tokyo.good location ( near shopping area) , good staff, restful sleep.it is a good hotel not only for tourists but also business people.the hotel has a good wifi connection.a highly recommended hotel for those of you who want comfort and luxury.

This was a lovely hotel to stay at and feel a little bit of luxury. The staff are friendly, attentive and happy to help. It's close to a couple of good malls and right next to a train line which was easy enough to navigate.

We stayed in this hotel from 21st May to 29th may. I am happy about the choice I made in choosing this hotel. The view from our room was simply awesome. we were in the 19th floor and had a lovely view of the sea and the skyscrappers that illuminated interestingly in the night. Such peaceful sight during night times.The hotel is ofcourse far from the centre of the city, if that is not the criteria and dont mind taking metro to reach the city then you will enjoy the stay. The hotel is well connected to the metro station, in fact the station stop looks like a dedicated stop just for the hotel. To reach the centre Daiba-Shimbashi-Metro to desired station. One way for one person costs to Shimbashi costa 320 yen. I do wish that the swimming pool and Gym were not charged.Thats the only minus I felt.Staff very helpful, room service, house keeping totaly good.Interestingly there is the aqua city and the mall that is infront of the hotel and the Currency exchange ATM is a great convience inside the mall.Vegetarian guys will def suffer a little (everywhere except India) in Tokyo. Overall I recommend this hotel.

This 5 stars hotel is located at Odaiba area. It has a big luxurious rooms, and also the bathroom. The view is so beautiful, you can see the beautiful rainbow bridge at night. Good location, well conected to many shopping malls such as diver city, aqua city, the decks, all malls can be reach with 10min walking distance from hotel.

We stayed here for 2 nights as part of our Japan Deluxe tours package. The location of the hotel is fantastic, and the trains were easy to navigate from here. We were able to walk to the nearby malls of Aqua City, and we were able to walk to Diver City to see the Giant Gundam Statue, which was awesome. The little convenience store outside the hotel had many different food selections that they would heat up for you to take back to your room, and also had the best red bean paste sticky buns of the whole trip! If we had known that store was there the first night, we would have saved a lot of money on dinner. The hotel's room service menu was outrageously priced, and the burger and fries we ordered were undercooked and not very tasty. The room was nice, clean, well appointed; the bathroom was lovely and clean. The beds were very comfortable, the room was well insulated and quiet. We had a spectacular view of the "rainbow bridge" and a lovely cityscape both day and night. We were on a very high floor, and the view was really wonderful. The hotel's breakfast buffet was delicious and grand, with excellent choices for both western and local fare. The little sausages were yummy, and their burdock roots and daikon breakfast dishes were fabulous. We did not have a single complaint about the breakfast buffet or the service of the wait staff or the rest of the hotel staff. It was a lovely hotel, and we enjoyed our stay here. I would certainly recommend it.

An excellent hotel, well priced, with spacious rooms, great views, clean well kept and lots of amenities. Only downside it is on a private subway train you have to pay separately from either the JR or metro system. Not too much else really close by, but it being on an island meant great views and quiet as can be in Tokyo, yet only 15 minute by train to the heart of the city. Not much for breakfast so they could use a cafe that was reasonable, but I hear there is lots more coming to these little man made island. The reasonable prices made up for the small inconveniences.

Traveling with kids, you have to find a place that's near their type of entertainment. That means temples and kabuki theaters take a back seat to wax museums, arcades and Disneyland. Well this hotel is walking distance to the first two and a free shuttle bus ride to the last one. And for the grownups, lots of department stores to walk to and a convenient train right outside the hotel to the main spots of Tokyo! Speaking of convenience, there's a convenience store also right outside the hotel.Rooms are Western and not Japanese in size, meaning their huge. And the hotel boasts anything you would expect from a four star rating, yet the price is so affordable, I first thought I booked one room instead of two. Save yourself the hassle, book here and enjoy your stay in Tokyo.

Stayed here for a week and really liked it.Located on an island facing the city (from what I heard it is an artificial island which used to be a waste dumping site - certainly not any more!).Great restaurants, excellent bedrooms (mine had a fantastic view).Located a few meters away from the metro system (must use it, it takes you downtown Tokyo in a few minutes and has amazing views of the city).Also located at walking distance from large shopping malls (I'm not a shopping fan, but wanted to get things for my family, and it was quite easy).

This was one of the best hotels that we stayed in 5 Japanese cities. large building, elegant reception and foyer, perfect professional well dressed english speaking staff that make you feel valued. very Nice classic rooms, high quality soft beds and sheets, classic elegant design, immaculately clean. superb bathroom fit for a king. 2 or 3 english channels on the TV, tea and coffee facilities in room. The Mini bar fridge was empty but there was a convenience store on the reception level right outside the hotel that sells everything you might want so that was great! there is also a segafredo coffee shop right outside and the train stop, the location is very good. If we needed anything we picked up the phone and they were there in minutes with ice, ironing board etc.. Great service. they have a shopping centre right next to the hotel. Nice bar on the top floor selling Champagne by the bottle or glass. Have no doubts this is a great hotel.

We booked this hotel for the proximity to Haneda and the free shuttle to the airport, but as it turns out the shuttle runs from 8.30, so we could not take it.Another annoying thing is check in at 3pm and considering we left at 6am the following day, the room did not come cheap.The hotel is absolutely massive and extremely busy with people coming and going. The room and the whole hotel in general has a feel of dated about it; it is very clean and all is functional, but it needs a bit of updating.Very nice views on Tokyo bay, but my impression was that it is more suited for a business trip, rather than holiday. I am glad I stayed just one night.

We had a great stay hotel staff were all very friendly. Free disney shuttle was great. Wifi very fast in room and free. Nice malls with plenty of dining options. The transit stop was very close and on the hotel property. We would love to return!

After months of researching we ended up staying here for six nights. We arrived early so went for a walk before checking in. We didn't end up getting to the hotel to late afternoon as there were beautiful promenades, spring flowers, a jazz festival and malls galore. Just loved the location of this hotel and even though it seemed to cater for business travellers they were so so friendly and accommodating to us with a young son. Couldn't ask for more and will definitely be back. There is a free shuttle to disneyland, is only about a minutes walk to the rail and a lovely area if you are a family. Very relaxing area and a large room and bathroom

This is a huge hotel in what I would say is almost a regency style that you would see in some London hotels. The hotel has a classy feel, staff are friendly and helpful and rooms although a little smaller than Hilton and Hyatt have still plenty of room and great views. The location is right next to the station and therefore easily accessible to other districts in Tokyo. The location is in a bit of a buzzing area with plenty of shops some within a really odd shopping centre which is like being in a Mediterranean town. There are plenty of options for eating nearby too. We stayed here just one night before heading back to Oz but it would have been perfectly comfortable for much longer stay. It is also not that far from Disney Tokyo so an option instead of staying in the resort hotels.

This was our first visit to Tokyo and the Grand Pacific turned out to be a great base from which to explore the city. The station being just a few steps from the hotel lobby made getting around very easy once we had mastered the rail network map and ticketing options (ask at the Bell Desk for an English version of the map). We took two adjoining rooms which were identical. Large comfy beds, a fridge, good living space and effective black-out curtains helped make our nine day stay very comfortable. We ate only once in the hotel at the buffet restaurant at the lobby level - it was okay. We found better dining options in the city and at the two malls located within walking distance of the hotel. All of the staff we encountered were polite, efficient and professional. Overall it was a very pleasant stay and we would use this hotel again.

While not in the centre of Tokyo only a short walk to a station so good location. Great views from the hotel room, which was one of the best I have stayed in. Good breakfasts, either a buffet or set Japanese style meal and plenty of places to eat lunch/dinner if not always wanting to venture further. Good view of Mt Fuji while eating breakfast. The staff very helpful.

Excellent location within easy walking of all shopping malls, tourist sightseeing, rail transport and Sky Hop Bus. Lovely parks and beach. Great views no matter which side of hotel, either Rainbow Bridge or harbour and city views. Handy 24 hour Convenience store on site and Foodcourts in adjacent Aqua City Mall for cheap quick dining. Excellent amenities in bathroom, housekeeping service efficient and clean. Friendly and efficient staff in Reception areas. Would highly recommend to all travellers looking for great rates for a top class hotel, great service and great location.

After fying in from Okinawa we caught an Airport Limosuine bus from Haneda Airport to the front door of the hotel and left our baggage until checkin. The foyer of the hotel alone plus the numerous staff on duty hinted at what was to be a quite luxurious hotel stay. While checking in we wre advised that we'd been upgraded and we found ourselves on the 24th floor with magnificant views out over the harbour including the Rainbow Bridge. The room was simply enormous even by Australian standards. From the hotel front door there is a free shuttle bus that travels around Odaiba. Within a short walk is the Yurikamome station Diaba which provides access via a fully automated rail system to the major railway interchange at Shimbashi Station. The Teppan-yaki restaurant "HAMAYU" on the 30th floor, although expensive, was an excellent experience which also afforded commanding views of the city lights including Tokyo Tower in the distance. Breakfast the next morning in the Lobby Café "LE BOUQUET" offered a wide selection of Japanese and Western options. This hotel provided a rather opulent and splendid ending to our wonderful 22 day holiday.

I was looking for a quick 1 night hotel in Odaiba since I was going to an event at the Diver City Mall. Luckily this hotel was having a special that was perfect for me. I really was lucky with the special because after walking through the front doors I know I wouldn't have been able to afford it otherwise. The opulence is just staggering. Beautiful décor throughout lobby, halls, and room. Plus the size of the rooms are amazing for a hotel in Japan. Definitely exceeds even American/European standards. Bathrooms provides both a bath & separate standing shower. Staff was extremely friendly & helpful. I arrived early & had to go to my event so I just dropped off my luggage & didn't return to check in till around 8pm. Location: Odaiba station is right outside the side door. Plus there are a multitude of shops all around. Diver City Mall, with the giant Gundam, is just a walk across an overpass on the same side the station is. Really convenient since I thought I would have to take the train again to get there. Plus Joyopolis, the giant ferris wheel, statue of liberty, & the docks shopping area are all either a bit of a walk or a 2 minute train ride away. Also the hotel offers free shuttles to Disney.Would definitely stay there again if I could.

The hotel is located right next to Daiba station, so very convenient to access via public transport. Also, there's a bus stop for free shuttle buses going around Odaiba area. I also saw a sign for free shuttle to Tokyo Disneyland.We were given a room where we can see Tokyo Tower and the Rainbow Bridge, and the view was really nice. The room is clean and spacious. The bathroom was a little dated, but the amenities they offer is the best I have ever seen. They give you bath salt, special towel to wash your body, toner, face moisturiser, etc. They even give you a little pouch to take amenities back home :-)We had breakfast at a restaurant on the lobby level. The quality and selection of food was excellent, and they even had ice cream!I recommend you to book the hotel early as they have special rates for advance purchase.

The lobby are really amazing and my girlfriend told me that this place is popular for Japanese wedding. My girlfriend booked a top suite and the room was wonderful and good quality. The bed was very soft and comfortable to sleep. The view from our window was fantastic! The shower and whirlpool tub are very relaxing. They included a breakfast voucher which it really nice! My only minor complaint is that they don't have a bath robe size for western man. I am 6'4 feet tall and the bath robe doesn't fit me which it fit to any Japanese men.

Very nice upmarket hotel with excellent service and with a bit of luck spectacular views of the Tokyo Bay and the Rainbow bridge. Location is a matter of priorities. On one hand to get there by public transport you need to change from the metro/train to the elevated Yurikamome line, which also offers great views but is a bit expensive (if I recall correctly, 370 JPY). On the other hand it is a couple of stops from the Oedo Onsen - the Japanese thermal baths- in this case with a theme ancient Oedo period village - bars, restaurants and shops. Highly recommended and enabling to stay all night, relaxing on hot baths and lounging on tatami floor...

Traveled as a group of 9 and spent 4 nights here. Hotel is accessible with a train station a few meters away but location is quite far from Tokyo center. Yurikamome line (which is a private line) is also more expensive than the JR or other subway lines in the city (Y320 vs ave of Y170-210). The Hotel is ideal though if you're travelling with a big group. Value for money price and room size wise. You can ask for connecting rooms. Plus points also that wifi is very fast. Only complain is that rooms are not cleaned thoroughly, coffee cups were left unwashed when we returned to the room after a whole day of sightseeing.

I spent 3 nights for business trip. Wifi connectivity was perfect, for any needs of Skype, VPN, mails and web browsing. Silence allowed me a good concentration, with wider space and wide desk. Direct shuttle bus to Airport greatly helped me to save time, in around 5Euro (Haneda). Bathroom equiped with large sized bus tab. Toilet with washlet and warmer. Amenity was nice. Nothing was missing. Convenience store was there, just next to the hotel. 15min easy travel to Ginza area, over the rainbow bridge and round the daiba beach. 5min walk to casual shopping mall, with less expensive restaurants. 10min walk to daiba beach, where ones overview the center of tokyo with symbolic tokyo tower. Ones might also get a wonderful view from the window by chance. Japanese news paper is delivered each morning for free. Gym with swimming pool costs around 10Euro. There's also japanese large bath space and sauna. Make your reservation to ensure a good price. I recommend this hotel than any other hotels in center of tokyo for the cost performance.

Was a quite goos stay, a little far from city attractions but near metro station and close to malls, cafés. Breakfast was poor but comfortable rooms. Very nice, cheerful staff and can communicate easily in English. Will be a strong alternative at next time.
user_name:
egolgeli
New York City, New York

review_body: Great hotel! Fabulous bathrooms. Clean, quiet and very comfortable indeed. Daiba feels a little out of the centre but you appreciate being out of the hustle and bustle with fantastic transport links on the doorstep of the hotel.

Highly recommended hotel!Everything you need is here. The location is perfect : Just right next to Daiba Station (Yurikamome Line), lots of shopping malls are just within walking distance such as diver city (where the giant Gundam statue is located), aqua city, decks (joypolis) and many more. Tokyo's statue of Liberty is just 3 mins walking distance from hotel and can be seen from my room. The room was really awesome. I booked triple room through Expedia and I requested a high floor with rainbow bridge view room. Before we traveled they emailed and informed me that they afraid our room wouldn't face the rainbow bridge but they'll try to give a high floor room. It is okay for me and wouldn't expect much but the day we checked in the staff brought our bags to our room which was at 26th floor and when I entered the room I was really surprised because the room overlooking the rainbow bridge! This was really fantastic! I can even saw Tokyo Tower, Tokyo Skytree and Tokyo's statue of Liberty from our room. Thanks so much to Grand Pacific Le Daiba! Arigato Gozaimasu! The room was really spacious, clean and comfortable.The bathroom was also spacious with separate shower and bathtub. A basket full of amenities and even hair band, razor, Kanebo skin care and toothbrush are provided. Free WIFI in room and super fast.Free shuttle bus from and to both Disneyland and DisneySea but have to book in advance.The staff were very helpful, friendly and polite. They are really nice!

I had read the Trip Advisor reviews of this hotel before booking and they were great, but unfortunately our experience was not so. Booked an Executive Floor Rainbow Bridge room for $USD623 per night. On checking in was told room we had booked was unavailable, so for the same money (no discount offered even though we asked for one) we had to accept a room on the airport side. Other than one person at reception who was extremely efficient, pleasant and helpful, the rest of the staff were off hand and showed no initiative or personality whatsoever. If asked a question they standard answer was: sorry to keep you waiting, but can't do .... whatever they were asked. Absolutely no initiative. Maybe this is hotel policy for their staff. Location great if attending Big Site - monorail short walk from hotel. The hotel atmosphere is sterile, furniture in our room well worn and a lot of the food offered as hot breakfast items were cold.

Stayed al GPLD for a convention. Everything was perfect. Rooms are quiet and comfortable, ammenities with everything you need and a few estra things one does not really need...all in all, a great hotel, excellent service, conveniently located.

If staying in Odaiba, this is a classy place to stay.Price is not that high considering their space, amenities and service. Spacious rooms with great view, big baths with basket-full of bath amenities, lots of restaurants to choose from, fast wifi internet, gym and heated pools. They have 2 lobbies, lower lobby for group guests and the main lobby for individual guests. You'll never find any of lobbies too crowded at one time. Main lobby has direct access to the Daiba station of Yurikamome line that connects Odaiba to central Tokyo. Same access leads you to the very convenient overhead bridge walk to Aqua City (overlooking the Rainbow bridge), Decks, even over the expressway to Palette Town (with the big Gandam robot) and Megaweb.

This is staying in Tokyo in 5 star luxury. Warm and hearty welcome from everybody,especially the Chief Concierge Ikuyo made my saty a very pleasant one. My room washigh-class on 22nd floor with a breathtaking view over the bay to Tokyo skyline.You should have seen in at nighttime, simply wonderful. Fantastic restaurant on topfloor, go for it while you are there!Location is brilliant too, right beside Diver City complex where I was going to seeBob Dylan, just 5 minutes walking distance, how great.Also easy to rech Tokyo downtown areas by 2 train possibilities. One station just infront of the hotel, another one a ten minutes walk away.I have to mention that the hotel is also easy to reach when you are landing at Haneda.Just take the cheap limousine bus, it wil take you directly to the hotel entrance!Arigato Ikuyo, arigato Grand Pacific Daiba!

Located in Daiba City. This 5 star hotel has it's all. The rooms are well equipped with the best amenities.a wide room with a very comfortable bed. The linens so clean and crisp. The bathroom was so clean with a separate shower and bath tub.There are at least three restaurants you can have breakfast.
