This hotel was minutes from Haneda Airport. We stayed here on a tour. Rooms are very spacious and the bathroom is very luxurious. Love the Toto toilet! Staff was excellent. Hotel even provided us with boxes and tape to use on our trip home

This property is very nice and typically Japanese. We were in Tokyo for a short stopover and need a place to sack out for a couple of hours. The close proximity to Haneda Airport made this the perfect choice. It took about 15 minutes from the airport, albeit at 0300, but how much worse can it be??? The hotel has several points that would be nice to have addressed, first no english TV, maybe BBC or CNN would be nice but it doesn't really take away from the hotel. The rooms are VERY clean and full of amenities. I stayed on the President Level and the room had a mini-minibar ... don't look for a midnight chocolate bar or chips, but beer,scotch and water are in it. There is hot water boiler with coffee and tea available in the room. The restaurants look nice though I didn't have time to try anything. The best thing to remember is that this is Japan and things need to be perfect from their side. The end result is a great stay in a large hotel located near the airport and what appears to be a large shopping mall.

Good hotel, a bit far from the city but right next to a shopping mall with many shops and restaurants. The rooms are not big which is normal for Japan. I like the fact that if you leave the do not disturb sign on the door and dont use the house keeping service you will get a 1000 Yen voucher (Per day) which could be redeemed anywhere in the hotel!

This was a nice hotel with great views and a very convienient location. The room was basic but nice. Breakfast was good and the service was OK. I would definitely recommend it as the place to stay in Odaiba.

Grand Pacific Le Daiba is a very "grand" hotel. I believe is considered a 5 star hotel. I would think for a 5 star hotel they would offer free internet service but they did not. You have to pay 100Y for 15minutes to use. That is why I gave a 4 star rating. Other than that it is a very comfortable hotel. Double room spacious. The bathroom very opulent with double doors and bathtub & shower stall separate. 2 minute walk to Daiba, Yurikamome monorail station. This hotel is not for the budget minded traveler. If you want to treat yourself the Grand would be the place.

The staff are friendly and helpful. The hotel is also very accessible with a train station next to it.The hotel also encourage occupants to "recycle" the towels, bath rodes, whenever possible as part of their "Go Green" effort. Occupants who help with the "recycle" is "rewards" with rebates or vocuhers.
Rooms are basic equivalent to a 3 star,breakfast is pretty ordinary , furniture worn and service is average

If you want a hotel that gives Tokyo Bay/ Rainbow Bridge view and that is not too expensive, check out this one. The room is of generous size by Tokyo standard and the staff are forever friendly and helpful. For those who are not so familiar with Tokyo, Daiba is not entirely close to city central and it is only served by Yurikamone line (which is privately run and one way fare for a 10-15 min ride to Shiodome is 360 yen). But it is well worth as the journey across the bay and bridge is scenic. Hotel is directly served by airport limo, and nearby places like Odaiba park, Aqua City (shopping mall), Fuji TV station etc are all within walking distance. It also provides complimentary shuttle to/ fro Shinagawa GOOS (which is just opposite JR Shinagawa Station) every hour. We got good promotional rates for 4 nights stay and couldn't ask for more really.

With my wife and daughter, we have spent 7 nights in this wonderful hotel.I can easly reccomend this hotel to everyone for every type of stay.It is in very easy place to reach many important part of Tokyo. Also for value against money, it has very high score.

I loved staying here on my first night in Japan. We had a lovely room with glorious views of Tokyo bay. The hotel definitely is GRAND with luxurious carpets, light fittings and curving wrought iron stairways set in grand reception areas. It's very romantic and a hotel to remember. We found the free shuttle service into the city very convenient and we used it in addition to the efficient monorail which is located nearby.We stayed at the Grand Pacific Le Daiba because of its reviews on TripAdvisor and were not disappointed. Read the previous reviews and you'll get an accurate picture of this hotel's high standards.

Thank you so much for your services and accommodations. We really like this hotel and staff. We book online and get free pick up from the airport. We stay at a nice room with sea view window. The breakfast is very delicious, everything is clean and comfortable. We had a chance to view Sakura, it's very beautiful.We had a good time in Japan, we will come back and recommend this hotel to my friend

This is a huge hotel. And seems to be busy all the time! Because I was part of a group, the check-in was handled by a separate desk, which saved a lot of hassles. The first thing that strikes you is its lavish marble and wood lobby, but in terms of architecture it could be anywhere in the world. But the place is littered with the polite bending and bowing and ever-smiling staff, so it could be only one place in the world - Japan! The room I stayed in had a view of the Tokyo Bay/rainbow bridge, which was really out of this world. The view was awesome in the day and even more spectacular at night. The speeding trucks and cars were disappearing into the underwater bridge, as if they were being swallowed and spat out at the same time. As expected, the room is lavishly appointed and was large. The best thing about staying in Japanese hotels are their super-intelligent toilet seats. Here too, it was no exception - the warm seat and the features it has is pure indulgence - all this for only using the potty! The bathroom is large and the amenities the hotel provides is superb. Frequent travellers would love the plethora of brushes and shaving razors and towelettes and what not. I had a dinner buffet and for a vegetarian in Japan, it was no issue at all. Besides the food was good too. Similarly, breakfast was lavish and tasty too. For breakfast there is an option to go to one of the top floors instead of going down to the lobby - I missed it, as it would have been breakfast with a view. There is nothing negative to say about this hotel except for its overtly western outlook in a beautiful and culturally strong country like Japan.

I was a little apprehensive staying here since I read the reviews here at Tripadvisor after I booked the hotel, but I did not regret staying here at all. First of all, to get free Internet in the room just sign up for the frequent stay program, I Prefer (http://www.iprefer.com/iprefer/index.aspx). We also received a free room upgrade! This was my first trip to Japan so I cannot compare the room to other rooms in Tokyo, but our deluxe room was the same size as a room in the US in a Sheraton or Hilton. The amenities, I can't say enough about them. Besides the usual soap, shampoo, conditioner and body lotion there was a razor with a small tube of shaving cream, a brush, comb, toothbrush w/toothpaste, hair band, q-tips, makeup remover pads, a Japanese style wash towel, a skin care kit, bath powder for the bathtub (btw our room included a shower stall). And they replaced anything missing everyday! In the drawers was a pair of packaged nightshirts that were also replaced every day, and if you needed children's size pj's you just had to call housekeeping. The hotel decor is a little dated but let's face it, do you stay in the hotel all day? Outside the bathroom was a vanity with mirror, very helpful to let someone do their makeup/hair while someone else could use the bathroom. And yes, not all the staff spoke perfect English, but we started asking our questions a couple of days in advance and eventually we'd find someone that could answer our questions. The monorail is a 1 minute walk away from the hotel, and a free shuttle goes to the Takanawa Keikyu Hotel in Shinagawa which is a 5-10 minute walk away from the JR Shinagawa station. The 1st shuttle left at 8:30 and ran every hour on the half hour, the return every hour on the hour, the trip taking between 20-30 minutes. Disney had a Good Neighbor bus that picked us up and took us to Disneyland and Disney Sea. This shuttle bus was free but you had to make reservations, only ran at certain times during the day, and took about 30 minutes to get to the parks. A 10-minute walk away from the hotel was Aqua City, a shopping mall like any other in the US, and included a McDonalds. Further past Aqua City is Decks which includes Joypolis, an arcade/amusement park. A 30-minute walk the other way (or you could take a free shuttle or pay 300 yen for a monorail ride) was MegaWeb/Venus Fort, a mall/outlet mall/Toyota showcase. Oh, and yes, the warm toilet seat was a kick, and I really got used to the toilet flushing sound every time I sat down, I kinda miss it. And I almost forgot, the convenience store is very convenient, and open 24 hours.

I Stayed for 3 days at this hotel. Nothing to say about the service: perfect from the beginning to the end.The room was very clean and quiet spacious with a nice view on the Tokyo bay. The hotel location is nice, and there is also a shuttle which takes you every 20 minutes to Shinagawa. You can also take the metro at Daiba station.There were also a nice fitness room and a very nice in door swimming pool. The outdoor pool is nice but very noisy. Note that the breakfast is at the higher level of the hotel with a huge view of Tokyo.Thank you to the whole staff

We stayed here for a few days and April and found our stay very comfortable. Its a very convieniently located hotel with large spacious rooms, great bathrooms and other amenities and good views. I would def recommend this to my fellow travellers

A forewarning - this review is based on a stay in summer of 2009.The reception of this hotel was incredibly welcoming with staff even more welcoming. The hotel is beautiful with high ceilings and very photographic corridors / areas. The rooms were big, plush and very comfortable. The bathroom was just filled with all amenties you could ever need - including one time shaving kits.Unfortunately we did not try the restaurant nor breakfast.The hotel is situated in Odaiba, which is accessible with a monorail connection. Unfortunately the JR pass / metro day tickets are not valid on the monorail and you need a special pass / one time tickets to travel to and from Daiba to other places in the city.The area and also the hotel itself appears to be very popular among wedding celebrations, therefore except wedding parties and guests at the hotel during your stay.Odaiba has huge park areas and at the time a toy company had built a functional 30 metre high Mech(?) robot - how crazy is that!

This hotel is located on Odaiba island, and accessed by an adjacent monorail station. As this monorail is somewhat expensive, not as capacious as a subway car, and not very fast, the hotel is not particularly convenient for activities in Tokyo. Most customers appear to be young couples or groups of mature ladies intent on getting away from urban life.The rooms, while not particularly spacious, are comfortable and well-equipped. The building being high and on an island, most rooms have a good view on Tokyo bay.Due to the size of the hotel, check-out can take a longer time at peak hours.

This hotel is easy to get to via monorail from other parts of Tokyo. If you're looking for peace and quiet, then this is your hotel.The facilities of this hotel are a little confusing as you enter (e.g. Where's the front desk!?), but once you get the hang of it, it's fine. We got two view rooms that offered stunning views of th Rainbow bridge and the Statue of liberty. The view and night was "over the top", and beautiful during the day too.We stayed in three other five star hotels during our visit to Japan, and frankly we found the service here the lowest. Still good, but missing a little. For example, the bell staff's english was so poor, it was hard to communicte with them over the reservation on the airport shuttle bus. The concierge spoke proper english with a french accent. His service was a bit like what you'd get from a four star in Paris...I'm giving you service because you're staying here, but it lacked the warmth and completeness we experienced in other hotels. He delivered enough sarcasam to us to make us all kind of shake our heads...not something you'd find at a five star in US or other japanese hotels.If you have reason to stay in Daiba, then this is a nice alternative. If we had it to do again (it was our last night hotel before we flew home) I'd have picked another area of Tokyo.

If you want to sleep good out of the Tokyo noise, go to this hotel. Luxerious, friendly helpful staff, good beds, big room, big bathroom, big enough closet. Railway station for the train crossing the Rainbow Bridge for downtown Tokyo in walking distance. Shopping everywhere around.

We enjoyed staying in Odaiba despite it being a monorail ride away from the JR lines that encompass Tokyo. The monorail stop is right outside the the entrance. A plethora of shopping and dining choices at Decks and AquaCity are a short walk away. Be sure to visit the technology museum to see Asimo the robot. Also, a free shuttle is offered from the hotel to the Disney parks. There's even a Statue of Liberty ; )This hotel will not put more than 2 people in a superior 2 bed room unless they are 8 or younger.( no roll-away beds I guess) When our son stayed with us for 2 of our nights we had to change rooms to a 3 bedroom and pay a substantial additional charge per night.The convenience store right outside the entrance is a godsend for inexpensive but good snacks and beverages. ( same croissants ,bean rolls, and sushi rolls as the restaurants inside!)

We have just returned from a 3 night stay and were generally quite happy with the hotel. It is a large and luxurious hotel and our room was spacious and well-appointed. We had reserved the ‘airport side’, which is cheaper than the ‘bridge side’ but we found ourselves in a room on the end of the building, so we had a great view in both directions. That was a nice little bonus. The bathroom did not have enough water pressure for a good shower in the mornings, but it was fine in the evenings. The shampoos, etc. are in large refillable containers, which seemed a bit odd for a luxury hotel, and seemed a bit watered-down, but we might be mistaken about that. We only ate one meal in the hotel – a lunch in the Italian restaurant, Collina Del Mare, and it was very good. We asked if breakfast could be included in our room rate, but we were told that it couldn’t be, even as we were watching some other people checking in and being handed breakfast vouchers. We also asked if we could earn frequent flyer points, but we were told that our room rate was too low so it was not possible. The moral of this story is that we should pay more!For a luxury hotel, they do a few things that seem pretty cheap. For example, we could have used the internet in our room – the cable and connection were supplied – but there would have been a charge. There was a computer in a tiny alcove off the lobby with a coin box attached – 15 minutes for 100 yen - about US$1). Why don’t they have free internet, wired or wireless? It seems like a reasonable expectation these days. Also, they have a fitness center, including a pool, but it costs 1,050 yen to use, even for registered guests. As it turned out it was closed for a few days of renovations while we were there, so we couldn’t have used it anyway, but again it’s a cheapskate thing to do. One other thing was annoying – both to us and a friend who was traveling with us: the staff in the lobby. There are too many of them. Walking through the lobby is like running a gauntlet. They are all just standing there waiting to pounce on everyone who passes through. They want to be helpful, but sometimes you just want to walk to or from the elevator without being helped and guided along. It’s overbearing. However, these criticisms are mostly minor, and overall the hotel is very comfortable and quite a nice place to stay.

I stayed here for 10 days in October of 2009 with my sister and had a fantastic time. During the 10 day stay the staff were very helpful. They were great with assisting with maps and directions and recommending places to go in Tokyo. Also, we didn't bring our ipods with us so the staff arranged for a CD player to be brought up to our room and the staff in the gym put our CD on for us whilst we worked out. The hotel itself was very beautiful aswell. Everything was very clean and the area around the hotel is great aswell. The train station is literally minutes away. You just step out of the hotel room and it's there. It is a little ride(just about 15 mins) out from Shimbashi (very close to Ginza), but it's a really nice ride over the Rainbow bridge and the train was never that crowded so you always got a seat. There's also alot of shopping around the hotel aswell. There is a shopping centre just about 3 minutes away from the station and then Venus Fort shopping centre is just about a 10 minute walk aswell, which is a must. (I think we went there everyday) They have lots of restaurants there, mainly Italian food. Absolutely no complaints about this hotel at all, will definitely stay there again and would recommend it to everyone.It's in a really peaceful area, but so close to all the major attractions in Tokyo.

I have stayed at this hotel many times when it was a Le Meridian (Starwood) hotel and prefer it over the Nikko just across the tracks. The staff is very welcoming and professional and take great effort to insure your comfort. Very easy access to the Big Sight and Tokyo by rail. I'd highly recommend for any business traveler. Exceptional hotel food.Enroll in the "I Prefer" hotel program (this is a Summit brand hotel) and get your reward as you check in.
